Oreste's birthplace was Argos, and on the death of his father, the king (who was, incidentally, murdered), he was taken away to Athens to be brought up there by a noble family. When he returns to Argos, he cannot feel a part of the city for the simple reason that he is innocent. He feels innocent, whereas all those citizens born in Argos and living there have supposedly been born into guilt. The entire play seems to be an attack on the Church and religion, especially Catholicism, considering Sartre's atheism.

The entire city of Argos is in perpetual mourning and repentance for a murder of which many were unaware. For those who were present, guilt is theirs because they did not prevent the atrocity. The Queen's mournful clothing and black funereal makeup emphasize the point: there is no happiness in the city. They allow themselves to be ruled by the past, as if trapped in a time-warp, not moving forward or even seeing their futures. Sartre's exaggerated portrayal of the real world and its religion is evident throughout the play. The concept that we are guilty because we are human and governed by the murder of Christ, of which we were unaware, yet must still repent this sin, is a significant theme.

A striking attribute of the play is the plague of flies around and in Argos, enhancing the picture of being totally enclosed and "attacked" by something that Sartre implies is all in the mind. This ability to shock his audience is a powerful attribute, as it guarantees their attention and reaction. By placing a god "on earth," Sartre challenges the notion of divine power. He suggests that they are no greater than humans and that miracles do not justify their servitude under them.

This realization leads him to question the value of life itself. When Clemenceau begins to think more deeply about life, he comes to the conclusion that it is futile. The haunting laugh he heard earlier and his realization that he was always hypocritical in Paris continue to plague him.

When Clemenceau first realizes his past was hypocritical and that he was guilty because the motives for helping others were "wrong," he decides to play the fool. He contemplates acts such as puncturing the tires of wheelchairs. It is when he realizes that absolute innocence is impossible that he decides to aim his life toward absolute guilt. He feels that by confessing his absolute guilt, no one will be able to laugh at him behind his back. This conviction is shaken when he thinks he sees a drowning woman in the sea from the transatlantic liner, and the guilt he feels for not even attempting to save the woman who committed suicide in Paris remains with him, underscoring the themes of guilt and judgment throughout the novel.

In existentialist terms, guilt is intrinsically linked with duplicity. In our quest to reconcile with the absurdity of human existence—the understanding that our innate desire to uncover the truth of the world is thwarted by the incomprehensible nature of the world and by our mortality—one consequence is the portrayal of a guilty nature. This reluctance to accept life's inherent absurdity often manifests through duplicity, as individuals attempt to revolt against it.

In "La Chute," guilt is depicted in various forms and attributed to different characters. Clarence is one such character who embodies guilt. His prior life as a lawyer in Paris was marked by a false sense of innocence and 'oneness.' However, when he hears a scream on the bridge, it triggers a flood of memories and self-recognition. Clarence realizes his previous life was duplicitous; his reflection in the mirror seems double to him as he recognizes he failed to grasp the essential nature of being human. He conducted his 'good deeds' not out of genuine altruism, but for his personal satisfaction in controlling others. He confesses, "His prior life was a guilty one, a duplicitous one." To confront this guilt, he initially seeks to demonstrate his double nature through self-indulgence and debauchery. Yet, unable to escape his guilt, he travels to Amsterdam, a city marred by Nazi atrocities, to fulfill his new role of 'juge-pénitent.' Here, he tries to exorcise his guilt by exposing it to others, thus regaining his sense of superiority and the power to judge. He fantasizes about confessing to a policeman, not out of a desire for punishment but to regain his self-esteem.

To emphasize his sense of guilt after his 'fall,' Clarence invokes legal terminology, referring to the friends he once dominated, illustrating how his duplicity created an insurmountable sense of guilt. His journey underscores the torment and self-consciousness that come with realizing the true nature of one's existence, marked by duplicity and guilt, and the desperate measures one might take to confront and potentially overcome it.

And so Caligula has understood the absurdity of our condition; the fact that we can never possess the world and never have full clarity leaves him with a sense of anguish. Le Mythe de Sisyphe, Camus' novel, is deeply bound with the theme that life is futile yet worth living to the fullest. At its core, the novel grapples with the absurdity of life and suicide, themes that Camus explores meticulously. He begins his essay by attempting to define the absurd, positioning it as the fundamental starting point rather than a conclusion. Camus criticizes other philosophers for failing to recognize the potential of the absurd, often using it only as a final point.

Absurdity emerges when an everyday object suddenly loses its familiar meaning. Camus argues that individuals need 'clairvoyance' or lucidity, emphasizing that people desire and require knowledge. Reflecting the Cartesian view, Camus asserts that the only certainty is 'I think, therefore I am,' highlighting the unattainability of absolute knowledge. The gap between the quest for fundamental truth and the certainty we possess remains unbridgeable.

Camus describes a process leading to the formation of the 'absurd' individual. Initially, an object is detached from its daily meaning. Suddenly, during a mundane task, this meaning is stripped away, rendering the act futile. He explains this sudden awareness of time passing and the resulting self-hatred for not making more of your life. When stripped of the meaning we typically assign to life, every action becomes senseless. Camus articulates the isolation and solitude in recognizing life's absurdity, likening it to a non-functioning light.

Having realized life's absurdity, Camus notes that some individuals attempt to deny it by taking a leap of faith. They seek solace in religion, adopting a stance that Camus critiques. This essay examines these concepts, highlighting the profound insights Camus offers on the human condition.

In Sartrean thinking, Oreste starts off in this play like a blank slate, his project yet to crystallize as he makes no choices to determine his course in life. He has been taught by Pédagogue to believe in traditional and customary ideas and also possesses a false sense of freedom. Thus far, he has acted like a 'free spirit', failing to make any real choices and not realizing his project. 

In the first part of the play, Oreste exhibits signs of innocent bad faith, as he has no past experience and believes that people are predestined. From Sartre's perspective, there is no predestination, as we control our destiny through the choices we make. Furthermore, Oreste feels he could find his past in Argos, an innocent bad faith since we cannot acquire an essence by assuming a social role. He also believes he could develop by taking over in Argos.

Oreste therefore starts in a position of bad faith and moves through the play towards authenticity and freedom of consciousness (pour-soi). This transformation is symbolized by Electre's acceptance of him as her brother and not Philèbe. Primarily, the bad faith of others in the play influences and helps change him. The people of Argos are deluding themselves to escape the anguish of individual freedom and responsibility, viewing themselves as unchanging objects determined by external forces. Their present and future, including their alleged complicity in the murder, are also shaped by past events. Even the children are raised with guilt.

Electre's behavior also plays a crucial role in Oreste's transformation. Initially, she seems to refute his self-remorse, attempting to make others recognize their bad faith. At the 'fête des morts,' she encourages the people to realize their freedom but is ultimately halted by Jupiter's miraculous intervention, parodying the making of Jesus during the miracle of turning a stone. This moment signifies a shift toward authenticity and the potential for change within the community of Argos.

Guilt and judgment are recurring themes in several of Camus' works, particularly evident in the account of Clamence's fall. Clamence's fall is not simply the retelling of an "évenement," but rather an "état de l'âme," in which Clamence becomes imbued with guilt and a desire to judge others. This sense of guilt is implicitly present in the account, as it is focalized through the form of a confession by Jean-Baptiste Clamance, an ex-parisienne lawyer. It is also subtly present throughout the play, alluding to the universal guilt of mankind. Clamance introduces himself as a "juge-pénitent," a term that is clarified only at the end of the novel, demonstrating his tendency to judge people, feel superior, and apportion guilt to those he encounters.

Clamance's former profession as a lawyer supports this theme. In his milieu, guilt was a constant presence, as he defended people guilty of crimes and often sought to prove others guilty. His profession gave him a sense of superiority, which he frequently felt in court, enjoying the satisfaction from looking down on people and judging them. Guilt and judgment are inherent in the legal system.

In Paris, Clamence led what he thought was a happy and satisfying life, finding joy in helping others, which gave him a sense of satisfaction. However, an occurrence—a laugh on a bridge—shaken his current existence and made him aware of his guilt. This pivotal moment shattered his perception of the world and forced him to confront his inner state, highlighting the profound themes of guilt and judgment that pervade his life.

In "Caligula," the narrative unfolds through the interactions among characters, all of whom are assigned a negative or positive valuation that influences our sympathy for Caligula. Caligula's character embodies Camus' theme of the absurd—the irreconcilable conflict between human desires and realities. From Drusilla's death to his own demise, Caligula becomes acutely aware of human mortality and the futility of existence. In doing so, Caligula partially evokes sympathy and admiration for his attempt to help his people live more fully by sharing his profound understanding of the world.

In "le Mythe de Sisyphe," Camus strives to elucidate the concept of the absurd, ultimately contending that life retains intrinsic value despite its inherent futility. Camus, an atheist, argued that humans are born free and possess the agency to choose their path, refusing to succumb to metaphysical constraints or predetermined fates. This belief underscores his conviction that individuals can always alter their way of life. Humanity's relentless quest for knowledge and truth exemplifies an inherent desire to understand and connect with the world. However, this pursuit inevitably encounters a gap, as absolute comprehension necessitates an unfeasible fusion with the subject, resulting in a perpetual intellectual leap.

Despite acknowledging the absurd, Camus firmly asserts that suicide is not a natural consequence of life's futility. He believes that, as humans persist in their search for truth, they must confront the only certainty of existence: mortality. This confrontation compels individuals to continue living, persevering in their quest for truth amidst the absurdity. Camus emphasizes that the awareness of death should not drive one toward self-destruction but rather inspire a continued pursuit of meaning within the confines of human existence. <quote>.

Before we can discuss the situation of French education today and in the recent past we should look at its history as this helps to explain the elitisme in the system.
We need to go back to the late 18th century when Napoleon put forward his views on education. These "bourgeois" children would then go on to Lycée and either to University or "Les Grandes Ecoles" so joining the class of the élite. This elitism has survived to a certain degree up to today.

Before we can discuss the situation of French education today and in the recent past, it is crucial to look at its history. This helps to explain the elitism present in the system. We need to go back to the late 18th century when Napoleon put forward his views on education. He believed that people should be educated in order for the state to run smoothly. In other words, he did not really believe in the right of people to be educated; he believed education was necessary only for the benefit of the state. At that time, most of the population was involved in agriculture, requiring only basic primary education for the majority. Napoleon left this responsibility mainly to the church, as he believed the church would promote social cooperation. Meanwhile, secondary and higher education were deemed more essential to train the professionals the country needed. This created a system where primary education was left to the church and secondary and higher education were run by the state. It is here that we can already see the opportunity for a gap between primary and secondary education—a gap that remained until relatively recently, despite several reform attempts, which I will go into later. This education system did not lead to much social mobility. Children from poorer backgrounds left school after primary, "école primaire," with only a basic education. In contrast, children from wealthier backgrounds could pursue secondary and higher education, joining the class of the elite. This elitism has, to some degree, persisted up to today. 

The gap between primary and secondary education became a major concern for later governments. Under the second and third republics, little progress was made on the education question, as it did not appear to be a priority. Under the fourth republic, reforms were proposed, but the frequent internal struggles within multi-party governments meant that these reforms were often unsuccessful.

Studies in demography have shown that the growth of a nation is closely linked to its economic development, social structure, and also cultural trends. On studying France throughout the twentieth century we can see that this is indeed true.
If we start at the beginning of the century we see that the growth of the population was inhibited greatly by the first world war, where France suffered many losses. The fact that the men in the society left to fight meant that the number of births was reduced greatly. This was also the case on the return of the men, when many did not come back having been killed. Therefore after the first world war the population of France decreased greatly.
Immigration was already present at this time, and helped to make up for the large number of losses in the war. Slowly the population began to build itself up again until the beginning of the Second World War. In this war France did not suffer as many casualties and deaths as in the first world war, but the fact that there had already been losses made the situation grave for France. The economy needed rebuilding, as did the whole country, and the work force was very depleated. There was an urgent call for immigrant workers to come to France, and indeed they did come (about 4 million).
When the troops came home, and families were reunited there was a great increase in births. The previous Malthusian attitude that less children meant a better life and greater security was replaced by a new attitude that in order to create and rebuild France a strong workforce was needed. Having a child was regarded as an 'investment in the future'. The french realised that a defeat was due to the fact that they were not a strong nation, and they wanted to build such a nation.
The gouvernement also adopted various policies to try and increase births in the society. It was suggested in the 1920s that contraception should be made illegal, but in the end this was restricted. Family allowances were increased, and medical costs were paid for in order to try and encourage births. Also leave from work was increased.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Studies in demography have shown that the growth of a nation is closely linked to its economic development, social structure, and cultural trends. On studying France throughout the twentieth century, we can see that this is indeed true. If we start at the beginning of the century, we see that the growth of the population was inhibited greatly by the First World War, where France suffered many losses. The fact that many men left to fight meant that the number of births was reduced significantly. This was also the case upon their return, as many had not come back having been killed. Therefore, after the First World War, the population of France decreased greatly.

Immigration began to play a role during this period, helping to make up for the large number of losses in the war. Slowly, the population started to rebuild until the beginning of the Second World War. In the Second World War, France did not suffer as many casualties and deaths as in the First World War, but the previous losses made the situation grave for the country. The economy and the whole nation needed rebuilding, and the workforce was greatly depleted. There was an urgent call for immigrant workers to come to France, and indeed they did, about 4 million.

When the troops returned, and families were reunited, there was a great increase in births. The Malthusian attitude that fewer children meant a better life and greater security was replaced by a new belief that a strong workforce was necessary to build and rebuild France. Having a child came to be regarded as an 'investment in the future'. The French realized that their defeat was due to not being a strong nation, and they wanted to create such a nation.

The government also adopted various policies to encourage higher birth rates in society. In the 1920s, it was suggested that contraception should be made illegal, though this was ultimately restricted. Instead, family allowances were increased, and medical costs were paid for to encourage births. Additionally, leave from work was extended to further support this goal.

Through these measures, France gradually rebuilt its population and workforce, leading to stronger economic and social foundations by the mid-century.

The roots of the problems in higher education lie with Napoleon's policy on education which was to educate a well-trained small elite to run the country, while guaranteeing that the country remained stable by ensuring that the majority of the population was not over-educated. Although any French citizen with the baccaleauréat is entitled through the constitution to a university education, the system is still characterised by major inequalities.
The system of non-selection for all univerisity courses (with a few exceptions such as dentistry and medecine had led to the impoverishment of the quality of instruction and the status of the universities. Trying to appear to be democratic, the system allows any bachelier to enter the first year of a university course. However, the drop out rate is incredibly high, about 57%, so many waste a year and undergo a great deal of stress, both emotional and financial in this manner. Before the Evènements of 1968, many argued that the universities were overcrowded, dirty, and ruled to closely from Paris. After 1968, Edgar Faure tried to allow for more autonomy and less direct rule from Paris. Although the Ministry was still to be responsible for Building costs, the universities were to be allowed to divide into Unités d'Enseignement et de Recherche (UER) and given more freedom in chosing accademic staff. However, universities were often divided into new universities according to the political leanings of its professors, and have been held back by political squabbles. The university graduate does not enjoy the same prestigue as his European counterparts. The Universities have little contact with the outside business world and the divided nature of the UERs allows little scope for cross fertilization of disciplines. A licence, does not automatically guarantee a good job, and a "jeune diplomé" could quite easily find himself working in a supermarket check-out. Many students, therefore wonder if it is worth the strain of the French university which does not guarantee any future. When it comes to the top jobs, the ex-students of the "Grandes Ecoles" will always be top priority. Described by "The Guardian" as "The Cram de la Cream", these schools train an elite for future top careers in administration, industry and government. The roots of the problems in higher education lie with Napoleon's policy on education, which aimed to educate a well-trained small elite to run the country while ensuring stability by preventing the majority of the population from being over-educated. Although any French citizen with a baccalaureat is constitutionally entitled to a university education, the system is still characterized by major inequalities.

The system of non-selection for all university courses, with only a few exceptions such as dentistry and medicine, has led to the impoverishment of instruction quality and the status of universities. In an effort to appear democratic, the system allows anyone with a baccalaureat to enter the first year of a university course. However, the dropout rate is incredibly high, around 57%, causing many to waste a year and endure significant emotional and financial stress.

Before the events of 1968, many argued that the universities were overcrowded, dirty, and heavily controlled from Paris. Following 1968, Edgar Faure attempted to introduce more autonomy and less direct rule from Paris. While the Ministry remained responsible for building costs, universities were given more freedom to choose academic staff and were divided into Unités d'Enseignement et de Recherche (UER). However, these divisions often reflected the political leanings of their professors, leading to stagnation from political squabbles.

As a result, the prestige of a university graduate in France is lower compared to their European counterparts. Universities have limited contact with the business world, and the divided nature of the UERs inhibits interdisciplinary collaboration. A university license does not necessarily guarantee a good job, and a "jeune diplomé" might end up working in a supermarket.

Therefore, many students question whether the strain of the French university is worth it when it does not guarantee future opportunities. When it comes to top jobs, graduates of "Grandes Ecoles," described by "The Guardian" as "The Cream of the Crop," are given top priority. These schools train an elite for future top careers in administration, industry, and government. Two-thirds of the top hundred French firms have directors who are graduates of these schools, guaranteeing high-ranking careers and accelerated promotions.

In discussing the factors which have marked the development of industrial relations in France under the Fifth Republic, it is first worth mentioning that de Gaulle established the 'comités d'entreprise' in 1946, a forum where the management (patronat), staff and trade unions could meet to discuss the business objectives and solve any disputes between different interest groups. It must also be noted before beginning the discussion of the Fifth Republic, that from 1884-1968 French Unions did not have the right to organise collectively at the workplace, they only had the right to 'social status' - as a national body. Furthermore, the French union movement is not organized according to professions as in Great Britain, but along lines of ideological stance, which gives it a different role altogether. The French unions were not, for a long time, concerned with representing the immediate material interests of their members, but in fighting long-term battles which they hoped would bring about a better and more just society. The CGT (Conféderation Générale du Travail) the largest union with ca 1.2 million members (it claims more) has always had strong communist affiliations, and has constantly been hostile to cooperation with the patronat, seeing its role as the destruction of capitalism. Although the Fifth Republic has been considerably more stable than previous Republics, there have, however, been various changes in government which have prevented continuity in policy matters, especially in terms of education. I will briefly mention previous reforms from the beginning of the Fifth Republic and show that the present situation is still burdened by inequality and various forms of social selection at secondary and higher education levels. I will briefly compare it to points in the English system.

The Fouchet reforms made the first cycle of secondary school (the first four years) more combined. However, they also introduced tracks or 'filières' early on, requiring students to make choices about their future. These reforms proved that students from lower social classes were encouraged, and still to a certain extent, to choose the shorter educational option that leads to employment at an earlier stage.

Haby sought to resolve these problems of social selection and aimed to postpone the need to make choices until a later time. He envisioned an orientation cycle in the last two years of the first cycle. For those continuing on, he proposed a general course of two years, where the first half of the 'baccalauréat' would be taken, followed by more choices in the final year. The second half of the 'bac' was to be taken at this stage.

However, the orientation cycle inadvertently brought back some form of 'tracking' from the previous system, leading to a form of social selection continuing.

The Algeiran crisis led the French Parliament in 1958 to allow de Gaulle and his government recast the political groundrules in a new constitution. This, he confirmed, would be typical of any constitution in a traditionally democratic Western society. Despite this limitation de Gaulle and his followers were able to shape the new Constitution largely according to their own views as to what would constitute a strong and durable republican regime. Debré, for example, was impressed by the British model; parlementarisme rationnel meant that the Government is not at the mercy of Parliament, yet is ultimately answerable to it and thereby be forced to resign.
De Gaulle, however, was the main inspiration of the Constitution. His experience of 1940 made him realise the need for strong, determined leadership from the top. Before the war this was greatly lacking.
The majority of articles relevant to the Presidnet in the 1958 Constitution were largely similar to those under the Third and Fourth Republics. Despite this, there were several new powers introduced and listed in Article 19 including, for example, Article 11 - referendum, Article 12 - right of dissolution and Article 16 - emergency powers.
There were, however ambiguities and certainties in the text which have proved very significant in determining the President's role in the 5th Republic. The role of the Prime Minister was such that he had powers and responsibilities in respect of government policy that could be seen to overlap with the President's function to mediate (arbitrage) between contending groups to ensure the smooth running of the country, assigned to him by Article 5.
This was open to varying interpretation. The maximalist interpretation was generally accepted. This meant that the President, instead of being limited to the 'domaine réservé' ie the powers attributed to him under the Constitution, he was justified by virtue of this article in intervening in policy-making and its implementation.
The President was also independent in carrying out this function: he was not accountable to Parliament by virtue of ARticle 68 and not even directly accountable to it via ministers or the Prime Minister for their 'contreseing'(countersignature) was not required by him.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The Algeiran crisis led the French Parliament in 1958 to allow de Gaulle and his government to recast the political ground rules in a new constitution. He confirmed that this would be typical of any constitution in a traditionally democratic Western society. Despite this limitation, de Gaulle and his followers were able to shape the new constitution largely according to their views on what would constitute a strong and durable republican regime. Debré, for example, was impressed by the British model, and he advocated for a system of parlementarisme rationnel, where the government is not at the mercy of Parliament, yet remains ultimately accountable to it and thereby obliged to resign.

De Gaulle, however, was the main inspiration of the Constitution. His experience of 1940 made him realize the need for strong, determined leadership from the top. Before the war, this was greatly lacking. The majority of articles relevant to the President in the 1958 Constitution were largely similar to those under the Third and Fourth Republics. Despite this, several new powers were introduced and listed in Article 19, including Article 11 (referendum), Article 12 (right of dissolution), and Article 16 (emergency powers).

However, there were ambiguities and certainties in the text that have proven very significant in determining the President's role in the 5th Republic. The role of the Prime Minister was such that he had powers and responsibilities in respect of government policy that could be seen to overlap with the President's function to mediate (arbitrage) between contending groups to ensure the smooth running of the country, as assigned to him by Article 5.

This was open to varying interpretation. The maximalist interpretation was generally accepted. This meant that, instead of being limited to the 'domaine réservé'—the powers attributed to him under the Constitution—he was justified by virtue of this article to intervene in policy-making and its implementation. The President was also independent in carrying out this function: he was not accountable to Parliament by virtue of Article 68 and was not even directly accountable to it via ministers or the Prime Minister. The countersignature of his actions was not required by him.

The trade union movement in France originated after the French revolution and has always tended to be revolutionary or ideological in character. The number of French employees unionized is relatively small, at about 11%, which results in significant competition between individual trade unions for membership. During periods of economic expansion, such as the period from 1945 to 1975, unions in France have been able to make demands for their workers for better pay and improved working conditions. However, during recessions, such as the oil crisis in 1975, the effectiveness of these demands diminishes and membership often declines. The first period, from 1958 to 1968, saw the state adopt a highly interventionist approach to the economy, regulating pay and price levels while also investing in and developing the economy. Under the 5th Republic, the most salient feature that emerged is the form of presidentialism initiated by General de Gaulle and continued successfully by his successors. From 1791 to 1958, France experienced 16 constitutions and from 1875 onwards, three Republics. The 4th Republic was characterized by a weak government and a weak presidency, with power concentrated in the hands of a divided National Assembly. The collapse of the 4th Republic and the mounting Algerian situation brought General de Gaulle back to power. De Gaulle was seen as the only person capable of addressing and resolving the Algerian issue. During his years in exile, de Gaulle witnessed France humiliated by its defeat and subsequent occupation by the Germans, governed by the notorious Vichy regime, and after the war's end, still not in control of its destiny, forced to align itself with the United States. France was referred to as "the sick man of Europe." De Gaulle perceived this sickness as a result of the undermining role and authority of the state. Upon returning to power in 1958, de Gaulle was determined to strengthen the state and establish a strong Executive, which he hoped to lead. His importance in shaping the 1958 constitution cannot be overstated. Though the constitution was initially tailor-made for him, it gradually became even more so due to constitutional amendments and changes in political life.

In drafting the constitution, two conflicting notions had to be reconciled. De Gaulle favored a return to the old Bonapartist tradition, wherein the President would hold full or near-omnipotent powers. However, others, fearing this concentration of power in a single source, wanted the government to possess more power. A compromise was reached, creating a strong Executive composed of a president and a cabinet headed by a Prime Minister responsible to Parliament. Eventually, de Gaulle strengthened the Executive in favor of the presidency. His interpretation of the ambiguous term "arbitrage" has been untouched for more than 30 years.

When General de Gaulle came to power in 1958, it was generally expected that the role of president would be given a new status in the policy of decision-making. De Gaulle's Bayeux speech and subsequent centrings made it clear that a clearly visible president was required, who would be the 'keystone' to the parliamentary régime. The constitution of the 5th Republic was adopted by the nation on the 28th of September 1958. It was a compromise between the Gaullists and other political forces. The constitution of the 5th Republic was adopted by the nation on the 28th of September 1958. As a compromise between the Gaullists and other political forces, it was a rather controversial document. Two significant outcomes emerged from this constitution: the presidency was strengthened, and the executive was strengthened vis-à-vis the parliament.

I will first briefly discuss the Prime Minister's role, then elaborate on the President's functions, and finally analyze each presidency to illustrate how the President's role has evolved.

The constitution does not clearly delineate who is in charge. While some articles suggest it is the Prime Minister, past Presidents and Prime Ministers have claimed it is the President. Some even argued for a twin-headed executive, but historically, Prime Ministers have accepted Presidential supremacy.

The constitution states that the Prime Minister is generally in charge of the government and has the authority to appoint ministers, among other functions. However, this function has been increasingly usurped by the President, along with other roles.

When asked about the Prime Minister's role, Giscard d'Estaing stated that the Prime Minister was responsible for contingency problems, while the President managed what was permanent and essential. This response, though technically accurate, violated the spirit of the constitution, as it echoed the practices of his predecessors. Thus, the role of the Prime Minister remains a controversial issue.

The President's role, defined in the Constitution, is also ambiguous and controversial. Article 5 claims that the President is an "arbiter." This term is sufficiently vague to be interpreted differently. De Gaulle claimed that it empowered him to rule the nation, and his successors have interpreted it as a call for an interventionist approach.

In conclusion, while the 5th Republic's constitution sought to balance power between the President and Prime Minister, ambiguities and historical practices have led to tensions and differing interpretations, particularly regarding the roles and powers of these key positions.

The President was to deal with long term issues especially foreign and defence policies whereas the Prime Minister was to deal with the short term domestic issues. This autocratic and authoritarian rôle of the President evolved throughout the 5th Republic. Pompidou, after having been Prime Minsiter for six years carried on dealing with economic, domestic and financial policies.
Article 11 was not in itself so ambiguous. The President could put important decisions to the people by referendum. De Gaulle used it in 1961 to ask the French whether they thought the Algerians should decide their own future. In 1973 Pompidou used it to see whether there should have been an enlargement of the European Community as the British wanted to join under Heath. Much of this ambiguity arose from the fact that the Constitution was a compromise between 'presidentialisme' and 'parlementarism.' The President was given the traditional powers of the Head of State as well as becoming the 'chef cérémoniale de l'État,' similar to our Queen. Additionally, the President became the Chief of the army.

He was given a lot of power through articles such as 8, 12, and 11 of the Constitution, as he didn't need the 'contre-seing' of the Prime Minister or other ministers responsible. It was with Article 8 that the main ambiguity arose. It gave the President the power to name the Prime Minister, but it remained unclear whether he also had the power to dismiss him. De Gaulle used this to his advantage and after appointing Michel Debré in 1958, he withdrew him from the position in 1962. De Gaulle saw Debré as a good Prime Minister during wartime but, after the Algerian War, he decided that Debré no longer served his purpose and effectively dismissed him. In choosing Georges Pompidou in his place, De Gaulle illustrated that the choice of Prime Minister was solely his. This interpretation of Article 8 became a cornerstone in the development of the President's power. By initially choosing Debré, De Gaulle established a precedent that created a 'domaine réservée' for the President, where the Prime Minister was not to interfere. The President was to deal with long-term issues, especially foreign and defense policies, while the Prime Minister was to handle short-term domestic issues. This autocratic and authoritarian role of the President evolved throughout the Fifth Republic. After serving as Prime Minister for six years, Pompidou continued to manage economic, domestic, and financial policies.

Article 11 was not as ambiguous as Article 8. The President could put important decisions to the people through a referendum. De Gaulle used it in 1961 to ask the French whether they thought the Algerians should decide their own future. Pompidou used Article 11 in 1973 to see whether there should be an enlargement of the European Community, as the British wanted to join under Heath. However, Pompidou was able to use Article 11 for tactical reasons, to divide the opposition, and also as a means to increase contact with people outside of normal political channels.

Demography is the study of population and the effect that its general character has on a country's society and economy. Demographists claim that it is a major factor in considering the problems of that country's evolution - for example, it is thought that many of France's problems during the twentieth century have been caused by a premature decline in the birth rate in the nineteenth century, and the consequent ageing of the population.
At the beginning of the 19th century France had the largest population in Europe, after Russia, and was also a major world power. Since this time, both its power and population in relation to the rest of Europe, have been in steady decline. By the beginning of the first world war, France's population trailed far behind that of Germany, which was one reason why Germany felt confident of victory. During both World Wars France not only lost thousands of men, but the birth rate also dropped dramatically. During the economic crisis and depression between the wars, the birthrate was also low, because it was a time of gloom and pessimism, with little hope for the future, and so people couldn't afford large families.
The consequence of these factors was that by the end of the second world war, the adult population in France was greatly reduced. It was at this time that the birth rate suddenly increased, with the Babyboom. Between 1946 and 1964 the birth rate increased 20%. - this was due to decreasing infant mortality, the introduction of social security and familly benefits, a new optimism for the future, and an abandonning of former Malthusian attitudes, in favour of a more dynamic outlook. The birth rate had in fact, begun to increase before the end of the war, as people took on a care-free attitude, with little feeling of responsibility.
At the same time, the death rate was decreasing, due to advances in medicine, and living conditions. This meant that the number of old people was steadily increasing. So, after the war, there was a reduced number of adults, to look after, and produce goods for, a increased number of children and old people. Demography is the study of population and its impact on a country's society and economy. Demographers argue that it is a significant factor in addressing a country's evolution. For instance, they claim that many of France's problems during the twentieth century stemmed from the premature decline in birth rates in the nineteenth century, leading to an ageing population. 

At the beginning of the 19th century, France had the largest population in Europe, after Russia, and was a major world power. Over time, however, both its population and influence relative to the rest of Europe have steadily declined. By the onset of the first World War, France's population lagged significantly behind Germany's, contributing to German confidence in victory during both World Wars. In these conflicts, France not only lost thousands of men but also experienced a dramatic drop in birth rates.

During the economic crisis and depression following the wars, the birth rate was low due to widespread gloom and pessimism and a lack of financial stability, preventing families from having many children.

By the end of World War II, the adult population in France had been greatly diminished. This period saw a sudden increase in the birth rate, known as the Babyboom, between 1946 and 1964, where the birth rate surged by 20%. The decline in infant mortality, the introduction of social security and family benefits, new optimism for the future, and a shift away from Malthusian attitudes toward a more dynamic outlook all contributed to this increase. Interestingly, the birth rate had begun to rise even before the war ended, as people adopted a more carefree attitude with little sense of responsibility.

At the same time, the death rate was decreasing due to medical advancements and improved living conditions. Consequently, the number of elderly people was steadily increasing. After the war, there were fewer adults available to care for, produce goods for, and support an increasing number of children and elderly individuals. This demographic shift, coupled with the need to rebuild the economy, led to an influx of immigrant workers into France, contributing to many of today's challenges with immigration.

The French system of higher education has always been of a hierarchical nature and divided. It was so before mai '68, and despite attempts at reform, it has been determined to remain so. Before 1968, French universities were overcrowded (the number of students rose from 122,000 in 1936 to 612,000 in 1968), centralized and impersonal.
In response to the events of '68, the Faure reforms were drawn up. They abolished old universities as such, and gave them the opportunity to form themselves into 'unités d'enseignements et de recherche'. They formed their own councils, and could group themselves into new universities. These universities had their own councils made up of staff, teaching and non-teaching, and student delegates. They elected the President who fulfilled a similar role to that of the British universities' Vice-Chancellor. The Faure reforms gave the universities a framework within which to create a new system of university education and to create new personalities for themselves. These reforms dealt with the centralized and impersonal aspects. But the universities could not cope with their new powers. 
They reverted back to their interdepartmental wrangling, and when it came to joining together to form universities, the subjects dominated by the Left, suchas sociology, did not want to combine with those subjects dominated by more Right-wing professors. The apolitical sciences did not want to be 'contaminated' by the Left-wingers.
Within the new universities, the departments were out to protect their own positions and to protect their share of the global budget, so there was little tendency to create new inter-disciplinary courses as Faure had hoped.
The universities are very much out of touch with the needs of the outside world. Their DEUGs and licences were very much theoretical and literal and of no use in finding jobs in specialized industry. Many professors wanted to keep universities as 'la finalité culturelle'. Donot want interaction with patrons, etc. But this is necessary to make degrees more relevant to job requirements.
Also left wing departments resisted any attempt by State for reform. Refused to see such attempts as sincere or benevolent, always suspected state of ulterior motives.

result:
The French system of higher education has always been hierarchical and divided. Before May '68 and despite attempts at reform, it has remained this way. Prior to 1968, French universities were overcrowded; the number of students rose from 122,000 in 1936 to 612,000 in 1968, and they were centralized and impersonal.

In response to the events of '68, the Faure reforms were introduced. They abolished old universities as they were and allowed them to form themselves into 'unités d'enseignements et de recherche'. These new entities created their own councils and grouped themselves into newly formed universities. These universities established councils comprising staff, teachers, non-teaching staff, and student delegates. They elected a President who fulfilled a role similar to that of the British universities' Vice-Chancellor. The Faure reforms provided a framework for the development of a new university education system and the creation of new identities, addressing the centralized and impersonal nature of the institutions. However, the universities struggled to manage their new responsibilities.

They reverted to old patterns of interdepartmental disputes. When forming new universities, subjects dominated by the Left, such as sociology, were unwilling to join those dominated by Right-wing professors. The apolitical sciences were also reluctant to be 'contaminated' by Left-wing influences.

Within the new universities, departments were primarily focused on protecting their positions and securing their share of the global budget. This led to little initiative in creating new interdisciplinary courses, contrary to Faure's hopes. Consequently, the universities remained largely disconnected from the needs of the outside world. Degrees such as the DEUG and licences were overly theoretical and did not prepare students effectively for specialized industries. Many professors were resistant to making degrees more relevant to job market requirements, preferring to maintain universities as 'la finalité culturelle', or centers of cultural finality, without external influence.

Left-wing departments also resisted any attempts by the State to reform the universities. They viewed such efforts with suspicion, believing they were driven by ulterior motives.

The gap between universities and the Grandes Ecoles was somewhat narrowed by the Instituts Universitaires de Technologie. However, the government left the Grandes Ecoles largely to their own devices, believing that they were serving France well and were not affected by the '68 movement.

At the beginning of the Fifth Republic, education reforms had not been implemented because of political instability, other priorities (notably the Second World War) and the notorious French concept of academic tradition and élitism.

The lycée had always been the bastion of élitism, with its Napoleonic tradition.

Jean Capelle, a leading figure in the initiative had very much admired, and tried to emulate the English comprehensive schools. But in an article by Hain Gaziel, his efforts were a failure. The creation of 3 'filières' were basically a division between prospective lycée and C.E.G. students. The third stream was theoretically intended to push pupils to the upper two streams, but in practice transfer was difficult - only 1% managed it. It was dubbed the 'poubelle' of the system. These two reforms came at the time of a population expansion which demanded education of any kind and prevented proper reforms - giving away a little in order to conserve a great deal.
School pupils became disillusioned, seeing the school as an agent of social discrimination. It seemed that equality of opportunity and high academic standards were incompatible.<|end|><|assistant|>

At the beginning of the Fifth Republic, education reforms had not been implemented due to political instability, other pressing priorities such as the Second World War, and the entrenched French concept of academic tradition and élitism. The problems to be solved were modernization, democratization, and secularization. At that time, in 1959, most children remained in primary school, and only 35% progressed to secondary education (the sixième year). Berthoin, the first minister of education to address democratization, attempted to extend school life for a larger number of pupils by making education compulsory until the age of 16, abolishing the entrance examination to the 'sixième', and abandoning the 'classe de la fin des études', where children stayed at primary school until 14. He introduced the concept of orientation and observation, whereby a pupil could be directed towards the school most suited to their needs, whether it be the prestigious lycée or the College d'Enseignement Général. This was an effort to bring the two schools closer together and move away from the highly élitist tradition of the lycée.

In 1963, Fouchet created the College d'Enseignement Secondaire, a lower common secondary school, to encourage upward social mobility. Jean Capelle, a leading figure in this initiative, had admired and tried to emulate the English comprehensive schools. However, in an article by Hain Gaziel, his efforts were deemed a failure. The creation of three 'filières' primarily served to divide prospective lycée and C.E.G. students. The third stream, intended to push pupils to the upper two streams, proved difficult in practice—only 1% managed it successfully. Dubbed the 'poubelle' of the system, these reforms were implemented during a population expansion that demanded education of any kind, leading to a compromise where some reforms were given away to conserve much of the system.

School pupils became disillusioned, perceiving the school as an agent of social discrimination. The lycées were seen as the domain of the bourgeois and cadres supérieurs, while the chances of 'ouvrier' children attaining higher education were remote. It became apparent that equality of opportunity and high academic standards were perceived as being incompatible.

The Fifth Republic inherited the limitations and dissatisfaction of the Fourth. The education system needed immediate modernisation and democratization. The first reform which aimed at achieve these was the Berthoin reform which was issued by decree under de Gaulle's emergency powers with no opportunity for parliamentary debate.
Under this reform, the school-leaving age was raised to 16, thus ensuring a longer span of education. A cycle of observation of 2 years was introduced for pupils at the age of 11, the idea being that during these 2 years pupils' progress would be observed and at the end of the cycle each pupil would be guided by teachers into either the lycée or the CEG (collège d'enseignement général) as best suited the individual. Berthoin hoped this would reduce social discrimination since all pupils would follow the same syllabus. However, this cycle of observation took place in different institutions - the lycée, the CEG and the primary school - and little transfer of pupils actually took place (1% of pupils transferred to the lycée on average). In these institutions sylabuses were harmonized but this was inefficient and insufficient as far as equality of opportunity was concerned.
The Fouchet reforms of 1963 sought to relieve the continued dissatisfaction of the political Left, primary teachers and trade unions by improving on the Berthoin reforms. Fouchet tried to introduce a common middle school for all pupils - the CES - which would cover the 11 to 14 age span. It was to be formed by converting the junior classes of the lycée into separate units and by transforming the CEG's. At the end of the CES, entry to the lycée would be by the pupils carte scolaire not by exam. Lycée teachers feared a drop in standards, and middle class parents feared tougher competition for their children. Hence conversion was resisted - in the opinion of the Legrand report, the CES never actually came into existance. However the CES such as it was did provide for an increased equality for pupils but the biggest drawback was the streaming system - the 3 filières, of which filière number one had the bad teachers and was dominated by children of the middle class. This led to a continuation of social selection for the lycées and a further setback for democratization.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The Fifth Republic inherited the limitations and dissatisfaction of the Fourth. The education system needed immediate modernization and democratization, prompting the first reform: the Berthoin reform, issued under de Gaulle's emergency powers without parliamentary debate.

Under this reform, the school-leaving age was raised to 16, ensuring a longer span of education. A two-year observation cycle was introduced for students at age 11, with the aim that teachers would guide each pupil into either the lycée or the CEG (collège d'enseignement général) at the end of the cycle, according to individual needs. Berthoin hoped this would reduce social discrimination by providing a uniform curriculum. However, the observation cycle took place in different institutions (lycée, CEG, and primary schools), resulting in limited pupil transfer (only 1% moved to the lycée). Harmonizing syllabi across these institutions proved inefficient and insufficient for equal opportunity.

In 1963, the Fouchet reforms sought to address the ongoing dissatisfaction of the political Left, primary teachers, and trade unions by building on the Berthoin reforms. Fouchet aimed to establish a common middle school (CES) for ages 11 to 14, converting junior lycées and CEGs into separate units. Entry to the lycée would be determined by a student's carte scolaire rather than by exam. However, lycée teachers feared a drop in standards, while middle-class parents feared tougher competition for their children, leading to resistance to these conversions. According to the Legrand report, the CES never truly materialized.

Despite the CES's limited implementation, it did promote increased equality for pupils. However, the biggest drawback was the streaming system, consisting of three filières. Fichier one, dominated by middle-class children, was often staffed by less qualified teachers, perpetuating social selection for lycées and a setback for democratization.

Voltaire tackles the question of philosophical optimism in 'Candide' by presenting it as a flawed and often devastating belief system. He sets out to criticize this philosophy, primarily through the character of Pangloss, Candide's ever-optimistic mentor. Throughout the novel, Voltaire illustrates how the unwavering belief in philosophical optimism leads to disastrous consequences, ultimately portraying it as a philosophy rooted in despair.

In 'Candide', Pangloss serves as the embodiment of philosophical optimism, continually asserting that "all is for the best in the best of all possible worlds." Despite facing numerous hardships, Candide clings to this belief, even when it becomes painfully evident that things are far from ideal. For instance, when Candide is forced to join the Bulgarian army, he endures severe punishment yet remains steadfast in his optimism, believing it to be for his own good. Later, he uses his training as a soldier to kill two men and his sweetheart's brother, actions he justifies through his unwavering belief in optimism.

Voltaire further demonstrates his disdain for philosophical optimism when Candide, Pangloss, and a sailor find themselves stranded at sea after a storm caused by an earthquake. As they witness widespread starvation and death, Candide's horror is palpable. Even when asked for an explanation by Pangloss, the philosopher's response—that some good will come of it—does nothing to alleviate the grim reality they face. This event starkly contrasts Candide's idealism, revealing the stark disparity between belief and reality.

Candide's journey doesn't end there; he soon arrives in South America, only to be forced to abandon his beloved Cunégonde with the local Commissioner of the province. The absurdity of this situation, given Candide's prior killing of Cunégonde's lovers, further underscores the futility of his unwavering optimism.

Throughout 'Candide', Voltaire gradually exposes the flaws in philosophical optimism. The constant assertion that good can emerge from bad situations is not inspiring but rather leads to a continuous cascade of misfortunes. Through Candide's experiences and evolving skepticism, Voltaire effectively illustrates that philosophical optimism is not only misguided but ultimately a philosophy of despair, incapable of accounting for the myriad hardships and tragedies that people face.

Philosophical optimism is the target of Voltaire's attack on social attitudes at the time. The idea of divine providence in a world of human cruelty and natural disasters was ridiculous to him, and he tries to hammer the realities home to his reader.

Philosophical optimism, Voltaire's target in his critique of social attitudes of his time, is rendered absurd by the harsh realities he presents to his readers. Voltaire illustrates the cruelty of the world, emphasizing the natural environment's indifference to human suffering. Their trek across the desert further emphasizes nature's harshness, as many of Candide's sheep succumb to dehydration or quicksand.

Voltaire's portrayal of civilization as oppressive and destructive further undermines the optimistic view. Each individual, in fact, often exhibits at least one unpleasant side.

The consistent portrayal of nature, civilization, and personality in such a negative light serves to demonstrate Voltaire's point: there is hardly anything "qui va pour le mieux dans le monde," and even less reason to believe that everything is for the best. Throughout Candide, there is scant evidence of good will or divine benevolence. The relentless suffering and misery inflicted upon individuals, often presented in a comic light, underscore the absurdity of optimism. Pangloss's string of misfortunes—being hanged, dissected alive, flogged, and chained to a Turkish galley—further emphasize the ludicrous notion that everything turns out for the best.

In sum, Voltaire uses Candide's journey and the surrounding hardships to dismantle the concept of philosophical optimism, delivering a scathing critique of the belief in a just and benevolent world governed by divine providence.

'Candide' is Voltaire's wittiest work, targeting the theory of eternal optimism propagated by Leibniz. However, it is not merely a clever and amusing tale around the "tout est bien" philosophy; Voltaire uses it critically to assess the doctrine. Voltaire expressed his displeasure with the "all is for the best" theory after the Lisbon earthquake, where grieving victims were told that their grief was needed to continue the general scheme of the world. He mocked them by stating that the masons might be celebrating due to earning a lot for rebuilding the city, or the heirs to large fortunes would be happy as they would now receive their inheritance. Voltaire described this philosophy as the only possible horror that could rival the earthquake itself.

In 'Candide', our hero's tutor, Pangloss, subscribes to Leibniz's theory, sometimes muddling it. We encounter the "tout est bien" principle in the very first chapter when Pangloss attempts to explain his beliefs with basic examples, such as ears being given so that spectacles could sit on them properly. He then expounds on this theory throughout the tale, often with a callous indifference.

This is exemplified when Candide, Pangloss, and Jacques, Candide's benefactor, are sailing to Lisbon. Jacques drowns in a shipwreck while saving an ungrateful sailor. The injustice of the situation is evident to all, but Pangloss shows no sympathy and consoles Candide by saying it had to happen at that time off the coast of Lisbon.

Voltaire's narrative continues with numerous incidents that stretch the reader's credulity to the limit, showcasing the farcical extremes Pangloss goes to justify his theory. Voltaire uses the Lisbon earthquake to underscore the same point seen above when the real earthquake occurred. 

The plot then descends into the ridiculous, with Candide being whipped and Pangloss being hanged at a magnificent auto-da-fé, held to prevent similar earthquakes from striking Lisbon again. Candide then embarks on a series of adventures without his tutor, beginning with Cacambo and then with Martin, an eternal pessimist. Throughout these adventures, Voltaire maintains his critical lens on the "tout est bien" philosophy, making 'Candide' a profound commentary on the absurdity of blind optimism.

In the "Discours sur l'origine de l'inégalité," Rousseau depicts how the development of civilization has corrupted man's natural happiness and freedom through the creation of artificial inequalities of power, wealth, and social privilege. To discover how this corruption of man came about, Rousseau traces the development of humanity from nascent man to society as it presented itself in the eighteenth century, aiming to uncover the principle sources of human equality.

Rousseau's depiction of natural man is essential to his argument. Imagined as physically strong and thriving in woodland, natural man was uncomplicated and had few needs, such as food, a mate, and rest. Rousseau argues that when man was alone and self-dependent, he was equal to his fellow man. However, it was only when man discovered the ability to cooperate with others, work together, and found the basis of a civilization, that man's corruption and the emergence of social inequalities began.

Rousseau places man's development in five separate stages. The first stage is the stage of man's innocence, where he is dependent only on himself and, in stark contrast to civilized man, he is free from corruption. The second stage is when man forms a social unit by building a dwelling and assumes the roles of protector and father, which Rousseau describes as the "golden age." This stage, however, is ultimately ousted due to man's desire for self-improvement.

This self-improvement leads to the development of the concept of property, as man who has become a cultivator needs to protect the land he has cultivated from others. Consequently, Rousseau describes a "state of war" as articulated by Hobbes, where "each against all." Ultimately, the final stage is the establishment of a "social contract" intended to secure peace for everyone and escape the perpetual state of war.

Through this social development, Rousseau observes how man transitions from a stage of equality to a life characterized by human inequality. Rousseau looks at "man-made-man" and sees how he is dehumanized compared to earlier man. Although the social development that occurred when men aspired to self-improvement enabled man's capability for advancement through science and scientific knowledge, Rousseau contends that "these supposed improvements were the source of his misfortunes."

Voltaire, one of France's most famous XVIIIth-century philosophers, is widely acclaimed as the wittiest and most perceptive author of the 'roman philosophique'. In Candide, he tells the story of the young hero's travels throughout the world in search of happiness. On his travels, the naïve boy becomes a mature man, and many of the episodes that the characters experience are outrageous and extravagant. These episodes serve to keep the reader's interest and to provide a cynical commentary on the world through Voltaire's eyes.

The main motivation of the novel, however, was to launch an attack upon a popular philosophical theory of the day: optimism. This doctrine of divine providence carried many prestigious names in its list of followers, such as that of John Locke, a very influential English philosopher of the period. Optimism stated that, as the world was created by God—a perfect being—everything that happens in it must be for the best. All individual suffering must be attributed to the general good.

Voltaire's experiences and knowledge did not allow him to adopt this theory. For example, he had been in Lisbon when a terrible earthquake destroyed the city and killed an estimated 50,000 people. How could such a terrible disaster possibly be 'for the best', and how could the deaths of so many people contribute towards the general good?

In the novel, the young Candide accepted optimism as an unshakeable theory when he was taught it by his tutor, Pangloss, whom he described as the best of all tutors. As the story charts the various disasters experienced by Candide and his companions, the hero finds it increasingly difficult to justify his faith in everything being for the best.

In the tale 'Candide' by Voltaire, we follow the principal character, Candide, on a journey of discovery filled with strange episodes. This journey allows Voltaire to illustrate his disdain for the prevailing climate of optimism, which often served as an excuse for the lethargy of contemporary society. The story begins with Candide comfortably installed at the mansion of Baron Thunder-Ten Tronkh, where he learns the philosophy of optimism from Pangloss, whose maxim is, "Tout est pour le mieux dans le meilleur des mondes possibles." 

In Westphalia, Candide falls in love with the beautiful Cunégonde, and because of this love, he is thrown out of the house and forced to wander. Despite these hardships, Candide clings to Pangloss's teachings, almost to the end of the book, steadfastly believing that "Tout est pour le mieux." For example, Candide is pressed into joining the army and witnesses a bloody battle where each side claims victory, having caused immense damage, and the supposed heroes turn out to be marauding rapists. Even after surviving the brutal conflict, Cunégonde moves on to Holland, where Candide encounters his friend and teacher Pangloss, who is almost dead from the pox he caught from Paquette. Pangloss still maintains his optimism, and they journey to Portugal, where they suffer greatly as their friend is killed by a vicious sailor, and they arrive in Lisbon to find it ravaged by a devastating earthquake that kills thousands.

Despite these harrowing experiences, Candide's optimism is renewed upon his arrival in South America. The naïve Candide remarks on how the sea and climate are much better here than in Europe and so believes this place must surely be "le meilleur des mondes possibles." Through Candide's journey, Voltaire effectively critiques the blind and misguided faith in optimism, demonstrating the harsh realities that can contradict and challenge such beliefs.

Voltaire was hostile to the philosophical outlook of his day, which embraced optimism. Though he did not necessarily oppose thinkers like Leibniz, Shaftesbury, and Wolff, he was utterly opposed to the perverse interpretations of this doctrine that transformed hope into despair.

Voltaire used pessimism as the primary means to attack the philosophical doctrine of optimism. In doing so, he highlighted the suffering and misery that pervaded the narrative. Martin, a character in the story, embodied pessimism as Voltaire saw it: the belief that humans are inherently evil and that every event is for the worst. Martin reveled in shattering Candide's hope, the character who lived for the ultimate happiness of reuniting with Lady Cunégonde. Martin's actions spurred Candide's lifelong journey.

Conversely, the character of Pangloss represented the optimistic theory, which maintained that "all is best in the best of all possible worlds where everything is connected and arranged for the best." Pangloss adhered to this doctrine despite enduring severe suffering—his own hanging, flogging, and dissection—which Voltaire found infuriating, particularly in light of recent disasters like the earthquakes in Linis and Lisbon, where thousands perished. Voltaire struggled to see how such calamities could contribute to the common good.

Every character in the book endured significant suffering. Candide, blinded by his desire for Lady Cunégonde, continued his journey with the hope of marrying her. However, when Candide finally met her, she had significantly changed, becoming unbearable. Voltaire used this transformation to illustrate that supreme happiness is unattainable.

Voltaire further critiqued the philosophy by demonstrating that goodness and kindness are never reciprocated. For instance, the Anabaptist named Jacques, who was widely regarded as a good man, saved a sailor from drowning during a storm near Lisbon harbor. Unfortunately, Jacques himself was swept overboard with the sailor and received no help. When Candide attempted to save him, it was too late; the sailor drowned, highlighting the painful reality of unreciprocated kindness.

Within the narrative, Voltaire uses the character of Pangloss as the chief exponent of philosophical optimism. His optimistic view is directly contradicted by Martin, the Pessimist. Candide, the central figure in the tale, is placed in the happy medium of skepticism by Voltaire. He initially believes in the optimistic philosophy but encounters a series of incredible and unlikely events as he ventures alone. These experiences enable Candide to develop his own ontology. Voltaire uses Candide as a vehicle to express his own views on philosophical optimism.

When Candide is forced to join the Bulgar army and is whipped for attempting to desert, he witnesses firsthand the futility of warfare and its fruitless and destructive nature. Montesquieu, an author of the Enlightenment period, developed his ideas in "De l'esprit des lois" by introducing new lines of thinking derived from scientific experiments. His approach involved studying the influence of climate on the characteristics of different societies. Though starting from a prouvable basis, he regresses to a dependence on racial prejudices, leading to debatable conclusions.

According to Montesquieu's theory, climate has a significant physical and spiritual influence on society. He compares societies in cold climates with those in temperate or hot climates. He claims that people from cold climates, whom he describes as having more vigor, are more courageous, enterprising, virtuous, less given to lying, and jealousies. This biased viewpoint is evident in his analysis, often based on questionable experiments, such as using the tongue of an animal to draw conclusions about human resilience to pain in cold climates and controlling their passions.

In "De l'esprit des lois," Montesquieu explores the spirit in which laws are formed. He equates "loi" with rapport or relationship, emphasizing the need to consider hidden structures inherent in humans, such as passions, while separating religious and moral influences to interpret society's characteristics accurately.

Montesquieu believes in a natural law that existed before the formation of societies, ensuring self-preservation, mutual attraction among humans, and a tendency to associate, despite the inherent vulnerability this creates. He argues that societies in colder climates have existed without legislative law for extended periods.

Finally, Montesquieu characterizes people from warmer climates as being excessively sentimental, driven by a code of honor, and exhibiting exaggerated forms of love. This portrayal, however, reflects his biased perspective and reliance on debatable conclusions.

In Voltaire's novel, the protagonist 'Candide' embarks on a journey of discovery that critiques the theory of philosophical optimism, championed by many French Catholics of his time. The doctrine of optimism posits that all events are for the best, advocating resignation and acceptance of life's happenings. This notion is embodied by the character Pangloss, who, despite enduring whipping, hanging, and near immolation at an 'auto-da-fé,' steadfastly clings to his optimistic beliefs.

As Candide begins his journey with naive optimism, he gradually uncovers humanity's inherent evil nature and the atrocities humans inflict upon one another. He witnesses senseless wars where no one wins but countless sufferings, natural disasters like the earthquake in Lisbon, and the pervasive traits of greed, selfishness, and deceit. These experiences erode his belief that the widespread slaughter and death are justifiable or beneficial.

Voltaire's critique extends beyond the theory of optimism to target the religious order associated with it, particularly the Catholic Church. The institution faces condemnation for its role in religious wars, and the clergy are depicted as hypocritical and manipulative, exemplified by Abbé Pérevourdin, who deceives Candide and attempts to steal his money. The Jesuits are also criticized for their efforts to dominate the subservient, reflecting the broader theme of inequality among people, including disparities in wealth, health, and housing.

This critique remains relevant today, as modern society still grapples with similar inequalities, varying by country and following Rousseau's hypothesis regarding the development of societies from their early stages. Voltaire's narrative thus serves as a timeless exploration of the flaws in philosophical optimism and the pervasive inequalities within human societies.

Theology claimed that God took man out of the state of nature soon after his conception, wanting him to be unequal. However, Jean-Jacques Rousseau disagrees with this notion. He believes in the concept of the 'noble savage,' where all men are born good and equal. Rousseau argues that inequality, along with vice, only developed as society progressed and attempts to illustrate this in his work, "Discourse on the Origin of Inequality."

Rousseau believed that there were two forms of inequality: natural or physical inequality and political or moral inequality. Natural inequality, as its name suggests, is given by nature and has always existed, though not always been recognized. In contrast, moral inequality originates from various sources. Natural inequality occurs because people possess different strengths, appearances, talents, or gifts. These differences lead to notions of beauty, merit, jealousy, and conflict. However, such observations of inequality would not have occurred in the state of nature, as men rarely met, and no comparisons were ever made.

As human populations grew and spread, men mixed more frequently, and a sense of moral obligation developed. In the state of nature, interactions among men were limited, but as their numbers increased, these interactions became more frequent. Differences, or inequalities, began to be noted with the onset of sexual inequality due to a sexual division of labor. This was the beginning of a simple society, marked by the emergence of land ownership and the establishment of property laws. Inequality hardly existed in the state of nature but grew as human faculties and experiences developed and became established and legalized through the introduction of property and eventually laws.

Although inequality existed even then, Rousseau considered it a 'golden age.' This state of equality and happiness would have continued indefinitely without further development. However, as people began to specialize and divide labor, they became interdependent, and labor itself became necessary. This led to the invention of agriculture and further specialization, with various jobs earning different levels of value. Economic inequality subsequently led to wealth inequality, dividing the world into rich and poor. These differences in wealth brought about further inequality in rank, social esteem, and power within society.

Candide, written in 1757, is a 'conte philosophique' that chronicles the metaphysical journey of discovery, weaving various themes throughout the narrative. One of the most dominant themes is that of Optimism. The concept of Optimism is personified by the philosopher Pangloss, who relentlessly preaches his beliefs even in the face of adversity. Pangloss maintains that everything, including the death of two hundred thousand during the Lisbon earthquake, is for the best according to God's will and contributes to the greater good of mankind. For Pangloss, every event has a purpose, exemplified when Candide's accidental kiss of Cunégonde, caused by her dropping her handkerchief, leads him down a path of misery. Pangloss's unwavering philosophical optimism is ultimately unrealistic, as it fails to acknowledge that good in the world does not necessarily outweigh the bad.

Voltaire subtly critiques the idea of Optimism, as originally proposed by Leibniz in 1721. He does this by exposing the illogical wanderings of Pangloss's rhetoric and juxtaposing it against a catalog of disasters and human suffering, such as rape, pillage, and war. Throughout Candide's journey to find Cunégonde and, by extension, happiness, he is continuously tested by every possible means. Initially, Candide adheres steadfastly to Pangloss's optimistic philosophy, but as the story progresses, he begins to doubt it. His skepticism reaches a turning point when he encounters a Negro slave in Surinam who is left lying naked on the roadside, with an arm and a leg missing, by his cruel master. This encounter prompts Candide to reject the idea of philosophical optimism, making him his own judge. However, Candide remains deceived by appearances, such as the seemingly happy lives of Abbé from Périgod, Paquette, and Giroflée.

Ultimately, the narrative underscores the futility of blind optimism and the need for a more nuanced understanding of the world. Through Candide's experiences and transformations, Voltaire invites readers to question the validity of such an all-encompassing optimistic worldview.
