Throughout "Candide," the question of optimism is persistently explored through Candide's reflections on Pangloss's influential words: "Tout est pour le bien dans ce, le meilleur des mondes." This philosophical indoctrination of his childhood leads Candide to conclude that there is a natural order of 'goodness,' no matter the calamities he encounters. Thrown into the confusion of the Bulgar war and subsequently put on trial, Candide is in a position to choose between being "fusillé" or "fustigé." His unflagging optimism, grounded in the belief that everything is for the best in the eyes of some Divine Providence, renders him grateful for such a choice.

Even though Pangloss is only present in a few chapters, his optimistic philosophy is constantly ridiculed by Candide's disastrous encounters. Cunégonde is supposedly raped and disembodied, Jaques is killed while a bandit is saved, Candide himself is betrayed, cheated, robbed, and flogged. His childhood paradise is increasingly shown to be little more glamorous than a horse stable compared to his adult visions. Moreover, the daughter of a pope recounts a life history of unspeakable misfortune. Nevertheless, Pangloss insists on reasserting Leibniz, when Voltaire mocked him, saying: "Je suis toujours de mon premier sentiment, car enfin, je suis philosophe... Leibniz ne pouvant avoir tort." Despite the relentless misfortunes, Candide's hope for finding his beloved is continually nurtured. She has become his reason for all, yet often seems to slip through his fingers. He hears of her infidelity, suffering, and even her ugliness and disagreeable nature. Still, Candide believes in the natural order of goodness in the world and clings to the hope that, once, she agreed to be his wife, it was for the greater good.

In this way, Voltaire uses Candide's journey to critique and ultimately deconstruct the overly simplistic and optimistic philosophy initially taught by Pangloss, highlighting the harsh realities and contradictions that life presents.

result:
We are experiencing today a definite movement towards an ever closer and more integrated Europe, principally through the creation of the European Communities: the European Economic Community (EEC); the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC); and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). The passing of the Single European Act in 1986 has given the concept of an open and common market a new lease of life by adding much detail to existing provisions in the EEC Treaty. Since the passing of the Single European Act in 1986, we can now see the completion of such an open common market as a reality: one free market for Europe with no trade barriers. However, even though Britain has joined the European Communities and accepted its effects through the European Communities Act of 1972, there has arguably been a very high price paid. This is, of course, the loss of absolute supremacy for the English Parliament.

The orthodox theory of parliamentary legislative supremacy states that Parliament cannot restrict its own legislative omnipotence. In other words, Parliament today cannot pass laws that limit tomorrow's Parliament's legislative powers, whether they are restrictions on the manner and form of legislation or restrictions on the subject matter. Inherent in the founding treaties as amended is the idea that European Community law must prevail over national law. Therefore, in the case of a contradiction between the two, European Community law must be abided by. This first aspect of Britain's membership of the European Communities has already shown a restriction on Britain's legal system: the doctrine of implied repeal. The court's view of this argument is of utmost importance; however, the judges have not had to decide this point yet.

Lord Denning, a proponent of the orthodox view, described Britain's Accession as a "farewell to our sovereignty," suggesting that such a loss of independence was an inevitable consequence of joining the European Communities. On the other hand, he also maintained that theoretically, Parliament can retain conferred powers even though in practice, it may be virtually impossible.

On the other hand, radical theorists would agree that it is indeed a "farewell to our sovereignty." They believe that, if Parliament is truly supreme, it should be able to legislate on absolutely anything, including putting legal limitations on itself. This perspective underscores the tension between national sovereignty and European integration, highlighting the ongoing debates about the implications of Britain's membership in the European Communities.

When the Treaty of Rome was signed in 1957, the foundation was laid for a new "continent"—a united Europe. It was said that Europe would not be created quickly, but over several years. Trade would be easier, with no frontier controls allowing free flowing transportation of merchandise. Business booms would be expected, along with free competition and the removal of protective practices, as well as greater freedom to travel.

Despite never having geographically been a part of Europe, the implications are far-reaching.

European integration is a wide-ranging and controversial subject, concerning the formation of a single political and economic entity amongst the members of the EEC. Many of the steps to its completion are already underway. It is also unprecedented in the history of Europe. The plans are to form a single economic market from the member nations, which would undoubtedly and unavoidably lead to political concessions on the part of Britain, if not total political capitulation to Brussels. This would lead to a loss of sovereignty for Britain, as indeed for all the other member states. This means a loss of national government power in favor of a central European institution of policymaking, covering four main areas of British society: i) economic, ii) political, iii) defense, and iv) legal.

As far as economics is concerned, British independent economic policy would be undermined. Primarily, being in a monetary union with other states would lead to a loss of the exchange rates as a method for controlling the flow of goods in and out of Britain. The British government would no longer be able to devalue or revalue the pound to regain competitiveness with European neighbors, potentially making Britain an unproductive backwater in Europe. The Bank of England would also lose the right to print and distribute an independent currency—the pound. Moreover, the British government would lose power over all monetary policy, as there would be a single European exchange rate, interest rate, and inflation rate. The supply of money would be controlled by a central European bank, which has jurisdiction over these variables. This would render Britain with only fiscal policy to control her economy, though there are even rumors that this may also be centralized in a new Europe, encompassing everything from tax policy to social security payments.

As a natural consequence of this, there would be a political loss of sovereignty, since if there is no way for British instructions to exercise their power, they may as well not exist. Already, there is a European Parliament, which is being given ever-greater powers to govern, further emphasizing the shift towards a centralized European entity.

The European Community is a unique grouping of twelve sovereign European Member States who are committed to the development of closer economic and political co-operation. The community has an aim to break down the economic and political barriers that have traditionally divided Europe. This fresh start came about because of three main factors. Firstly, was Europe's realization of her own weakness, after having lost her age-old position at the centre of the world stage to the United States of America and to the Soviet Union. These superpowers were economically, militarally and politically stronger than the divided individual European states. Secondly was the conviction that military conflict should in the future be avoided; after all, the two great wars had both begun as European "civil wars". Thirdly was the common desire for a better, freer world in which international relations would be conducted in a more orderly way. One of the first major moves towards European integration was the creation of the European Economic Community, in 1958. Its membership has grown from the ten original founder countries to twenty-three. One of the most innovative features of the European Community compared with other international bodies is that the member states have ceded to it a part of their national sovereignty and endowed it with its own sovereign powers, which it can use to adopt acts, having the force of national law. The European Community is a unique grouping of twelve sovereign European Member States who are committed to the development of closer economic and political co-operation. The community has an aim to break down the economic and political barriers that have traditionally divided Europe. In particular, the community seeks to facilitate greater movement within its frontiers; movement not only of goods but also of services, capital, and people. However, the issue of sovereignty is certainly a much debated one; to what extent should a member hand over its sovereignty to the Community, if at all? Let us look at the founding of the European Community before we discuss the issue of sovereignty in more detail.

There were several attempts at peaceful unification after the First World War, but only after Europe had again been devastated by war was the futility of national rivalry truly apparent. The political and economic exhaustion of the European states called for a fresh start and a far more radical approach to the re-ordering of Europe. This fresh start came about because of three main factors. Firstly, Europe realized her own weakness after losing her age-old position at the center of the world stage to the United States of America and the Soviet Union. These superpowers were economically, militarily, and politically stronger than the divided individual European states. Secondly, there was a conviction that military conflict should in the future be avoided, as both the two great wars had begun as European "civil wars." Thirdly, there was a common desire for a better, freer world in which international relations would be conducted in a more orderly way.

One of the first major moves towards European integration was the creation of the European Economic Community in 1958. Its membership has grown from the ten original founder countries to twenty-three. One of the most innovative features of the European Community compared with other international bodies is that the member states have ceded to it a part of their national sovereignty and endowed it with its own sovereign powers, which it can use to adopt acts, having the force of national law. This novel approach to pooling national sovereignty is called "integration."

The 1970s saw progress in integration, with the introduction of community policy instruments, which enabled greater scope for national policies. The Single European Act, signed by the twelve European Community member states in February 1986, represents a commitment by all the member countries to achieve a single market in goods, services and capital before 1992. The Single European Act can be analyzed according to three broad areas. Firstly, it reaffirms the Treaty of Rome's original aims by removing all internal, physical, technical, and fiscal barriers, creating one external frontier with uniform standards and rates within the market. Thirdly, it recognizes the position of the European Council (not originally included in the treaty), gives the role of foreign policy creation to the European Policy Corporation (EPC), changes the voting procedure for the Council of Ministers, and makes the European Parliament a directly elected body. These are significant changes and are aimed at facilitating the transition from the partial integration that exists at the moment into fully integrated economic and monetary union.

The single European market now seems to be inevitable, although many differing views and interpretations of the idea are still evident. The fact that the concept of a single market is itself very hard to define has been the source of much confusion and some hostility towards it from the British public. A great fear of losing our sovereignty has stemmed from the varying theories of what "1992" entails, and from many people's wish to remain ignorant of current developments.

The most evident implication of the single market is, in my view, the abolition of trade and customs barriers. This will apparently extend our free market economy to the whole of Europe, or at least to those countries who participate. The consequences of the lifting of these barriers can be viewed positively. For British firms that rely on international trade to survive, the single market will be an incentive to increase dealings with other European firms. Moreover, the convenience of moving goods across frontiers, especially with the eminent launch of the Channel Tunnel for public and commercial use, will bolster British firms. However, it can be argued that British firms may face challenges from European competition or even dominance.

Additionally, if a single European currency is ever introduced as part of the process, it could provide an incentive for European firms to "buy British." The formalities required in foreign exchange would no longer exist, and the UK's current balance of payments situation may even improve as a result. British firms might also look for new products in other countries if they are no longer constrained by tariffs, leading to a more diverse product range and potential enhancements in profits.

But the question of the single currency is itself a subject of much controversy. I believe that it is an aspect which is more threatening to British sovereignty than the general concept of the single market. Somehow, the prospect of treating Europe as one market is more acceptable if the countries participating keep their individual currencies and hence their identities. However, the idea of all the states using one currency is generally regarded as being a much greater threat to sovereignty, and would mean, to many people, the sacrificing of the pound to suit the aims of the Europeans.

A very important characteristic of the UK constitution, and one which is central to the question of sovereignty, is that it is the Westminster Parliament that is the supreme legal authority in the UK.

A very important characteristic of the UK constitution, and one which is central to the question of sovereignty, is that it is the Westminster Parliament that is the supreme legal authority in the UK.

According to the orthodox school, which subscribes to the views of Albert Venn Dicey, the Westminster Parliament is omnicompetent and can pass laws on any subject it likes to regulate the activities of any person, anywhere, even those of aliens outside British territory. In theory, then, the Westminster Parliament could pass a law banning smoking on the streets of Paris. If our Parliament did so, British courts would be obliged to accept Parliament's decision and pass judgement accordingly. However, in practice, as the Radical school points out, in this hypothetical situation, the Parisiens would take no notice whatever of the UK Parliament's legislation. This illustrates how Parliament would be fettered despite its theoretical omnipotence.

Dicey said that as each Parliament is omnipotent, and therefore has the power to make or unmake any law, no Parliament could bind its successors as to the content or manner and form of subsequent legislation. The Radical school points out that since the passing of the European Communities Act in 1972, the Westminster Parliament has ceded some of its sovereignty and supremacy to Europe. The orthodox school retaliates by pointing out that since a Westminster Parliament passed the 1972 Act, thereby putting the UK into the European Communities, a future Parliament could just as easily repeal this Act and take us out of Europe again. Firstly, what is the European Union? It appears to have two distinct forms, Political Union and Economic and Monetary Union, which seem to worry the British public the most. In fact, these issues have become so heated in Great Britain at present that they have led to many disputes within the present government and are considered one of the major reasons for the resignation of Mrs. Thatcher. It would be tempting to think of the various European Communities as an embryonic United States of Europe, especially when politicians emphasize the importance of European unity. However, it is important to realize that Europe is very far from becoming anything like the United States. When the original 13 American states resolved to form what is now the United States of America, they were intent on forming a political as well as economic entity. They were prepared to yield as much of their own sovereignty as would be essential to allow the newly formed national government to operate as a single international political force. A balance was therefore struck in the constitution to allow the individual states as much self-government as possible while ensuring that, for example in military matters, the central government spoke for all. Today, disputes over state sovereignty still arise, but no one would challenge the fact that, on matters external to the United States, the government in Washington represents the sole policy-making body.

In Europe, it is quite clear that many people would like to see a political union of the countries since this would produce a formidable international military force. However, it is equally clear that while there might be some unified political action flowing from the European Communities, such as the response to Europe's involvement in the Falkland Islands dispute, the Communities were intended as purely economic entities in the first place. Membership almost certainly involves some loss of national sovereignty, but the United Kingdom could probably leave the community by a simple majority vote in the Westminster Parliament, something that no state in the United States could lawfully do. We are still a very long way from a Single Parliament for Western Europe with the power to make political decisions for all, and even with 1992 approaching and a single market, the gulf between the UK and Europe remains very wide.

The supremacy of Parliament will never be challenged. Its ability to make and break any law—made by it or Europe—means that it retains full sovereignty. The Crown has power to enter into Treaties which bind the UK in International Law. But this prerogative power does not include the power to alter the rights of individuals within the UK. If alterations to British law are required by the Treaty, an Act of Parliament must be passed. If Parliament fails to pass any legislation required by a Treaty then it may be in breach of its international obligations as imposed by that Treaty. This represents a loss of sovereignty as Parliament is bound to a certain extent in that Parliament is obliged to legislate under the constraint that if does not the UK will be in breach of its international obligations.

However in interpreting statutes the court will wherever possible interpret so as to conform with international law.

In 1963 the European Court of Justice stated that "... the Community constitutes a new legal order of international law, for the benefit of which the states have limited their sovereign rights, albeit within limited fields, and the subjects of which comprise not only member states but also their nationals". result:
The Crown has the power to enter into Treaties that bind the UK in International Law. However, this prerogative power does not include the power to alter the rights of individuals within the UK. If alterations to British law are required by a Treaty, an Act of Parliament must be passed. If Parliament fails to pass any legislation required by a Treaty, it may be in breach of its international obligations, representing a loss of sovereignty as Parliament is obliged to legislate under the constraint that without it, the UK will be in breach of its international obligations.

Parliament's freedom to legislate is not in theory fettered by such a Treaty. An Act of Parliament is enforceable by British courts, even if it is in breach of Britain's treaty obligations. However, in interpreting statutes, the court will wherever possible interpret so as to conform with international law.

The European Economic Community (EEC) is a distinctive Community compared with other international organizations because it has its own broad executive and legislative powers, as well as judicial powers for creating and enforcing Community Law, such as Regulations made by the Council of Ministers, which are directly applicable in all member states. In 1963, the European Court of Justice stated that "...the Community constitutes a new legal order of international law, for the benefit of which the states have limited their sovereign rights within limited fields, and the subjects of which comprise not only member states but also their nationals."

The Community legal order, therefore, is inconsistent with the orthodox view of Parliamentary supremacy and sovereignty.

The Single European Act, signed in February 1986 by the Heads of Government of the 12 Member States of the European Community and which came into force on 1st July, 1987, aims to create a single market by the end of 1992. This major target will be achieved by the removal of all fiscal, technical, and physical barriers. Consequently, merchants or tradespeople could sell their goods in any community country, individuals could borrow and deposit money in the banks of any member state, and work with national qualifications in any member state. Additionally, the introduction of a European passport and an integrated transport system would further facilitate this seamless market.

Despite the forward proposals to amend the Treaty of Rome, which originated from Lord Cofield, an Englishman, there has been widespread dissatisfaction in Britain regarding the single market. This dissatisfaction is evident in frequent debates in Parliament and letters published in leading national newspapers. In contrast, Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, characterized the measures as a mere compromise.

In accordance with Britain's Constitutional Law, Parliament is the supreme law-making body, which inevitably presents problems when another source of law deemed to be supra-national emerges. Parliament has the right to make treaties, but these treaties are not directly effective on British individuals. Therefore, when a treaty contains provisions granting rights and duties to individuals, these cannot be relied upon until they are substantially incorporated into the law of the United Kingdom, by an Act of Parliament. This acts as a curb to the enforcement of European Community Law, allowing for a certain degree of sovereignty to be retained.

Personally, I believe that while the integration of Britain into Europe will be beneficial in many aspects, such as freedom of transportation, movement, and work, several disadvantages also lie ahead. These include the potential loss of sovereignty to a certain extent. Despite this, the potential benefits may still outweigh these drawbacks, provided that careful consideration is given to maintaining a balance between national sovereignty and European integration.

"But we'll lose our sovereignty!" is the cry of the opponents of European unity not only in Britain but throughout the 12 member states of the EC. On this island at the very edge of Europe, however, we possess a particularly low reputation for fighting change and exhibiting general xenophobia. What are we afraid of? Perhaps the most unpopular EC policy in this country is the Common Agricultural Policy Regulations, which dictate the amount of food we are allowed to produce as a country. If you mention the common agricultural policy to an Englishman, most of them will immediately think of the butter mountains, wine lakes, and surpluses of meat. The positive elements of the policy do not get as much publicity as the negative ones.

Therefore, the EC is widely viewed in Britain as an institution that interferes with and disrupts the British economy and way of life, rather than enhancing it. The notion of "sovereignty" is an old-established term in the world of international relations and is generally accepted to mean that while other states may have a right to have some say in how a state runs its foreign affairs, the domestic affairs of that state are the concern of that state alone. No other state should interfere. It is the fact that the EC is seen as interfering in the economic affairs of each country that causes so much discontent. Political sovereignty seems important to the general public only insofar as it involves control of the economy. The reasoning of the opponents of European unity is that "Brussels bureaucrats" when making policy decisions will have more their interests at heart than those of any particular country.

This is the short-sighted view. The broader, long-term European citizen will move in the direction of global integration.

In order to determine whether Britain, or more accurately speaking the United Kingdom, would lose sovereignty in the event of the unification of Europe, it is first necessary to discuss the nature of sovereignty in this country at the moment and to see how it might be able to lose it in the future. Sovereignty, originally invested in the Crown, today stems by convention from Parliament, which is traditionally believed to be legislatively supreme. As there is no written, or codified constitution in the U.K., which has a higher status than that of ordinary law, Parliament can theoretically make or unmake any law whatsoever. In the words of the known jurist Dicey, this shows that, by the orthodox, traditional approach, it is impossible to bind subsequent governments as to the procedure or manner and form of legislation. Consequently, entrenchment of statute is deemed impossible. Unification would, by implication, involve a universal European adoption of common laws to provide compatibility between the individual constituent nation states and to ensure those laws are recognized by UK courts. This necessitates the adoption of these laws in the U.K. through the ordinary way, such as by enactment of an Act of Parliament.

Those adopting the orthodox viewpoint would see this as a "loan" of sovereignty rather than a "loss." They would argue that, by the theory of parliamentary legislative supremacy, the U.K. might reclaim this sovereignty by repealing the European statutes through the ordinary legislative process.

It could be claimed that the U.K. made its first steps towards unification when it joined the European Community (E.C.) with the enactment of the European Communities Act 1972. By considering whether, by adopting this Act, the U.K. has lost some sovereignty or merely "loaned" it, we can predict what effect subsequent legislation related to the formation of "a single Europe" would have on the sovereignty of the country.

Several reasons have been put forward as to why the European Communities Act 1972 cannot ordinarily be repealed, suggesting that the U.K. has lost sovereignty. It has been argued that when the U.K. joined the E.C., a new order had been created in which Parliament is no longer all-powerful and cannot amend or repeal any statute that establishes that order.

As a British student of modern languages, having lived and worked in Paris for a year, and become acquainted with the  French culture, I might be expected to have a more "European" perspective than the average British person. Yet if my experience taught me anything it is that issues of national identity are very emotionally charged. At a conscious level, I support the idea of a united Europe; yet surprisingly often during my year in France I would find myself at dinner parties embroiled in a heated debate over the channel tunnel and the impact of 1992. 	More than other European nation, I believe the British have a particular attachment tot the idea of the nation's being sovereign over itself. The French for example already seem to mistrust even power at a national level, if this might take power away from individual citizens (perhaps a legacy from the French Revolution's ideals). Other European nations are divided down into smaller federal regions, as is the case in Switzerland. In fact Britain has been one of the few European countries not to favour an electoral system of proportional representation. This implies the British prefer the idea of a single government, united in policy, reflecting the interests of a supposedly united nation. Of course such a vision is a false one. Nevertheless, such an image makes any loss of sovereignty to such a nation more keenly felt. The current and recent British governments have been at odds with the more common political stance in Europe, the British one being right-wing and individualistic. In particular Margaret Thatcher and Nicolas Ridley (rather tactlessly, in his case) opposed a complete alignment with Europe. However I believe this difference in political stance is a less important factor in the British unease about 1992 than is the more deeprooted notion of Britain's being self-contained.
	In just one year, the original aims of the 1957 Treaty of Rome will be fulfilled, cementing European unity. This will have undoubted economic benefits, freeing both trade and the movement of people across boundaries. But perhaps the most significant change is that decisions  - over laws, human rights policy and defence issues -  will be taken collectively, not individually.<|end|><|assistant|>

As a British student of modern languages, having lived and worked in Paris for a year, and become acquainted with French culture, I might be expected to have a more "European" perspective than the average British person. Yet my experience taught me that issues of national identity are very emotionally charged. At a conscious level, I support the idea of a united Europe, yet surprisingly often during my time in France, I found myself at dinner parties embroiled in heated debates over the Channel Tunnel and the impact of 1992. I frequently surprised myself by the vehemence of my defense of "other" British people who were nervous about the whole prospect.

More than other European nations, I believe the British have a particular attachment to the idea of the nation's being sovereign over itself. The French, for example, already seem to mistrust even national power, possibly due to the ideals of the French Revolution. Other European nations, like Switzerland, are divided into smaller federal regions. Notably, Britain has been one of the few European countries to oppose an electoral system of proportional representation, implying a preference for a single, united government reflecting the interests of a supposedly united nation. Although this vision may be false, such an image makes any loss of sovereignty felt more keenly. The current and recent British governments, which have been at odds with the more common European political stance, have leaned right-wing and individualistic. Margaret Thatcher and Nicholas Ridley's opposition to complete alignment with Europe was particularly notable, though arguably less crucial to British unease about 1992 than the deep-rooted notion of Britain's self-containment.

In just one year, the original aims of the 1957 Treaty of Rome will be fulfilled, cementing European unity. This will undoubtedly have economic benefits, freeing both trade and the movement of people across boundaries. However, the most significant change is that decisions over laws, human rights policies, and defense issues will be made collectively rather than individually.

European nations have long been connected through war and peace, and over time, they have grown closer on more institutional lines. One significant example of this is the formation of the European Community, which includes the European Coal and Steel Community, the European Atomic Energy Community, and the European Economic Community.

In 1987, the European Community adopted the single European Act, committing member countries to establishing a single internal European market by 1992. This act has raised questions in Britain about whether it will lead to a loss of sovereignty for the nation.

An important aspect of the single European Act is its commitment to majority rule rather than the previously common practice of consensus decision-making in the Council of Ministers. This shift could limit the ability of individual nations to veto key decisions.

British sovereignty could be jeopardized if a centralized European government begins to impose its authority on Britain. A centralized European government might restrict Britain's decision-making capabilities. The recent incident involving the European Parliament imposing its ideals on Britain underscores the authoritative principles that might be expected if such a strong central body were created. For example, the European Parliament's attempt to halt construction on the Channel Tunnel link due to environmental concerns was seen by many in Britain as an infringement on its sovereignty.

If the European Community were to introduce a single currency, Britain might lose its sovereignty, as it would forfeit its individuality and bargaining position in foreign exchange markets. Currency decisions would then be made by a central body, which Britain would have to accept.

On becoming a member of the EEC and signing the 1972 Treaty of Accession, the UK had to enact the provisions of the treaty to make our accession part of English law. Simply signing the treaty meant members were already pooling their sovereign rights in certain areas. Resistance to joining from inside Britain and from inside the Community itself was centred around the argument that Britain was already enjoying favourable trading conditions with the U.S.A. and with the countries of the Commonwealth. As the EEC assumes ever greater proportions, the debate, particularly in Britain, is now centred around a potential loss of sovereignty as member states look to integrate further.

As Britain continues to sign treaties, the regulations that are entailed in these treaties become directly applicable to the U.K. without the interference of Parliament. The Single European Act has given rise to more majority voting in the European institutions, making it increasingly possible to introduce legislation in the U.K. to which no one here has agreed. Certain rules of community law regarding rights and duties are directly effective, and it has been made quite clear that the courts are to apply these rules as if they were Acts of Parliament.

It is increasingly the case that Parliament legislates so the end result is as desired by the Community. The Community was quick enough to remind the Italians that a new legal order had been created and that pieces of community law would be directly applicable. In short, the Community was reminding the Italians of the degree of transfer of sovereignty.

However, the current European writer Collins, while maintaining his support for community law and discretion, is in favor of the power of Parliament to repeal the 72 Act that made Britain a member. Lord Denning too agrees that if Britain wished expressly to repeal the E.C. Act, then we could and would do just that. The present situation can be referred to as Parliamentary self-denial, meaning that for the moment it accepts the output of Brussels. Lord Scarmann reminds us that the E.C. has force of law in Britain only because Parliament says so, and he too is of the opinion that if Britain should for whatever reason want to disassociate with the Community, we could.

At present, the issue of whether Britain should become more closely integrated within the European Community is very controversial. The question is whether integration should be to a lesser extent, exemplified by the establishment of a single, common currency, the E.C.U., in each member state, or to a greater extent, involving the complete political unification of the "Twelve" into the so-called United States of Europe. This debate has become a political powder keg, especially for the Conservative Party, which has divided itself into two factions: one for and one against closer integration. This internal conflict led to the resignation of Margaret Thatcher, who tried to "bully" her Cabinet and Parliamentary Party into supporting her undeniably Europhobic views.

In my opinion, a single Europe in a political sense would be disadvantageous for Britain and unworkable due to the mix of opinions and cultures within the E.C. A single, politically unified Europe would likely struggle to form a stable majority since there would probably not be a large enough number of Members of the European Parliament (M.E.P.s) of a particular persuasion, whether Socialist, Centre Right, or Christian Democratic. This would lead to the formation of coalitions across ideological boundaries, which, as we have seen in recent examples from Italy and Belgium, often results in unstable and ineffectual governments.

A perfect illustration of both the impact of coalition governments and the current lack of agreement among E.C. members on crucial issues such as Defence and Foreign (i.e., extra-European) Policy can be seen during the Gulf War. As Britain prepared for Operation Desert Storm, it ran low on stocks of ammunition for certain types of guns and artillery. To address this, Britain requested that one of its European Community partners and NATO allies, namely Belgium, sell it some of its ammunition.

However, Belgium, under the premiership of Wilfred Martens, refused to cooperate despite the fact that Britain, among others, was engaged in an operation to combat the naked aggression of Iraq against its tiny neighbor, Kuwait—a mission that had the full backing of the Security Council of the United Nations. Belgium's refusal to cooperate was due to the fear of aggravating extremist minorities within its country, which could potentially split its coalition government. School integration has been a hot topic across the United States since 1954, when the Supreme Court decided that, and racial segregation in schools was declared unconstitutional. After this decision was made, the number of black students attending schools with white students increased slowly but surely. Medicine has made many advancements in the past several years. For example, drugs such as Dilantin, used to treat seizures caused by epilepsy, have improved the quality of life for many people. These drugs have even promoted the longevity of patients who might not have survived otherwise. People affected by diseases like cancer and AIDS have relied on treatments like Depo-Provera and AZT for their therapeutic value. The miracles of modern biochemical research have dramatically changed the way we treat disease. However, drug companies have escalated their prices over 82% in the decade of the 80s, causing financial strain for many Americans, including pharmacies and drug buyers. This led to lawsuits seeking fair discounts. Blatant overpricing of many important drugs has significantly impacted the quality of healthcare, particularly for the elderly and those with fixed incomes. This situation underscores the necessity for federal intervention and the establishment of a price regulation review board to curb the increasing costs of drugs.

Health care statistics on expenditures are indeed staggering. The pharmaceutical industry argues that drug costs outside hospitals were $36.4 billion in 1991, which only constituted five percent of the total national health costs ($751.8 billion). This figure might seem reasonable. However, these statistics are flawed because 55 percent of what American consumers paid for health care went out of pocket, mainly because Americans often get prescriptions from places other than hospitals. This price-gouging is evident in skyrocketing hospital bills.

Despite these statistics, the pharmaceutical industry contends that medical pricing boards would raise prices and eliminate competition between companies. However, evidence from other countries suggests otherwise. For instance, the Patented Medicine Prices Review board in Canada leads to substantially lower drug prices for Canadian subsidiaries of American companies, averaging 32% less. Similarly, rates for European subsidiaries are anywhere from 74 to 45 percent lower than those in the United States. Most European countries under the European Community also have drug price regulation boards, which helps keep prices lower.

By examining these international examples, it's clear that the establishment of price regulation could lead to more affordable healthcare and prevent exorbitant drug prices. Federal intervention and the creation of a price regulation review board are vital steps in addressing this issue.

How far would you go to be the best athlete in the world? Some people might push their limits too far. Steroids and the use of other performance-enhancing drugs are becoming a major problem in today's society. Steroids are chemical cousins of the hormone testosterone. They promote muscle growth and increase aggression, spurring athletes to more strenuous workouts. The International Olympic Committee has already banned nearly 100 substances, highlighting the ongoing struggle between athletes determined to use any means available to enhance their performance and those dedicated to fair play. Drug testing of all athletes is ethical and should be mandatory to ensure fair competition, protect athletes' health and safety from the long-term effects of steroid usage, and prevent drug usage among student and professional athletes regarded as role models.

Many people question whether mandatory drug testing is ethical or if it is a violation of athletes' rights to privacy. Ethics refers to human conduct, emphasizing the determination of right and wrong. Using performance-enhancing drugs is against the rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and professional sports associations. To enforce these rules, athletes must be drug-tested. As John Chaplin, an Olympic track official and veteran track-and-field coach, pointed out, the only way to clean up sports is to institute random testing. In the article "A Game of Cat and Mouse," he stated, "If you want to keep the game fair and athletes safe, random testing is essential." Athletes are notified in advance that they will be tested, allowing them to prepare adequately. Thus, maintaining the integrity of the sport and ensuring a level playing field are paramount.

There are many dilemmas that humans must face every day. Some of these dilemmas are easily justified, while others are not. These dilemmas can range from a simple act of choosing which friends to side with in a disagreement, to something more serious, like a priest breaking his reconciliation oath and handing over a confidential confession of a murderer to the police. We make most of these decisions based on our values and beliefs, which often stem from our religious backgrounds or the morals and ethics on which we were raised. These ethics contribute to the majority of our decision-making tactics. When forming a decision based on ethics, we must be careful to determine which side is morally correct.

A dilemma in which morals have come up more often than not is the case for animal rights. Should these animals be tested to protect human lives, or what gives us the right to test these animals? In the Bible, humans are given certain responsibilities. What better authority figure than God could give us this right? Animals were put on earth for humans to use, as long as we did not take advantage of this gift. I believe that in most cases, animal testing is trying to save people's lives, one way or another. The decision must be made that a human's life is more important than an animal's life. Animal testing is a crucial part of our society and must continue if humans want to maintain their status as the superior species.

An example of this is a three-year-old named Timmy Baker who suffered a heart attack from a disease he possibly contracted from eating an undercooked hamburger. He was not responding to resuscitation efforts, and his doctor, Dr. Michael McManus, decided to give him the epinephrine drug. The dosage recommended by the medical association did not work, so Dr. McManus heard about the research done by Dr. Traystman. In Dr. Traystman's research, pigs are electronically subjected to heart attacks, resuscitated, and then given a dose of the drug epinephrine to help revive heart attack victims while preventing brain damage. Dr. Traystman also conducts tests to determine whether additional doses of the medication can help a suffering patient. This research highlights the importance of weighing the ethical considerations of animal testing against the potential benefits to human lives.

According to the Centers for Disease Control, the sheer size of this problem has prompted Chancellor Joseph Fernandez to develop a plan to combat this epidemic. reciting the pledge of allegiance and a group prayer. Today, the

Forty years ago, starting the day off in a public school often meant reciting the pledge of allegiance and a group prayer. Today, the American flag garners little attention, and a public prayer contradicts constitutional law. But why does praying in public schools receive such a negative reputation? There is a strong movement in the United States to bring back prayer to the schoolhouse. However, the argument used to support the use of prayer in public schools relies too heavily on shaky speculation, fallacies, and fanaticism for effectiveness.

Those who oppose prayer in public schools focus on fairness and equality for everyone, making their argument much more convincing and acceptable. An easy claim to make in arguments for the use of prayer in public school is that it can help troubled youth. Although this may seem like an encouraging thought, it nonetheless displays naïveté and wishful thinking. A prayer alone cannot subdue major societal problems. Trying to get a troubled youth out of a gang with a prayer in school is comparable to trying to extinguish a burning house with a thimble full of water. It is just not enough to be effective. A thorough religious awakening may help alleviate significant problems that plague youth, but a daily prayer in school hardly qualifies as this.

Additionally, a side overlooked by supporters of prayer in public schools points out that teen pregnancy, violence, and drug abuse among youths are increasing since the ban of school prayer. This fact strengthens the argument for not allowing prayer in public schools. Supporters often point to these trends as evidence that prayer leads to moral virtue. However, too many uncontrolled variables, like an increase in broken homes and violence on television, may distort results. During the time when prayer existed in public schools, moral tarnishes such as segregation, lynchings, and the oppression of women blemished society.

In short, because no data shows that prayer actually causes a better educational or social environment, there is no reason to allow for its inclusion into the public school.

Many children not only live in homes that cannot support them

nurturing care, but may be scarred for life. There are also too many
people taking advantage of the system by continuing to have children to

To many, just the word "orphanage" has a dark ring to it. Those who feel this way often see pictures of Oliver Twist or Little Orphan Annie in a dreary prison for children. While over the past century, there have been poorly run orphanages, the vast majority were pleasant places for orphans to grow up. In the past decade, the question of whether orphanages should be brought back has come to the government's and the public's attention. Today, there are still a few orphanages running, but their numbers are nowhere near what they were one hundred years ago. With the current welfare crisis, many, such as Republican Newt Gingrich, feel that support payments to mothers continuing to have children on welfare should be stopped or greatly reduced. The money would then be used to support orphanages. This, of course, would mean taking many children away from their natural parents. Opposition to the idea of orphanages mainly boils down to two reasons: they disagree with the breakup of families, and they believe that the whole policy would be too costly.

While these two ideas are difficult to content with, the truth is in the numbers. Many children not only live in homes that cannot financially support them but also face abusive environments. These children are not receiving warm, nurturing care but may be scarred for life. There are also too many people taking advantage of the welfare system by having more children to gain financial support.

Despite the criticisms, many children have proven that growing up in an orphanage provides a stable and nurturing atmosphere. Therefore, orphanages should be reinstituted. This way, children in desperate circumstances can receive the care and support they need in a safe and loving environment.

When someone thinks of business, they often envision big corporations, suits, stocks, bonds, and money. However, business is more than just an economic exchange involving money, commodities, and profits. In business, there is more than just making a profit and getting ahead; it involves relationships throughout the business environment, necessitating a sense of respect and trust. The relationships created in business include the union between producers and consumers, employers and employees, and the corporation and society. I believe that the public has a right to be informed about anything and
everything that they want to be informed about, and people want to be
informed about the death penalty; therefore, media should have access to
report on executions. However, there access should be restricted to

to be executed, was Robert Alton Harris.
Robert Alton Harris was sentenced to death in 1979 for the kidnapping
and murder of two San Diego teenagers. He was on parole after having
served three years for manslaughter when this happened. After an
enormous number of appeals, Harris was finally executed in the gas
chamber on the morning of April 21, 1992, shortly after 6 a.m. Harris
was the first person to be executed in California since 1967.

However, San Francisco public television channel KQED filed a lawsuit
opposing the ban because they were working on a documentary about Harris
and wanted to film the execution. Over two dozen newspapers and
broadcast stations joined KQED in protesting the ban. Some of these
groups included the American Newspaper Publishers Association,
California Newspaper Publishers Association, California First Amendment
Coalition, National Press Photographers Association and the Radio and
Television News Directors Association of Southern California. The media
groups filed a brief in U.S. District Court asking that the ban be
canceled on the grounds that it would <*>. Judge Robert H. Schnacke
overruled the ban and allowed for reporters to be in the witness
execution room. He did not allow them to bring in video cameras, though.
James F. Brelsford, attorney for the San Francisco Examiner and author
of the brief mentioned previously, said he was <*>. The reason Schnacke
made the decision that he did was because the warden, Vasquez, had made
to effort to justify his ban on all reporters that no evidence was

I believe that the public has a right to be informed about anything and everything they are curious about, and people are increasingly interested in learning about the death penalty. Therefore, it follows that media outlets should be granted access to report on executions. However, access to such coverage should be strictly limited to exclude any and all devices capable of endangering the security or safety of those involved. This argument is frequently debated, especially during times when the death penalty is actually being carried out.

One notable case that received national attention was the execution of Robert Alton Harris in California. Harris, who had been sentenced to death in 1979 for the kidnapping and murder of two San Diego teenagers while on parole after serving three years for manslaughter, faced numerous appeals before his execution in the gas chamber on April 21, 1992, shortly after 6 a.m. Harris was the first person executed in California since 1967.

Originally, San Quentin warden Daniel Vasquez banned all media coverage of Harris's execution, citing security concerns. However, San Francisco public television channel KQED challenged the ban because they were preparing a documentary about Harris and wanted to film the execution. Over two dozen newspapers and broadcast stations joined KQED in opposing the ban, including the American Newspaper Publishers Association, California Newspaper Publishers Association, California First Amendment Coalition, National Press Photographers Association, and the Radio and Television News Directors Association of Southern California. These media groups filed a brief in U.S. District Court, arguing that the ban would prevent the public from learning about the reasons behind the execution, which they believed was a crucial part of understanding the justice system.

Judge Robert H. Schnacke ultimately ruled against the ban, allowing reporters to be present in the execution room, but he did not permit video cameras. James F. Brelsford, attorney for the San Francisco Examiner and author of the brief mentioned earlier, believed this decision was fair because the warden, Vasquez, had failed to provide any evidence suggesting that reports using notebooks and pencils posed any security risks. Ten weeks later, Schnacke extended the ban to include sketch pads, which are often used by journalists during such events. This decision further highlighted the tension between the need for public access to death penalty executions and concerns about media presence during such sensitive events.

I remember driving to northern Wisconsin with my Father when I was twelve. On the way there, he told me he wanted to explain the bird's and the bee's to me. We both blushed, chuckled, and shrugged it off to embarrassment. Although I had many questions for my Father, the talk of sexual relationships never came up again. However, my curiosities about sexual relationships still existed.

Finally, at the age of eighteen, I gave in to peer pressures to have sexual intercourse. I decided to have sex with a classmate to feel socially accepted by my peers. From that moment on, my life would never be the way I expected it.

At eighteen, I needed to make life-altering decisions with my mate about what our options were. We felt the right decision was to get married, have the child, and live happily ever after. We were wrong. After a few difficult years of marriage, we divorced.

In all of the colleges and universities across the United States, administrators are working diligently to increase enrollment. This effort is entirely ethical and necessary for maintaining many of the programs and facilities that universities offer. Furthermore, universities frequently adapt to the evolving needs of their students by offering services like free tutors and expanding their staff.

However, the approach of Marquette University stands out, and not in a positive way. This institution is attempting to attract students with a vast green space that spans about five city blocks, complete with grass, trees, and a fountain. While the idea of creating a more comfortable learning environment is commendable, this substantial investment may have unforeseen consequences. The $10 million cost, which students will ultimately bear, could place an undue burden on them, particularly those struggling financially.

Moreover, this green space will also impact the local community, requiring a matching $10 million to reroute the utilities that run through Wisconsin Avenue. Although Euthanasia is practiced throughout the U.S., it is still a very
controversial topic of conversation. Proponents of euthanasia argue that
the Declaration of Independence states life, liberty, and the pursuit of
happiness as rights that all American possess. Opponents of euthanasia
present the questions, "does the right to your own life include the
right to take that life as well?" In my opinion, that should not be so.
Simply because that there are few people who are thinking of taking
there own lives and are also of sane mind. If someone is having a bad
enough struggle within themselves that they are willing to end that God
given life, then it is possible that the individual is not mentally or
emotionally stable to make that decision. So, who is to decide whether a
life is worth living? Who can project whether a patient in a coma will
come to consciousness or not? With questions such as these, there is no
black or white answers. There is a large gray area involved in answering
those questions that the law is supposed to cover. Within this paper it
will be shown that there are three ideas working against the practice of
euthanasia. For one, America is not ready to allow any human being to
take an innocent, and in some cases a guilty individual from this world,
whether it be his/her own or another. The second idea is that it is too
difficult to determine if a person will suffer too much in his or her
lifetime to go on living. This idea is held together by the fact that
there is too much gray areas within ethics and that patients or doctors
can not decisively determine whether a live is worth living. The third
idea is that the "law" that determines whether a life is "worth living"

of these reasons, euthanasia should not be allowed to be practiced as
freely as it is in the United States.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Although euthanasia is practiced throughout the U.S., it remains a very controversial topic of conversation. Proponents of euthanasia argue that the Declaration of Independence states life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness as rights that all American possess. Opponents of euthanasia, however, raise important questions, such as "does the right to your own life include the right to take that life as well?" In my opinion, that should not be so. Simply because there are only a few people who are considering taking their own lives and are of sound mind. If someone is experiencing such a significant struggle within themselves that they are willing to end their God-given life, it is possible that the individual may not be mentally or emotionally stable to make that decision.

So, who is to decide whether a life is worth living? Who can project whether a patient in a coma will come to consciousness or not? With questions such as these, there are no clear black or white answers; there is a large gray area involved in answering those questions that the law is supposed to cover. Within this paper, it will be demonstrated that there are three ideas working against the practice of euthanasia. Firstly, America may not be ready to allow any human being to take an innocent, and in some cases, guilty individual from this world, whether it's their own or another's. Secondly, it is too difficult to determine if a person will suffer too much in their lifetime to continue living, as this idea is held together by the fact that there are too many gray areas within ethics and that neither patients nor doctors can decisively determine whether a life is worth living. Lastly, the law that determines whether a life is "worth living" is too vague, allowing for too many shaky judgments to be made.

Because of these reasons, euthanasia should not be allowed to be practiced as freely as it is in the United States.

decision to make. Will they keep the child to raise and love him, or

opinion. Because this is so, there is still no answer as to who should
have rights over a child.
Blood is thicker than water. This is the main underlying value stated by

bound by law to favor the biological parents unless abuse, neglect or
abandonment can be proved. The righteousness of this point is debated

Recent cases that have played out in the media have raised the question of the rights of biological parents versus the rights of adoptive parents. While both sides present some good arguments, neither proponents nor opponents of biological parents used strong values or consequences, nor attempted to change public opinion. Because of this, there is still no definitive answer as to who should have rights over a child.

Blood is thicker than water, which is the main underlying value stated by supporters of biological parents. The United States' legal system is bound by law to favor biological parents unless abuse, neglect, or abandonment can be proved. The righteousness of this point is debated well by supporters of adoptive parents. They cite a case in which an 18-year-old woman abandoned her child in a hospital and later got custody, even though she was living in a homeless shelter at the time. This is a somewhat strong argument against the favoring of biological parents. Although they use a rare case as an example, it highlights the inconsistency of our court system. How should the Fourth Amendment be interpreted? According to the Constitution, illegal search and seizure is unlawful, except for in "exigent circumstances." That phrase leaves much room for interpretation. The recent search of O.J. Simpson's home following the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldwin was an example of exigent circumstances, according to Judge Kathleen Kennedy, Powell. Yet, the defense and prosecution have different ethical reasons for arguing whether this evidence should or should not be allowed into the courtroom. Many people, including the prosecuting attorneys in the case, believe it is ethical because, if someone is guilty of a crime, they should pay the price. It is irrelevant whether the detectives obtained the evidence legally or not. The defense, however, argues that the court should not allow the jury to hear this evidence during Simpson's trial because O.J. Simpson's rights as a citizen of the United States were disregarded. The detectives and the Los Angeles Police Department gathered much of the evidence without a warrant, leading to skepticism about its validity. Both sides recognize their strengths and weaknesses concerning the issue and format their arguments accordingly. The proposition for the admissibility of the evidence relies on the judge's interpretation and the detectives' statements to help the public understand their actions. The opposition, however, highlights the detectives' past and inconsistencies in their statements to cast doubt on the reliability of the evidence collected.

On the evening of June 13, 1994, authorities discovered the bodies of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldwin, brutally murdered at Nicole's condominium in Los Angeles. After investigating the scene, they drove to the home of O.J. Simpson, supposedly out of concern for his safety. When they arrived, they rang the doorbell several times before climbing the five-foot fence without a search warrant. Shortly afterward, detective Mark Fuhrman discovered a bloody glove that matched a glove found at the crime scene. This discovery led the detectives to search O.J.'s home and find several key pieces of evidence linking O.J. Simpson to the murders.

Many events in our lives have consequences, but there are none as drastic as suicide. Suicide means the end of all problems, which are usually solved easily. However, the opponents of suicide often fail to provide evidence for their arguments. All the statements they make are strong, and with some thought, they can be rationalized. Yet, the opponents usually neglect to prove their statements.

The argument that suicide is selfish is weak and lacks substantial evidence. However, if readers examine their own experiences with those who attempt suicide, they might find this argument more convincing. In "The Case Against Suicide," William Rauscher argues that suicide is an inherently selfish act because it does not consider the effects on others. He believes that individuals who commit suicide are focused solely on ending their own suffering, ignoring the impact on their loved ones. Rauscher hopes to convey that the primary concern of those who attempt suicide is whether they should end their own pain. However, Rauscher fails to consider the thoughts and emotions of those attempting suicide, such as their thoughts about their family and friends. For instance, a person dying of lung cancer might cause significant distress to their family if they were still alive. The immense pain experienced by someone dying of cancer, and the family's helplessness in comforting the person, might not have been fully considered by Rauscher in his analysis. Thus, the emotional and psychological consequences for the family are significant and should be taken into account.

The idea that <*> seems at first to be in harmony with our perceived values of equality in American society. Although it is likely that most Americans, if asked, would profess to the belief that equal work deserves equal pay, equality of work as defined by specific task, physical difficulty, or cognitive difficulty, is not the real issue. The real issue, in a discussion of relative contribution to society, involves our deeper cultural assumptions about values of various societal functions, including non-productive (in financial terms) work.

Child care work makes a good example for this point. Americans profess to value children, spending time, money and thought on such concerns as education and child safety laws. Our national education system is a pereniel subject and topic of debate in the media. However, as a nation, Americans have not reached a level of conscious acknowledgment that labor performed in the child care industry is valuable labor. If we consider that our society rewards valuable labor - valuable contributions - with first, economic measures, and, second, measures of status, then the child care worker may reasonably be judged as not providing a "valuable" contribution to society.

It is difficult to imagine, however, a society where workers are encouraged to take employment seriously - to say nothing of finding satisfaction from employment - and where the work force is filled with a diversity of willing workers, without considering the fundamental value of child care providers. If we recognize that a work force filled with such diversity of workers will inevitably include women - of all ages - as well as man with family responsibilities, then we see the undeniable economic connection between this "low value" contribution of child care providers, and the economic strength of the nation. It is not difficult to conclude that child care workers are underpaid, and the issue will be difficult to resolve without  involving employers or the government in the child care industry - which may not be the ideal solution. <*>. These are the words of Karl Marx, the father of modern communism. In any society, that principle applies to the members of the society in varying degrees. If one were to break the community structure into small parts, on e would understand the concept of Marx as it applies practically.

All of the members of a family will normally protect, provide and nurture its own. Absent a deviation from our general nature to propagate and extend ourselves through our offspring, the concept of egalitarianism is a natural choice for the family unit.
Society also has social institutions & practices in order which preserve the egalitarian concept. In Western society, for example, the primary guide is Christianity. The New Testament teaches <*>. This norm is deeply entrenched in western ideology. These beliefs extend to the individual. The individual, in turn, incorporates the norm into rational thought. Even those who are not Christian but who live in western society will most likely have inculcated that value on a personal level. 
In an affluent society, the concept of giving back to society that which can be given is thought of primarily in monetary terms, hence the idea, <*>.
There are several problems with this notion. First, who it to define what contribution merits what reward? If I value my own family and I make it my primary goal to raise my children to be productive and good citizens, is that not enough? Must I go instead into the streets to save the homeless man or rescue the battered woman? Should my financial rewards be less or more?
Second, there is the problem of freedom. The individual is paramount in the post-modern world. This seems highly contradictory to the forces that bind us: family, religion, common language & experience. This tension has been recognized by philosophers, poets & politicians throughout the history of western civilization.

Karl Marx's ideas, as the father of modern communism, find varying degrees of application in different societies. If we break down society into smaller components, we can better understand Marx's principles in a practical sense. For instance, the family structure in any society or culture exemplifies Marx's egalitarian goals. A mother nurtures her helpless infant, and family members generally protect, provide, and nurture their own. Without the inherent drive to propagate through offspring, the concept of egalitarianism is a natural fit for the family unit. 

Society also has social institutions and practices that preserve this egalitarian concept. In Western society, Christianity, particularly the teachings of the New Testament, serves as the primary guide. This norm is deeply entrenched in Western ideology. These beliefs even extend to individual thought, so that even those who are not Christian may personally uphold this value.

In affluent societies, the notion of giving back to society is primarily expressed in monetary terms. However, this perspective raises several issues. Who defines what contribution merits what reward? If someone prioritizes their family, aiming to raise children who become productive and good citizens, is this not a sufficient contribution? Should they also be expected to engage in broader social actions, such as saving a homeless person or rescuing a battered woman, and how does that affect their financial rewards?

Additionally, the problem of freedom in the post-modern world presents a challenge. The individual holds paramount importance, which appears at odds with the forces that bind us: family, religion, common language, and shared experiences. Consequently, there is a persistent tension between the rights of the individual and the good of society as a whole, a tension recognized by philosophers, poets, and politicians throughout Western civilization's history.

Ultimately, the onus is on the individual to determine their contribution to society, if any. The religious can find solace in the belief that rewards come from God, while the secular can find comfort in intrinsic, non-religious values.

In order to determine whether or not crime pays, one should first define what is meant by the word "pays". If a person gains $100 in a jewelry store theft, yet uses ten dollars worth of gas to get away, cuts his hand on a broken window and pays $50 in medical bills, and spends another $50 for a hideout hotel room, then his crime has actually left him ten dollars in the hole. 
However, the question of crime paying requires a deeper level of "pay" than simple dollars and cents accounting. In terms of criminal work, pay must be weighed as gains made from crime versus all manners of loss that occur as a result.
One issue to consider as a loss is the type of capital loss illustrated above. Crime, like any small business, requires an investment. One investment is time. If the time involved in the planning and enacting of a crime does not pay off in a gain that can justify that time expenditure, then the crime has not paid. Whether or not crime pays in this instance depends on how much money a criminal could make in a legitimate field. If the criminal can only expect to earn minimum wage in a legal job, then crimes can earn less to justify time spent. If a criminal is well educated and could function in one of the professions, then his crimes must earn more.
Other capital investments in crime could include equiptment such as get-away cars, dynamite, weaponry, and disguises. Mafia and police pay-offs could be involved. Dealing in stolen property or other contraband could require splitting monies earned with other involved parties. A crime's income must be enough to cover all these expenditures.
Another type of loss to be considered is loss of mental or physical health and well being. Many times violence is a part of crime. The cost of taking a gunshot or knife in the leg is more than just the medical bills. It could be an injury that keeps someone from ever working again. Very few criminals have worker's compensation. The stress that comes about from constant risk of injury and incarceration is a cost in itself, and could lessen both a person's life span and enjoyment of life.<|end|><|assistant|>

In order to determine whether or not crime pays, one should first define what is meant by the word "pays". If a person gains $100 in a jewelry store theft, yet uses $10 worth of gas to get away, cuts his hand on a broken window and pays $50 in medical bills, and spends another $50 for a hideout hotel room, then his crime has actually left him ten dollars in the hole. However, the question of crime paying requires a deeper level of "pay" than simple dollars and cents accounting. In terms of criminal work, pay must be weighed as gains made from crime versus all manners of loss that occur as a result.

One issue to consider as a loss is the type of capital investment illustrated above. Crime, like any small business, requires an investment. One investment is time. If the time involved in the planning and enacting of a crime does not pay off in a gain that can justify that time expenditure, then the crime has not paid. Whether or not crime pays in this instance depends on how much money a criminal could make in a legitimate field. If the criminal can only expect to earn minimum wage in a legal job, then crimes can earn less to justify time spent. If a criminal is well-educated and could function in one of the professions, then his crimes must earn more.

Other capital investments in crime could include equipment such as getaway cars, dynamite, weaponry, and disguises. The Mafia and police might require pay-offs. Dealing in stolen property or other contraband could require splitting monies earned with other involved parties. A crime's income must be enough to cover all these expenditures.

Another type of loss to be considered is the loss of mental or physical health and well-being. Many times, violence is a part of crime. The cost of taking a gunshot or knife in the leg is more than just the medical bills; it could be an injury that keeps someone from ever working again. Very few criminals have worker’s compensation. The phrase <*> is often invoked to justify living by the rules when a criminal has been caught. For example, a working class man may recite it with some satisfaction when he reads that a famous bank robber has died penniless in prison or that a former politician who scammed the public for millions in personal gain is now incarcerated making license plates for a token wage, such as $23.00 per month.
The phrase plays an important role in reassuring people who play by the rules or admonishing potential criminals. Crime seems also to pay for some less violent criminals. Michael Milliken reportedly made more money with his stock broker scams than he returned in his restitution, managed to continue his activities while in a "country club" prison, and has returned to society as a university teacher. The phrase "crime does not pay" is often invoked to justify living by the rules when a criminal has been caught. For example, a working-class man may recite it with some satisfaction when he reads that a famous bank robber has died penniless in prison, or that a former politician who scammed the public for millions in personal gain is now incarcerated making license plates for a token wage, such as $23.00 per month. The phrase plays an important role in reassuring people who play by the rules and admonishing potential criminals. Parents of miscreants often point out the error of the young person's ways with variations on the theme, emphasizing that crime does not pay. They reinforce this message with restitution or punishment that outweighs whatever payoff may have been associated originally with the crime.

However, if crime does not pay, then why does it persist? Behavior that is not reinforced will not persist. Yet, crime seems to pay for some, particularly less violent criminals, raising questions about who benefits. For instance, Michael Milliken reportedly made more money with his stock broker scams than he returned in his restitution. Milliken managed to continue his activities while in a "country club" prison and has since returned to society as a university teacher. Richard Nixon, having violated public trust, was deprived of public office and lived a sequestered life for several years. Nonetheless, he managed to become a representative of the nation again and, when he died, was honored as a "statesman" rather than a criminal.

These examples highlight the complexity of the adage "crime does not pay" and suggest that the perceived costs and benefits of criminal behavior vary widely, challenging the straightforward notion of it being an unprofitable endeavor.

There are many standards by which success and hard work have been measured and rewarded in the past. In earlier times people had the lifestyle of fending for themselves.
