In order to feed your family you had to plant. In order to live you had to build. To have clothing, you had to sew. Each hour of each day was devoted to meeting these needs. Even in early times the harder you worked, the more food, shelter or clothing you gained. This is a very simple support of reward equaling effort.
Bringing this to a more present time, we are now reaping the benefits of advanced technology, expanding knowledge, and modern times. We have many machines to held us meet our food, clothing and shelter needs with little or no effort on our part, it would appear. Persons with great technical minds are using their talent on the job and paying someone to do their labor. However, just as in earlier days, the harder you work, the greater the reward.
Let's imagine a society where all men and women were treated equal. All basic survival needs (and even wants for that matter) were provided regardless of the effort put forth. I would venture to guess that we would not be as advanced of a society as we are today. Competitiveness and jealously would set in and fights would occur. Worst case scenario: the world would become divided or even destroyed because someone was sitting on the sidelines and not doing their share. We would not have motivation to develop our talents and abilities and to use them in a way to benefit others. Our society would become selfish and hoarding and our culture would suffer. People with great technical minds are using their talents at work and paying someone else to do their labor. However, just as in earlier days, the harder you work, the greater the reward.

The question of compensation for services rendered is never so simple as remitting a predetermined salary based on qualifications and a person's dedication to the task at hand. If one has preconceived notions concerning one's salary, they will certainly be disappointed since some employers value their skills and abilities less than others. "Contribution to society" is subjective and therefore impossible to compensate "equally."

In the 1920s in America, it became very popular to disdain people who did not actually work for a living but merely lived off the interest of their investments. The stock market was experiencing a boom, and several formerly working-class citizens became wealthy and relished the idea of retiring early. However, several great authors of that period questioned the right of these investors to effectively live as parasites; they received money but contributed nearly nothing to society.

People who inherit money or live off the interest of investors often seem to spend their time in search of a new thrill, some sort of excitement that money cannot buy. Having almost unlimited wealth changes people, both those who are born into it and those who earn their own money early on. But do they have the right to live this way? These questions become particularly poignant when considering those who work very hard yet are paid miserably. A migrant worker may labor all day in a field and make less money in a day than a wealthy person spends on a tip at lunch.

The answer to this question lies in one's feelings about democracy. Some might argue that if a person is smart enough or lucky enough to earn money for an early retirement or their children's inheritance, they are entitled to it. On the other hand, a rather hard view might be that if someone who works on a menial or physically taxing job does not make a fair or moderate salary, it is their own fault or bad luck. These opinions are based on a rather faulty American premise that all people are given an equal chance in life and what they make of it is their own responsibility.

I am a true believer in the old saying that crime does not pay. Why? Well simply because I was always told that whatever you do in the dark eventually comes to light. A person who commits a crime will probably reap the benefits of whatever it is that they have done. For example, if I robbed a bank for about a cool million immediately afterwards, I would probably feel really good, financially stable, and that if I got away with that, I could probably do something even more complex or dangerous. With this mindset, someone could definitely head for destruction.

For an individual who starts out doing small crimes—or less serious crimes that do not harm or endanger the lives of individuals or groups—the thrill of not being caught only makes them want to try one more thing they feel they may just slide with. The cycle goes on and on. Once you reach this stage, you can consider yourself a habitual offender or someone who needs some kind of jail sentence, punishment, or deterrent to stop you, if not slow you down.

Besides the fact that you will eventually get caught doing a crime, the punishment varies according to the type of crime you have committed. For example, you can expect to get a stiffer punishment for a crime when you have endangered someone's life or their personal safety in some way. The phrase "I'll pay," though often repeated, prompts us to ponder the deeper meaning behind its common truth: crime indeed costs money. As we peruse the daily paper, tune in to the evening news, or converse with others, we frequently encounter stories of individuals robbed of possessions, jobs, and lives by their criminal acts. When the perpetrator of a crime is caught, the loss of their freedom is typically the immediate price they pay. Incarceration, regardless of duration, incurs financial costs. These costs frequently fall upon the criminal's family, friends, and acquaintances through the burden of increased tax dollars. As the number of criminals grows, so too does the tax money required to house them.

Such moments of realization can stir intense emotions rivaling, if not surpassing, the loss of one's own freedom. A simple apology—"I'm sorry"—cannot erase the pain inflicted upon the victims or the lasting burden the criminal must carry.

Moreover, law-abiding citizens are well aware that crime does not pay. Areas with high crime rates often see a decline in property values. Even attempts by individuals to enhance the worth of their real estate in such areas are thwarted by the pervasive effect of crime, leading to a direct financial loss for the community. Thus, the financial implications of crime extend beyond the individual perpetrator, influencing the broader society and economy.

However, when these small actions are combined, they can overwhelm a waterbody, leading to a degradation of water quality and a loss of water uses such as swimming, fishing, and boating.

The focus of this paper is on water pollution and its relationship to the Exchange Theory and the Rational Choice Theory. Human life is dependent on the presence of fresh water. Humans only get less than 3% of the planet's fresh water supply. Most of this water is locked up in glaciers, ice caps, and snow fields, yet only a fraction is easily accessible for humanity. Therefore, it is crucial for us to take responsibility for the water we do have.

To look at fresh water pollutants, we can divide them into four major categories: infectious agents, organic chemicals, inorganic chemicals, and radioactive materials. Infectious agents include bacteria, viruses, and parasites, primarily originating from untreated human excrement entering the water cycle. This contamination can have immediate effects on human health.

Organic chemicals encompass pesticides, fertilizers, plastics, detergents, oil, and gasoline. Inorganic chemicals include acids, caustics, salts, and metals. Radioactive materials, although rare, can come from natural sources or nuclear waste. Both sources can significantly impact water quality.

Regarding sources of pollution, we have two types: point source and non-point source water pollution. Point source pollution is predictable and easily detected, such as a discharge from a drainpipe. On the other hand, non-point source pollution does not have a specific location and unknowingly contaminates the water supply, like leaking oil from an engine carried by rain to a water source. Non-point water pollution is considered the most serious water pollution threat in the United States.

The Rational Choice Theory is relevant to water pollution because, as it suggests, society would benefit more if they were informed of the negative effects of water pollution. By understanding the consequences of our actions, individuals and communities can make more informed decisions to protect our precious water resources.

Pot, grass, reefer, kif, Mary Jane, Ganja, herb, dope, tea, weed, are all nicknames for marijuana, an ancient drug derived from the dried leaves of the cannabis sativa plant. When these leaves are smoked, alone or with tobacco, they produce a "high" that can range from mildly pleasant to highly intoxicating. The intensity of this high depends on the strength of the drug and the amount smoked. While there are hundreds of ingredients in marijuana, tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) is its primary component. THC affects the brain and circulatory system, particularly the heart, causing it to beat faster, sometimes dangerously, and causing small blood vessels to expand, which is most noticeable in the eyes as tiny capillaries swell and blood fills them, giving a bloodshot appearance.

Marijuana, also known by its Mexican colloquial name, is botanically identified as cannavais sativa and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years, making it one of the oldest agricultural commodities not grown for food. In 1914, El Paso, Texas, enacted the first U.S. ordinance banning the sale or possession of marijuana. By 1931, twenty-nine states had outlawed marijuana. In 1937, Congress passed the Marijuana Tax Act, effectively criminalizing the possession of marijuana throughout the United States. In 1970, the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act differentiated marijuana from other narcotics, reducing federal penalties for possession of small amounts. Prompted by Congress, President Richard Nixon appointed a bipartisan commission to study marijuana, which in 1972 released the Schafer Commission's report. Although Nixon rejected their recommendation for decriminalization, eleven states, home to a third of the nation's population, decriminalized marijuana during the 1970s, and most states softened their laws against it. However, the 1980s marked a significant shift in attitudes toward marijuana. Ronald Reagan's election brought the war on drugs to the White House, and in 1980, the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA) declared marijuana the most urgent drug problem facing the United States.

This paper will focus on the problems associated with the criminalization of marijuana and the positive implications of its legalization. A basic right of a human being living in a democratic society is that they are entitled to life. Food and shelter are fundamental needs a person must have in order to survive. A percentage of the population of the citizens of America lacks these necessities. Homelessness has become an intense problem in the United States that must be solved. In today's society, the purpose and effectiveness of the welfare system in Me United States are constantly questioned. With over fourteen million people reliant on welfare in the United States, some change is definitely needed. Conservatives hope to abolish the system completely while liberals insist that welfare reform is the answer. Nevertheless, a crucial question must first be answered: Why does welfare exist?
      Public welfare was first provided to families under the Social Security Act of 1935 as Aid to Dependent Children (ADC) . The target group was children who had become economically dependent because of the deaths of their fathers. The theory behind the act was that the number of families headed by women, who were primarily widows at that time, would remain small and that these mothers should remain at home rather than trying to achieve economic independence in the labor market.
      However, by 1962, welfare rolls had expanded. Children were no longer found to be dependent just because of the deaths of their fathers but also because the fathers had left the family or had never been part of the family unit. The program name was also changed to Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC) <R>.
      In 1967, the Work Incentive Program (WIN) was established to provide job training and counseling services. These services recognized that welfare families had special social and psychological difficulties. Child-care efforts were also expanded. Plus, "job developers" were attached to WIN offices to locate appropriate positions for WIN graduates.
      Further reforms occurred in 1971. Under the Talmadge Amendments, WIN offices were required to spend at least one-third of their funds for on-the-job training or public-service employment. The new theory was that placement in these components would improve the chances of participants obtaining regular jobs at the end of their assignments. It was also believed that welfare recipients lacked motivation to enter the work force and needed to be pushed into it <R>.
      Nevertheless, none of the past or present reforms of welfare policy have succeeded in lowering the number of welfare recipients in the United States. Since its beginning, AFDC has undergone a major transformation in its size, cost, and clientele.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
In today's society, the purpose and effectiveness of the welfare system in the United States are constantly questioned. With over fourteen million people reliant on welfare in the United States, some change is definitely needed. Conservatives hope to abolish the system completely, while liberals insist that welfare reform is the answer. Nevertheless, a crucial question must first be answered: Why does welfare exist? 

Public welfare was first provided to families under the Social Security Act of 1935 as Aid to Dependent Children (ADC). The target group was children who had become economically dependent because of the deaths of their fathers. The theory behind the act was that the number of families headed by women, who were primarily widows at that time, would remain small, and that these mothers should remain at home rather than trying to achieve economic independence in the labor market.

However, by 1962, welfare rolls had expanded. Children were no longer found to be dependent just because of the deaths of their fathers but also because the fathers had left the family or had never been part of the family unit. The program name was also changed to Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC).

In 1967, the Work Incentive Program (WIN) was established to provide job training and counseling services, recognizing that welfare families faced special social and psychological difficulties. Additionally, child-care efforts were expanded. Job developers were also attached to WIN offices to locate appropriate positions for WIN graduates.

Further reforms occurred in 1971 with the Talmadge Amendments, which required WIN offices to spend at least one-third of their funds for on-the-job training or public-service employment. The new theory posited that placement in these components would improve the chances of participants obtaining regular jobs at the end of their assignments. It was also believed that welfare recipients lacked motivation to enter the workforce and needed to be encouraged to do so.

Nevertheless, none of the past or present reforms of welfare policy have succeeded in lowering the number of welfare recipients in the United States. Since its beginning, AFDC has undergone a major transformation in its size, cost, and clientele.

The divorce rate nearly doubled between 1965 and 1975; however, the rate of increase began to slow down in the late seventies. Many conclude that the divorce rate has stabilized for the time and may fall even further. Even though the divorce rate appears to have stabilized, the fact is that over the last fifteen to twenty years, the divorce rate has been higher than it has ever been in our society.

General trends in the divorce rate occur in race and age groups. African Americans and younger people continue to have higher rates of divorce than rates of whites and older people, although all the rates have recently fallen.

The projection for the near future is that two-thirds of all first marriages will end in divorce. Children are the innocent victims in many of these divorces. It is predicted that one out of every three white children and two out of every three African American children born to a marriage will experience the breakup of their parents' marriage by the time they reach age sixteen.

If divorce is widespread, it is a sign that we are having a problem with the actual structure of marriage. This leads us to say that widespread personal troubles indicate a social problem. Several different theories can be used to analyze why divorce exists and why the divorce rate has increased.

One theory used to help understand divorce is symbolic interactionism. These theorists stress how changing expectations affect people's behavior. In the early 1930s, sociologist William F. Ogburn recognized that personality was becoming an important characteristic in a mate. Sociologists Ernest W. Burgess and Harvey J. Locke noted in 1945 that family solidarity was increasingly coning to depend on mutual affection, sympathetic understanding, and temperamental compatibility. The modern microcomputer (PC) has evolved at an incredibly fast pace: from the very first modern computer in the 1940's to the computers of today, there have been many technological advances and also there has been a tremendous impact on society. The computer has made life easier from a physical standpoint and harder from a mental standpoint.
The physical effects of the computer are numerous and easily seen. In offices, the computer is everywhere. From word processors to spreadsheet/database programs, computers have made office work easier and faster.  Automation of factories has also eliminated many manual jobs. Also almost everyone has at least one simple computer, e.g. a calculator. There are of course many other things computers are used for, but a lengthy list is not necessary as everyone already knows (except for people in 2nd & 3rd world countries) how abundant computers are.
The mental effect of computers is two-fold. Firstly, computers have made mathematical computations so easy to do, many people do not fully understand how or why their computer works. This has created a surplus of "needless" computations, figures, etc. People can easily do calculus or other type functions with a computer.  What many people do not realize is that computers make errors all the time.  Granted, it is the person who "told" the computer what to do that truly made the error; however if that person knew what he should do, or better stated "was able to do with a computer", he would not have erroneous answers. Mathematical models, theories, etc. are absolutely riddled with errors simply because there are many things people don't know or can't predict.  Due to this errors frequently exist in the world of computers simply because humans are ignorant- for whatever reason - of many "variables".
Secondly, computers have sometimes become more reliable than people.  A computer's circuits don't get tired and, if programmed 100% correctly (another perhaps impossible computation), never make errors.  This supposed reliability has left many workers out of work.  The effects of this are unpredictable.  Anger, frustration, fear, and many other negative feelings have sprung up simultaneously with the rise of computer usage.<|end|><|assistant|>

The modern microcomputer (PC) has evolved at an incredibly fast pace: from the very first modern computer in the 1940s to the computers of today, there have been numerous technological advances and tremendous impacts on society. The computer has eliminated many jobs through the automation of factories, accounting, engineering, and other scientific programs, etc. Despite the positive and negative effects on society, it is clear that the computer phenomenon is a catch-22. On one hand, the computer has made life easier in a physical sense and harder in a mental sense.

The physical effects of the computer are numerous and easily seen. In offices, computers are everywhere—from word processors to spreadsheet/database programs, making office work easier and faster. Automation of factories has also eliminated many manual jobs. Almost everyone has at least one simple computer, such as a calculator. While there are countless other uses for computers, it is evident how abundant they are, even in the most technologically advanced countries.

The mental effects of computers are two-fold. Firstly, computers have made mathematical computations so easy to perform that many people do not fully understand how or why their computer works. This has created a surplus of needless calculations and figures. People can easily do calculus or other types of functions using a computer. However, many are unaware that computers can and do make errors. Granted, the person who inputted the instructions is usually at fault, but if they understood what they should have done or could have done with a computer, they would not have erroneous results. Mathematical models and theories are riddled with errors because there are many variables people don't understand or cannot predict, leading to frequent mistakes in the world of computers simply because humans are often ignorant of these variables.

Secondly, computers have sometimes become more reliable than people. A computer's circuits don't get tired, and if programmed 100% correctly (which is another challenging computation), they never make errors. This perceived reliability has left many workers out of work. The effects of this are unpredictable, leading to anger, frustration, fear, and many other negative feelings that have arisen simultaneously with the rise of computer usage. This dichotomy highlights the complexity and far-reaching implications of the computer's role in modern society.

However, the use of these means humans have developed is where the greatest problems lie. Alone, they do not threaten us, but when they become welded with certain aspects of and certain people in our societies, they become potentially the most dangerous things that we hold in our hands.

Speaking from my experience living in the United States, I have come to feel that technology has become a large detriment to our youth in particular. People say that technological development has made our world much smaller, and I would concur that a great majority of Americans live in their own personal closets. In schools, Geography classes rarely, if ever, exist. Before I came to Spain, a group of children asked me if Spain was in Michigan. Explaining that Spain was located across the ocean did not seem to improve their understanding of the layout of our world. Furthermore, the effects of science and technology on the U.S. cannot be described fully, and I feel that its people have adopted the same "I am self-sufficient—I don't need any help" type of mentality. This mentality will slowly destroy us.

Moreover, our awareness of other people, other cultures, and other languages is very low on the priority list of our educators. Until I was 15, I was unable to study any foreign language at all, and even at that time, I had only one choice—German. Since I was twelve, I had an intense desire to learn Spanish. Unfortunately, due to the circumstances I mentioned earlier, I had to wait until I was twenty years old to even begin to learn this language. My experience is not unique.

In my home town of Kalamazoo, the invention of the shopping mall has significantly altered the lives of its residents and the town itself. While many people enjoy and utilize these malls, I contend that they are more of a detriment than a blessing. 

Kalamazoo, like most American cities, initially developed around central transportation hubs. Cities were first located near water, then near train tracks, and eventually farther away as trucks and cars emerged. Downtown Kalamazoo once thrived, with larger industries and specialized stores for everyday supplies located near the train station. Homes and neighborhoods sprawled outside the central city, with several floors of apartments above some stores to accommodate families who needed to live close to work.

Everyone was near the central city, making it accessible to all, regardless of social class. Historically, wealth disparities have driven the rich to build specialized shops and strip malls outside city limits. As the wealthy moved to the suburbs—facilitated by the automobile—they left the inner city to the poorer and working-class residents, many of whom lacked transportation or the means to relocate.

This trend has left downtown businesses in Kalamazoo struggling to maintain stability. Why should those with cars prefer to shop at a nice indoor mall instead of venturing downtown, where they will encounter less affluent residents who need to shop in specialized stores scattered throughout the city? The shift has led many larger stores and offices to relocate to strip malls near the main malls or within the malls themselves. While larger factories and office buildings still exist downtown, executives and business people often do not rely on commuting to and from the city, missing out on the thriving neighborhood that once was.

Though some may recognize and enjoy the downtown district, the stark contrast in the way people shop today reveals the profound impact of shopping malls. I believe that, despite their convenience, these malls have contributed more to the decline of downtown Kalamazoo's vibrancy and accessibility than they have provided in their intended benefits. And still, there is potential for revitalization, yet it seems overshadowed by the current shopping mall-dominated landscape.

Within this century, there have been many technological advances which have resulted in a drastically different society than that of a hundred years ago. Clearly, of the inventions of this century, the one that has made the most impact on world views and lifestyle is the television. However, the invention of television also gave society an easy way to waste time; one has only to turn it on to tune out reality.

Instead, television has become the escape route of the masses, a way for people to flee from the conflicts they experience in their culture, rather than confront them and try to understand them.

For centuries, millions of people were left dead or permanently maimed because of disease. Although this tragic reality still occurs, with increasing medical and technological advances since the middle of the century, many lives have been saved from the torment of disease. Perhaps the greatest invention and discovery is the polio vaccine, invented by Salk, which fundamentally changed the future and the lives of future generations. The effects of such a vaccine are countless and immeasurable when compared to any other 20th-century invention.

Why was it so great? The polio vaccine changed the population and acted as a foundation for further medical advances. For 20-year-olds, polio has never been a real issue; it is one of the many vaccines we received as children. For us, the new dreaded ailment is AIDS, which we have no cure for—a fear that lingered for some of our parents and grandparents.

The vaccine was first utilized in the middle of the century, coinciding with the Baby Boom. With this new vaccination, fewer children were dying, maimed, or born with disabilities, giving them a greater chance of having a healthy childhood. While it is debatable whether the vaccine contributed directly to the Baby Boom, the larger surviving group born during that era could have contributed to an increase in life expectancy.

Disease historically plays a role in population control. Periodic outbreaks would eventually balance an overpopulated world. The polio vaccine stopped death in its path. The process of vaccination also opened new doors, making previously impossible things possible. It seemed strange to inject the dead virus to protect against the virus itself, but it worked. Thanks to Dr. Salk, we are a little more protected than we would have been before, living in a world of uncertainty.

The invention of the airplane, in my opinion, has drastically changed the lives of many people. Air transportation allows people to travel from place to place more quickly and efficiently. Overseas travel has been drastically improved as well, as it now takes significantly less time to reach distant destinations than before. Without the airplane, a trip from the U.S. to Spain would've taken an extraordinary amount of time, perhaps a week. The invention of the airplane has also affected areas other than solely travel. Business, entertainment, and international relations have all been impacted by this revolutionary mode of transportation.

Travel times have been significantly shortened due to airplanes. For example, driving from Michigan to California takes about 30-35 hours, but flying the same distance takes approximately 3 hours. The business world has thrived because of airplanes, as significantly reduced travel times have made it easier for countries to collaborate. Additionally, business relations within a country have improved. Today, it is relatively easy for an American businessperson to establish business relations in any part of the world. This trend is evident in the increase in international business over recent decades.

Similarly, entertainment has grown with the invention of the airplane, facilitating the quick travel of entertainers—be they musicians, actors, or athletes—from one place to another. An example of this is Michael Jackson's concert in Madrid, which was made possible due to the airplane. Professional athletic teams benefit from reduced travel time, enabling them to play more games in various locations.

Finally, intercontinental relations have been positively and negatively influenced by airplanes. On the positive side, important diplomatic efforts such as "peace talks" between nations are made more feasible, as it would take significantly longer for someone like the President to reach their destination with ground transportation. Additionally, heads of state can more easily interact with other leaders and visit foreign countries using airplanes. Unfortunately, airplanes have also been used for negative purposes, such as in wars. For instance, Japan used airplanes to bomb Pearl Harbor, and the U.S. used airplanes to drop atomic bombs on Japan. Despite these downsides, the overall impact of airplanes on intercontinental relations is undeniably positive, as they facilitate quicker and more convenient communication between nations.

It is funny that we are writing on this subject because it was a topic of discussion in my home the other night. My father suggested the zip-lock bag, and I'm going to have to agree that that is an invention that I cannot live without! 

First of all, zip-lock bags are great for keeping things fresh. Sandwiches, crackers, cookies, cereal, and more do not get stale as quickly when they are stored in these bags, especially when kept without any air. In addition, food also stays fresh in the freezer. Essentially, almost anything can be stored in a zip-lock bag without getting freezer burn.

Another thing that zip-lock bags are good for is keeping certain odors in and out of the bag. I cannot even count the number of times that my father would pack a roast beef sandwich to bring to school for lunch. By the time lunch came around, I could already smell the sandwich before I even opened my locker. Finally, I asked him to put my sandwich in a zip-lock bag, and I never had a smelly locker again.

There are also times when foods tend to take on the smells of other foods to which they are near. One solution would be to put the odorous food in a bag, but if that cannot be done for some reason—for example, you are planning to serve it at a fancy dinner later—you can put the surrounding food in the bag to keep the smell out. A third solution would be to bag everything!

But, there are other uses for zip-lock bags. Where else can you place ice to hold on a swelling lip, without it melting and getting everything wet? And for traveling, these bags are even more useful. Too many times people have opened suitcases at the end of a long day, only to find shampoo all over their clothes—especially on their "dry-clean only" items. Gallon-size zip-lock bags solve this problem by allowing a person to fit a whole bottle of shampoo and a bottle of conditioner in a single bag.

By incorporating these transitions, the essay now flows more smoothly and effectively conveys the various uses and benefits of zip-lock bags.

One of the most important discoveries of the 20th Century would have to be AIDS.  This discovery of AIDS has changed how people think, live, and view mortality.  At first, AIDS was thought to be a predominantly homosexual disease.  Since there was little tolerance of homosexuality in the early 80's, no one really cared that gays would die.  Then it became known that IV drug users could also contract AIDS.  And once again no one really cared, simply because they thought AIDS would never effect them.  How wrong they were.
 Once children became infected with AIDS, society began to care.  It was inconceivable that a small child could die from such a horrific disease.  As the 80's came to a close there was a greater awareness of AIDS;  however, with the awareness also came discrimination.
	Ryan White, a twelve year old hemophiliac, was the first person to have his disease widely publicized.  Everyone was in a panic that their children would get AIDS simply from being around Ryan.  Thus began the campaign to educate the public on how one contracts AIDS.  It was seen everywhere (and still is)- on t.v., magazines, radio, & in the schools.  Parents are still fighting the distribution of condoms in schools  and they want their children to learn abstinence and not sex education.  Abstinence is the only safe way to prevent AIDS, but society must be realistic.  Children are becoming sexually active at the age of eleven.  How likely is it that an eleven year old is going to go to a pharmacy & buy condoms?  Most people are more careful about who they sleep with, and AIDS has become less of a taboo subject & more of an accepted reality.
	Due to the discovery of AIDS people are aware that if they are promiscuous & do not practice safe sex, they could die.  Society has become aware of its mortality, and in some cases, has banded together to try to find a cure for AIDS.  Right now, more important than a cure, is the acceptance of AIDS victims & the education of the public. One of the most important discoveries of the 20th Century was AIDS. This discovery has profoundly changed how people think, live, and view mortality. Initially, AIDS was thought to be a predominantly homosexual disease. Since there was little tolerance of homosexuality in the early 1980s, society largely ignored the deaths among gay communities. However, the understanding of AIDS expanded when it became known that IV drug users could also contract the disease. Once again, society showed indifference, under the false assumption that AIDS would never affect them. How wrong they were.

When children began to become infected with AIDS, society's concern grew. The idea of a small child dying from such a horrific disease was inconceivable. As the 1980s came to a close, there was a greater awareness of AIDS, but with it came increased discrimination.

Ryan White, a twelve-year-old hemophiliac, became the first person to have his disease widely publicized. Everyone feared that their children might get AIDS simply from being around Ryan. This panic launched a campaign to educate the public about how AIDS is contracted. The message was everywhere—on television, magazines, radio, and in schools. Despite these efforts, parents continue to fight against the distribution of condoms in schools and strongly advocate for abstinence education. While abstinence is presented as the only safe way to prevent AIDS, society must grapple with the reality that many children are becoming sexually active at an early age, making it difficult for them to access condoms.

Due to the discovery of AIDS, people have become more aware of the risks associated with promiscuity and unsafe sex. Society has become more conscious of its mortality, and while a cure remains a crucial goal, there is also an urgent need to accept AIDS victims and to educate the public. Magic Johnson’s high-profile diagnosis brought significant attention to the epidemic, highlighting the importance of acceptance and respect for AIDS victims. Ultimately, regardless of whether a cure is found, the dignity and rights of those affected by AIDS must be upheld.

The invention of the television in the 0th Century has had one of the most profound effects on people's lives, particularly during the 1950s in America, a period marked by a cultural revolution. The era of Populuxe instigated a "must-have" ideology, with the television becoming the most significant "must-have." The presence of television has introduced several crucial trends in our culture: the mass culturization of various groups, the commercialization of our lifestyles, and the rapid dissemination of information.

Gathered around the television, the American family learned the "ideal" way of life. However, the picture of perfection was uniform across all homes. Everyone received the same information, saw the same families like The Cleavers and The Andersons, and learned how to behave. Mothers were depicted as beautiful, fathers as wise, and children had cute, harmless problems. This omniscient portrayal gave even farmers in Iowa an idea of what a family in New York might look like, contributing to the mass culturalization of the United States. The examples on television, though often exaggerated, provided people with glimpses into different lifestyles, making the "strange" somewhat familiar.

Another effect of the television on people's lives is the commercialization of our daily routines. Advertisements, initially designed to inform people of their purchasing options, have evolved into an art form. Fifteen-second blocks of time are sold for millions of dollars, compelling the American population to laugh, cry, and frequently purchase products.

Finally, the advent of television marked a significant increase in the amount of information citizens received, along with the speed at which that information was delivered. Unlike a hundred years ago, when different sections of the country were isolated by the time it took to mail a letter or print a newspaper story, we now receive news within seconds, as demonstrated by real-time broadcasts like the Challenger explosion coverage.

In conclusion, the television revolutionized communication, culture, and commerce in America, bringing people closer together while shaping their perceptions and experiences in profound ways.

They cried, they cheered. Their faces expressed joy, triumph, pride, and perplexity. The world watched in anticipation—mesmerized by the images of TV, expecting something new at every moment and not wanting to miss it. I remember that day it was the only topic of conversation at school: "Have you heard?," "I can't believe it!," "After all this time!," "I never thought it would happen." We all felt like we were living one of those historic moments you read about in a history book and were proud to be a part of it—November 9, 1989, the day that the Wall fell in Berlin.

Within a few weeks, the excitement had died down and people had turned their attention to more recent news. However, for me, this had been the start. It marked the beginning of what our now-President Bush refers to as "our" winning of the Cold War. This event gave the people of the Eastern Bloc countries the hope that their efforts were not in vain.

For 40 years, the people had suffered under a communist regime that had not allowed them to express themselves freely or leave their homelands in search of a new life. Many had tried to escape. Some had been executed. I had a classmate whose father had escaped from Hungary. He had left his family and friends, his whole life, and set out for Western Europe with little money. I had asked him once if he hadn't been scared, scared of what he would find once he left. He told me that nothing could compare to the way he had been forced to live his life there. Even though I had lost touch with this classmate, his father's words were with me as I watched the events unfold in Germany.

Bolstered by the Germans' success, the people of Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, and Romania rose against communist regimes as well. Now, three years later, communism as we once knew it no longer exists. Whether the people are happier or not, I cannot say. However, they will have at least seen the "other side."

There has been a literal explosion of inventions during the twentieth century, ranging from the garbage disposal to the atomic bomb. Some inventions were created to make life easier, others to make life longer, and all were developed for the purpose of advancing civilization. While each invention has affected our lives in one way or another, some stand out as more significantly changing our mode of living. The small town store owner can watch her son in his Olympic race as it's happening without spending thousands to travel to see him in person. The examples are endless.

An invention of the 20th century that I think has significantly changed people's lives is television.  TV allows the instantaneous communication of ideas, images, news, etc.   Now, if something is happening in any part of the world- from across town all the way to Beijing -- every person in the world can watch this event as it is happening.  While previously people had to wait days, or even weeks for news (which consisted of second-or third-hand accounts, which always involved much interpretation & distortion) now they can see it happening, for themselves, as it is happening, this allows them to make their own, informed judgment about the event; and if a reaction is necessary- such as the gathering of opposition to a certain law -- it can be made immediately, while the emotions are still strong, and before the action is finalized.  As well, the fact that so many people (especially in the US) have television sets means that everybody (well, at least everybody who watches) receives the same inflow of information & ideas.  So, for example, people in Spain can be informed about how people in California or Japan speak & act, this allows people from different cultures to come together and discuss ideas.
	 In my opinion, this is one part of the process of making the world a "smaller", more unified place, or a "global village" as one journalist has called this world of the Information Age.
	Not only the news, but also entertainment is an important practical function of television, through television entertainment, as through literature & drama, people learn different messages about life.  They can see various actions acted out to their ends, and understand the consequences of these actions, without having to perform the same actions and experience the consequences for themselves.  Unfortunately these TV shows are not always accurate portrayals of real life and have a tendency to glorify violence, as well as making life seem the good guy always wins, and always lives thru dangerous situations.  However, this sense of reality is not so distorted, and so hidden that people are going around acting like Superman.  As long as one has a well-developed sense of reality, TV can be an excellent tool for understanding the world we live in.
<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
An invention of the 20th century that I think has significantly changed people's lives is television. TV allows the instantaneous communication of ideas, images, and news. Now, if something is happening in any part of the world—from across town to Beijing—every person can watch this event as it is happening. Unlike the past, when people had to wait days or even weeks for news (which consisted of second- or third-hand accounts that often involved much interpretation and distortion), TV viewers can see events unfold live, forming their own informed judgments about them. If a reaction is necessary, such as gathering opposition to a certain law, it can be initiated immediately while emotions are still strong, preventing the finalization of action.

Moreover, as television is widely accessible, especially in the US, people receive the same inflow of information and ideas. For instance, people in Spain can see firsthand how people in California or Japan speak and act, fostering intercultural dialogue and understanding.

This phenomenon contributes to making the world a "smaller," more unified place, or a "global village," as one journalist has termed it in the Information Age.

Not only does television serve as a vital news source, but it also plays a crucial role in entertainment. Through TV entertainment, people learn different messages about life, understanding various actions and their consequences without having to experience them firsthand. However, it's worth noting that TV shows often portray an oversimplified sense of reality, sometimes glamorizing violence and presenting an unrealistic notion that the good guy always wins and survives dangerous situations. Despite these exaggerations, TV can still be an excellent tool for understanding the world, provided viewers maintain a well-developed sense of reality.

Overall, television has profoundly impacted how we perceive and respond to the world, making it a significant 20th-century invention that has shaped our modern lives.

Gender role stereotyping is prominent in American culture, revolving around the traditionalists' view that men should dominate the world of commerce while women are expected to rear children and order home life. Over the years, the question of whether American culture should maintain distinct gender identities has risen. I have come to the conclusion that, for psychological, sociological, and economic reasons, the culture should maintain gender identities, but only to a certain extent.

Traditionally, the stereotyped male image depicts a man as strong, courageous, self-reliant, and the backbone of the family. Conversely, a woman is often portrayed as gentle, emotional, sensitive, loving, and whose future plans revolve around her husband and children. These stereotyped images, while they may appear pleasant to some, are not always realistic. For instance, a man is not always the strong backbone of the family; the successful businesswoman or single mother may, in fact, be the backbone, providing both emotional and financial support.

Having these typical images can be advantageous in creating role models for growing boys, who learn to be strong and know how to provide moral and financial support for their families. However, this places a great deal of pressure on men. As they aspire to get through college, secure the best jobs with good salaries, they may become so preoccupied with their careers and success that they neglect their families. This is clearly the case in Warren Farrell's book "Why men are the way they are," in which Ralph admits that his hard work to provide for his family caused him to lose touch with them.

Another disadvantage of having an ideal male image is its impact on sensitivity in men. According to William Masters, a social scientist, school-age boys are generally expected to show masculinity by demonstrating physical competence and bravery and are criticized for showing fear or emotions. When boys mistakenly display sensitivity, they are ridiculed and become the primary concern of psychiatrists, who are puzzled by their behavior. This expectation creates an additional layer of difficulty for male children as they navigate their formative years.

In conclusion, while maintaining gender identities can have its benefits, it is essential to recognize the unrealistic nature of these stereotypes and strive for a more balanced and true-to-life portrayal of both men and women.

As humans, we belong to the Phylum Chordata, never deviating from our structure until we are in the Genus Homo sapiens. Then we sort ourselves into subclasses or ethnicities, such as black, white, rich, poor, male, or female, often through coercion. This coercion, whether it began as a struggle for dominance between ethnicities or not, has invoked stereotypes of each, leading to individuals expecting traditional outcomes and pre-sought expectations. Our history has broadcasted the man as being the dominant figure in a world built for both. In Betty Friedan's "The Problem That Has No Name" and "Ralph's Story" by Warren Farrell, the focus is not on superiority, but on the choices individuals are expected to make.

In "Ralph's Story," Ralph goes through a self-awareness process, realizing that even though he had choices in his life, he felt he had no true choice. With Ralph's preconceived notion of what would benefit his family (monetarily), he felt compelled to drop baseball for college. When Ralph had to choose between becoming a social work lawyer or a corporate business lawyer, he had no real choice; he felt he had to become a business lawyer to prove himself in the legal world. Ralph never saw the "big picture, just the means to get there" (568). Similarly, in "The Problem That Has No Name," the women interviewed had chosen to have several children and stay at home to cook and clean, not because that was their ideal choice, but because it was the expected norm for women, and they chose to conform to the standard without deviation. These choices led to a massing guilt and subconscious resentment for what they perceived as their imposed lives.

The consequences of their decisions were always deeply nested within the individuals. In my experiences, I have grown up in an age where a career man and career woman have become necessities in a household. However, members of my family and other generations are new to this expectation, highlighting how these traditional roles have influenced and constrained choices over time.

Sometimes when people suffer from extreme illnesses they look for other options as an easy way out. Many of the cases concerning euthanasia in the past few years have been performed or assisted by a doctor known as Dr. Kevorkian. There has been much controversy over assisted suicides, especially those performed with the assistance of a doctor. There are several different forms of euthanasia. One form of euthanasia is when a person's life is in a permanently unconscious state, sometimes referred to as a "vegetable." When a person is in this state, if they do not have a living will stating their wishes, the family has the right to make the decision concerning whether the patient should remain on life support or not after they have consulted with the physician concerning the matter. There are very few legal objections to this form of euthanasia. It is widely practiced in hospitals all over America. Many people leave in their will expressed wishes to not be kept alive on life support systems. When the physician determines that there is no chance of a patient's
recovery, it is their duty to carry out the patient's wishes and disconnect life support. Another type of euthanasia is when a patient requests that the doctor provide no more treatment. The patient declining treatment normally remains alive for a period and thereby receives some opportunity to change one's mind or to eliminate any mistake on the physicians part in comprehending the patient's wishes. Sometimes when people suffer from extreme illnesses, they look for other options as an easy way out. When the pain becomes unbearable and the medication stops working, some people would rather die than to continue to live in pain. Euthanasia is a "mercy killing" meant to alleviate extreme suffering. Many of the cases concerning euthanasia in recent years have involved Dr. Kevorkian. There has been much controversy over assisted suicides, especially those performed with the assistance of a doctor. Should euthanasia be legalized to allow doctors to assist in suicides of terminally ill patients, or should they be bound by their Hippocratic Oath?

There are several different forms of euthanasia. One form is when a person's life is in a permanently unconscious state, sometimes referred to as a "vegetable." When a person is in this state, if they do not have a living will stating their wishes, the family has the right to decide whether the patient should remain on life support or not after consulting with the physician. There are very few legal objections to this form of euthanasia, as it is widely practiced in hospitals across America. Many people leave in their wills expressed wishes to not be kept alive on life support systems. When a physician determines that there is no chance of a patient's recovery, it is their duty to carry out the patient's wishes and disconnect life support.

Another type of euthanasia is when a patient requests that the doctor provide no more treatment. If medical conduct to end the patient's life is prohibited, the patient is allowed maximum opportunity to change their mind and demand treatment. This allows the patient to stay alive for a period, thereby giving them a chance to reconsider their decision or to correct any potential misunderstandings on the physician's part.

A third type of euthanasia is self-inflicted, where the individual ends their own life. This method also raises significant ethical and legal questions. Overall, the debate on euthanasia focuses on whether it should be legalized to allow doctors to assist in suicides of terminally ill patients, or if doctors should adhere strictly to their Hippocratic Oath.

Lowering the drinking age would gradually change society and encourage a more mature management of alcohol.

Lowering the drinking age would decrease the amount of crime among youths. Many youths break the law every time they attempt to buy or consume alcohol. Democrats in the White House seem to think that more education and training for jobs within a two-year time limit is the key. Republicans in Congress, on the other hand, seem to think perhaps shorter time limits and cuts in spending on some welfare programs would be the answer (Silverstein 13-15). However, the heatedly argued welfare issue can be solved by combining the ideas of both parties. The welfare program would be successful if it changed to include a time limit, required training programs, less government funding for certain welfare programs, and abolishing the law that states that women should get more money for having more children.

Both parties agree on having time limits and training programs so that welfare recipients can find jobs (Economist 33). It is important for recipients to work for their welfare check so that they do not become dependent on the system. After all, the purpose of welfare should be to help recipients in a tough time, not support them for the rest of their life (Silverstein 13). Training programs should be an essential part of the welfare program. "Fourteen million people survive off welfare payments," and by making recipients participate in well-designed welfare-to-work programs or training programs, long-term welfare dependency can be reduced (Economist 33). These training programs would help most women who have been on welfare for years. 

These women have so little work experience that they have to rehearse with social workers to remember to say, "good-bye," and "thank you" at the end of an interview (Whitman 30). A major uproar has arisen in the United States and other countries about saving the environment for future generations to enjoy. There are many possible ways for this to be achieved, one of which being recycling. Recycling would include not just the standard aluminum cans and paper bags but also plastic, steel, glass, refrigerators, batteries, and so on. In order for the world to be one that our children and grandchildren can benefit from, recycling needs to become commonplace uniformly. Before every landfill and dump site is exhausted, the human population needs to educate themselves on the few, simple steps that can be taken to maximize the remaining room for recyclable materials.

"Most plastic can be recycled and collection for plastics is rapidly increasing," the Recycler's Bill of Rights states (1). This includes but is not limited to; plastic bags, containers, cups, toys, and hangers. All plastic products have recycling codes somewhere on them, often on the bottom, since mixing plastics can ruin the melt. Most types of plastic grocery bags can be mixed together. Even bags containing bread, pasta, and marshmallows can be recycled together. Many plastic products such as compact discs, video tapes, and computer discs are made from mixed materials that can't be recycled unless first disassembled (Recycler's 1). Corporations that produce grocery bags are starting to realize the importance of being environmentally friendly. For example, The Superbag Corporation produces their bags with a significant amount of recycled material. The finished product is completely recyclable and can be used in a number of ways (Superbag 1). Plastic bags are much better for the environment than paper bags because their production is better for the natural resources.

The brown paper bags used in some supermarkets are made from virgin paper, without contributions from recycled materials. Paper making pollutes water, releases dioxin, contributes to acid rain, and costs trees. Heretically, some uses of virgin paper can be more damaging to wildlife than plastic substitutes. If consumers support virgin paper bags over plastic bags, they are implicitly supporting higher levels of pollution (Superbag 1).

Such views by pro-life advocates can make their entire argument appear unrealistic about the necessity of abortion.

Another common argument used by anti-abortionists is known as the Slippery Nazi Slope. They claim that abortion is a form of genocide, equating a society that accepts abortion with the Nazis' actions in killing the Jews. While this may sound like a strong argument initially, it is not substantial upon closer examination. The true meaning of genocide is the systematic extermination or destruction of a political, racial, or cultural group, which does not equate to the practice of abortion.

By examining these arguments, one can better understand the complexity of the abortion debate and the importance of maintaining a nuanced and informed discussion.

Over the past few years, one question that has repeatedly surfaced in the courts is whether women should be allowed to attend the Citadel. There are many objections to this idea, but equally strong are the arguments supporting it.

Whenever the question arises about why women shouldn't be admitted, two points are consistently highlighted. Firstly, it has traditionally been an all-male institution, and some believe women couldn't handle its demands. The purpose of this passage is not to convince you to legalize marijuana or to more strictly enforce Marijuana laws. Rather, it's purpose is to inform you on all the facts about Marijuana. There is nothing wrong with choosing to make Marijuana illegal, as long as you have justifiable reasons for doing so.

The first thing to look at when deciding about a stance on Marijuana is its history in the United States. Marijuana became federally illegal in 1937, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) began prescribing THC pills in 1980 to control nausea in cancer patients. Who has the authority to prohibit the reading and studying of certain texts? Is it the school boards of education, parents within various school districts, or censorship groups like the Citizens for Excellence in Education (CEE)? Nashua Board of Education, the board was unable to provide a legitimate reason for its removal, and thus, the magazine returned to the shelves of the school library.

The American Heritage dictionary defines culture as the transmission of culture is a very important aspect of ethnic American literature. Many ethnic American writers emphasize this transmission from generation to generation, perhaps to uphold the customs and traditions of their native country. Many of the novels we have read this semester illustrate this aspect of transmitting culture. For example, the predominant novel, Amy Tan's The Joy Luck Club, showcases the mothers' efforts to hold on to the old ways of China and raise their daughters "the Chinese way." They tell their daughters stories of China and, in essence, try to tell them about their heritage, where they came from, who they are, and why they act the way they do on certain issues. Despite this, the daughters, having been Americanized, find it challenging to grasp these stories. Ultimately, by the end of the novel, the daughters understand their foreign mothers and accept their traditions, opening the doors for the transmission of culture. Consequently, Amy Tan's novel becomes a significant representation of this important aspect of ethnic literature.

Similarly, Walker's The Color Purple demonstrates the transmission of culture. In this novel, Celie's sister Nettie departs for Africa as a missionary and attempts to transmit African-American culture to the natives. On a different note, Mama Elena in Esquivel's Like Water for Chocolate endeavors to transmit culture to Tita and her other daughters. Though she fails with Tita and Gertrudes, she eventually manages to influence Rosaura with traditional values.

Through these narratives, the novels vividly illustrate the challenges and successes of cultural transmission, thereby highlighting their place within ethnic American literature.

"Candide" is a parody on the guidelines of Neoclassicism.

Additionally, Candide could be labeled as anti-war for its satirical take on the ongoing conflict between the Avars and Bulgars. The book could also be seen as a satire, farce, or picaresque novel. However, Candide is best described as a parody because of Voltaire's targeted critique of the French Academy's rules, particularly his denial of verisimilitude subject matter on sex and violence, along with his attacks on religion and politics.

Verisimilitude, or truth to lifeness, is a principle that the French Academy upholds, stating that a story should occur at one place, at one time, and with one action. Voltaire cleverly discards this idea, writing in his own creative manner. The plot begins at the castle of Baron Thunder-ten-Tronckh. As if mocking the single-action rule, Voltaire sails the character Candide to Lisbon. After this trip, Candide travels to Paraguay, where he has a troubling encounter with the Oreillons. As time passes, Candide and his servant journey to an unexpected destination, Eldorado, a utopian society. Following this, Candide bribes an officer to take him to England. In England, he witnesses the brutal execution of an admiral, causing him to quickly depart for Venice, Italy. After many adventures, Candide ultimately finds his love in Constantinople, where he marries her without her brother's consent.

The Neoclassic Age emerged in France during the reign of Louis XIV. In 1636, the French Academy established a set of rules it saw as an appropriate guideline to literature. These rules included the use of verisimilitude, propriety on stage, and proper character management. Voltaire's "Candide" can be appropriately labeled as a parody of the neoclassical rules of propriety. Through repeated use of sex and violence, Voltaire ridicules the French Academy's teachings.

Voltaire's attack on sex in "Candide" includes homosexuality, consent, and rape. Subtle hints to the reader reveal Cunegonde's brother's homosexuality. He "never tired of embracing Candide" and was overjoyed to be reunited with him. The Jesuit also admits to taking a bath with another young man, not realizing it was a same-sex relationship. As Candide grows, he encounters several instances of consent. While Candide is living at the Baron's castle as a youth, Cunegonde sees Pangloss giving the chambermaid lessons in "experimental physics," which she then tries to teach Candide behind a screen. In later travels, Candide sees two young ladies running "nimbly" while two monkeys follow closely. Candide discovers that these monkeys are the young ladies' lovers. When Candide is on his way to find Cunegonde, the lady of the house at Faubourg Saint Honoré willingly "gives herself to him" on the first night they met. When Candide is first reunited with Pangloss, and is told that Cunegonde is dead, Pangloss reveals that Cunegonde was "as much as a person can be." Voltaire's portrayal of these relationships and events directly undermines the neoclassical emphasis on proper character management and societal propriety. By doing so, he challenges the audience to reconsider the values placed upon propriety and morality in literature and society.

Traffic jams are becoming larger and more frequent. Trains are never on time. Everybody always has a complaint about some part of the transport system in the United Kingdom. What is wrong, and what can we do about it?
The amount of criticism aimed at the British rail network increases daily, and not without reason. Much of the rolling stock is old, slow, noisy and uncomfortable. Passengers whose life seems to revolve around annoying others - listening to not-quite-personal stereos, smoking in no smoking sections, putting bags on seat - are a common sight on trains. All this makes the train less appealling to the general public, and, in particular, the commuter.
Another problem is that of understaffing, both on trains and at stations. This leads to an increase in fare dodging, which is now quite possible unintentionally - with ticket offices closed at both ends of the journey, and no guard, who are you supposed to pay?
All this leads to trains being unprofitable, except on a few major commuter routes. Many things have been tried to reverse this, but to no avail. Closing small lines which regularly lose money may seem sensible but leads to less people getting trains in general - after all if you have to drive twenty miles to the nearest station, you might as well just drive to wherever you are going. Increasing or decreasing prices could be tried, but as trains are more expensive than cars for most journeys anyway, this would have little effect. 
The only way to make profits is to get more people on trains, and this requires an improvement in services. This would initially cost a lot, and unfortunately sufficient funding is never available. 
As more and more people use cars, traffic in city centres during rush ours comes to a near standstill. More cars arrive, get stuck in jams, and spread the congestion further and further out of the city, until motorways and bypasses become blocked.
The problem is obvious - there are too many cars on Britain's roads. There are two ways around the problem - reduce the number of cars, or build more roads.
In cities, where all traffic jams start, there is no room for more roads - every square yard is already in use. The only place more roads can be built is outside cities, building more and wider motorways.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Traffic jams are becoming larger and more frequent, and trains are seldom on time. Everybody always has a complaint about some part of the transport system in the United Kingdom, but why is this the case, and what can we do about it? 

The amount of criticism aimed at the British rail network increases daily, and not without reason. Much of the rolling stock is old, slow, noisy, and uncomfortable, making trains less appealing to the general public, particularly commuters. More disturbing, however, is the issue of understaffing both on trains and at stations, leading to increased fare dodging and further decline in service quality.

All of these problems lead to trains being unprofitable, except on a few major commuter routes. Multiple attempts to reverse this trend have been made but to no avail. Closing small lines that regularly lose money seems sensible, but it results in fewer people using trains, as driving to stations that are far away from their destination might not be practical. Similarly, adjusting prices would likely have little impact, given that trains are already more expensive than cars for most journeys.

To make trains profitable, services need to be improved, requiring substantial investment—an unfortunately frequent but still unattainable goal. Meanwhile, as the number of cars on Britain's roads continues to grow, city center traffic becomes nearly impossible to navigate during rush hours. Cars get stuck in traffic jams, spreading congestion well beyond the city, until even motorways and bypasses become overwhelmed.

The problem is evident—there are too many cars on Britain's roads. However, the solution is not as simple as constructing more roads. In cities where all traffic jams start, space for additional roads is already at a premium, with every square yard in use.

Therefore, the only viable solution seems to be to reduce the number of cars on Britain's roads. This would be a monumental challenge, but it may be necessary for a long-term solution to the transportation woes plaguing the United Kingdom.

The problems facing road transport are numerous with potentially severe penalties. Today, the vast amount of UK families own a car. It is, no doubt, a fast way of commuting to and from destinations with little stress on the body; however, traffic congestion is becoming a major concern in any city or town. It has even been attempted to build more roads for the cars to travel on, but it seems that the number of cars increases on the road, making the problem the same as it was before. Lancaster is a very good example of a failed one-way system. It is becoming more apparent that walking is faster at peak times of the day (i.e., 08:00 and 17:00). As a result, a bypass was introduced, but it is used by very few cars, amounting to another failure.

In addition to traffic congestion, pollution is another significant issue. All of these problems can be linked to congestion and the number of cars on the road. To attempt to lessen this number, I have a number of solutions:
1. Implement Park and Ride systems, where cars are parked outside of town and riders can catch a free or cheap bus into town.
2. Improve public transport by offering cheaper fares and creating a cleaner, more pleasant environment to encourage people to leave their cars at home.

The number of cars in the United Kingdom has greatly increased since the mass motorway building schemes in the 1970's. This has meant that whereas people used to walk or catch a bus to work they now drive into work. This is especially true in the major cities such as London and Birmingham and this can be seen in the horrific traffic problems which plague these cities. When faced with large traffic jams there is the tendancy to find shortcuts and this can lead to heavy traffic through rural villages or residential areas. The number of heavy goods vehicles on the road networks has also increased and frequent lorry traffic can damage roads not built for this purpose quickly. They also restrict the flow of traffic on motorways especially when in large numbers.
The rail transport in the United Kingdom also has many problems. One of these is the increasing number of people who prefer to drive rather than catch a train. This unpopularity has come about especially over shorter distances due to the delays and strike problems etc.
The privatisation and sell off of many of the more profitable networks such as the South East has lead to a profit-base operation meaning fewer trains, higher fares and the closure of many of the smaller stations.
Another problem is the unwillingness of industry to transport goods by train often due to the limited rail network and the cost compared to transport by HGV's.
The opening of the Eurotunnel, connecting the UK network to the rest of Europe, it is hoped, will stimulate the rail industry but a number of problems and Eurotunnel's increasing debt has done little to convince the general public.
There are many possible solutions to the problems I have identified many of which would compliment each other. Firstly the problem of traffic congestion of our roads could be mainly tackled in two ways.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The number of cars in the United Kingdom has greatly increased since the mass motorway building schemes in the 1970s, putting increasing stress on our road network, especially along major commercial routes such as Birmingham to London, and in town centres where the streets and roads were not designed for such a large number of cars. This large number of cars is causing congestion and general "wear and tear" of our roads.

The easy access to cars has enabled people to move out of the polluted, "grey" cities and into out-of-town villages where they can commute. This has meant that whereas people used to walk or catch a bus to work, they now drive into work. This trend is especially notable in the major cities such as London and Birmingham, leading to the horrific traffic problems that plague these cities. When faced with large traffic jams, there is a tendency to find shortcuts, which can lead to heavy traffic through rural villages or residential areas. The number of heavy goods vehicles on the road networks has also increased, and frequent lorry traffic can damage roads not built for this purpose quickly. These vehicles also restrict the flow of traffic on motorways, especially when in large numbers.

Rail transport in the United Kingdom also has many problems. One of these is the increasing number of people who prefer to drive rather than catch a train. This unpopularity has come about especially over shorter distances due to the delays and strike problems, etc. The privatisation and sell-off of many of the more profitable networks, such as the South East, has led to a profit-base operation, meaning fewer trains, higher fares, and the closure of many of the smaller stations. Another problem is the unwillingness of industry to transport goods by train, often due to the limited rail network and the higher costs compared to transport by HGVs.

The opening of the Eurotunnel, connecting the UK network to the rest of Europe, was hoped to stimulate the rail industry. However, problems and the increasing debt of Eurotunnel have done little to convince the general public of its benefits.

There are many possible solutions to the problems I have identified, many of which would compliment each other. Firstly, tackling traffic congestion on our roads could be accomplished in two ways: by implementing strict traffic management measures and encouraging the use of alternative modes of transport.

British transport has always been either a source of national pride of concern. Nowadays we hear so much about the indaquacies of our transport system. Public transport is underfunded; the roads are croweded and almost unbearable near cities + even smaller towns nowadays.

OK so this is the solitary age of the 90's, + people don't want to trust anyone or anything else but the greater reason is the abysmal public transport we have at this time. Over priced, shoddy surroundings, poor service and more often than not, late. If public transport was just a little bit more accomadating than it is then many people would consider using it rather than their own private 'tank'.
A root cause for these problems is the endless privatisation of anything and everything by this government. They feed endless diatribes onto the people who are too lethargic to care. They say that privatisation will lead to better service and prices. However the advent of many, separate profit making companies running the roads and track cant be good for the consumer in the long term. The government is effectively handing out monopolies to companies just to try and balance their short term interests.
Also the means of transportation hasn't changed greatly in the past 10 years whilst the volume of traffic has increased threefold in the case of the roadsystem. Obviously more roads are needed. However there is a limit. Nobody wants a concrete jungle for a country. There is though an optimum balance which I believe has not yet been reached. It is when bypasses of bypasses are being built that the country will reach saturation levels. To be fair the authority's are in a no win situation here. If they don't build more roads then people complain about the density of traffic and if they do then rabid enviromentalists spring out form their undergrouth and start chaining themselves to trees! result:
British transport, once a source of national pride, has become a cause for concern. Today's headlines frequently discuss the inadequacies of our transport system. Public transport is underfunded, while roads are crowded and almost unbearable near cities and even smaller towns.

If you ever find yourself in a traffic queue, take a moment to observe the occupants of cars. Over three-quarters of them are alone. This suggests a broader trend: the solitary age of the 90s is not just about a lack of trust, but also a result of the abysmal public transport available today. Over-priced, shoddy surroundings, poor service, and often late arrivals make public transport less appealing than privately owned vehicles.

A root cause of these issues is the endless privatization of various sectors by the government. They feed endless diatribes onto people too lethargic to care. They claim privatization will lead to better services and prices. However, the rise of many, separate profit-making companies operating the roads and tracks can't be good for consumers in the long term. The government is effectively handing out monopolies to companies to balance their short-term interests.

Additionally, transportation infrastructure has not changed much in the past decade, even though the volume of traffic has increased threefold in the road system. Clearly, more roads are needed. However, there's a limit. A concrete jungle is not the ideal for a country. The optimal balance has yet to be reached. This balance will be achieved when bypass after bypasses are built and the country reaches saturation levels.

However, authorities are in a no-win situation. If they don't build more roads, people will complain about traffic density. If they do, environmentalists will emerge from the underground and chain themselves to trees, as seen in the case of the planned Newbury bypass, now behind schedule due to environmentalist opposition. Even the most ardent environmentalists would acknowledge the necessity of something being done on this road stretch.
