It cannot help but be noticed that Britain's roads are becoming increasingly unsavoury places. Congestion is a severe problem, particularly in urban areas, where it is very difficult - almost impossible in fact -to create new road systems to cope with the taffic. A journey into Lancaster, for example, may only take ten minutes when the roads are quiet, but can take three-quarters of an hour during the 'rush-hour'. Congestion is certainly not a problem that will go away; the number of cars on Britain's roads is increasing constantly. The M25 has already been dubbed 'the biggest car-park in Europe', and if current trends continue, the number of cars using it will double by 2030.
A huge amount of pollution is chewed out by all those cars, contributing to global warming, acid rain and smog in cities. Although catalytic converters are now compulsory on new cars, fumes in cities have become so bad that scientists have linked them to a marked increase in the number of asthma sufferers. The emissions from diesel vehicles - cars, buses and lorries - are particularly harmful (just watch a bus start its engine, and observe the huge black cloud that belches forth from its exhaust pipe), and yet there is no control on these vehicles' exhaust.
Hundreds of people are killed on the roads every year, and as cars become faster and taffic denser, the number of accidents will surely increase. Cars are also an extremely inefficient way of transporting people - large amounts of energy are used, and very often the car is only carrying one person. The number of lorries around is increasing, as more and more freight is carried by road (as opposed to sea or rail), due to the influence exerted by the road-haulage lobby on the government. Lorries create more noise and pollution than cars, and are much more damaging to the roads they travel on.
Now that rail privatisation has gone ahead, many people are likely to lose faith in trains, due to the percieved inefficiency of the operators (for example the time-table book full of errors or the recent survey in Which? magazine about overcharging). Fares are likely to increase, and many rural lines that used to be subsidised by the government face closure. Very little freight is transposed by rail these days, so the railways have lost income due to this.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Britain's roads are increasingly becoming unsavory places due to severe congestion, particularly in urban areas. Creating new road systems to cope with the traffic is almost impossible. A journey into Lancaster, for example, can take ten minutes when the roads are quiet, but can extend to three-quarters of an hour during the 'rush-hour.' Congestion is a persistent problem, and with the number of cars on Britain's roads constantly increasing, it's unlikely to go away. The M25, dubbed 'the biggest car-park in Europe,' could see its traffic double by 2030 if current trends continue.

A significant amount of pollution is emitted by the countless cars on our roads, contributing to global warming, acid rain, and smog in cities. While catalytic converters are now mandatory on new cars, city air quality remains poor, with scientists linking it to a marked increase in asthma sufferers. Emissions from diesel vehicles, including cars, buses, and lorries, are particularly harmful, as seen when observing a bus's exhaust. Alarmingly, there is no regulation on the emissions from these vehicles.

Each year, hundreds of people are killed on the roads, and as car speeds increase and traffic becomes denser, the number of accidents is sure to rise. Moreover, cars are an inefficient mode of transportation, especially when large amounts of energy are consumed, and they often carry just one person. The number of lorries is growing, as more freight is transported by road instead of by sea or rail, influenced by the road-haulage lobby. Lorries produce more noise and pollution and cause more damage to the roads they travel on than cars.

With rail privatisation, many people may lose faith in trains due to perceived inefficiencies of the operators, such as frequent timetable errors and overcharging, as noted in recent surveys by Which? magazine. Fares are expected to rise, and many rural lines previously subsidised by the government may face closure. Additionally, since very little freight is transposed by rail, the railways have lost significant income. Consequently, the future of rail transport seems uncertain, adding another layer of complexity to the already critical road congestion and pollution problems.

The United Kingdom is a small island and with a population of around 55 million is very overpopulated. Britain now has the most cars per mile of road anywhere in the world and modern traffic policies are not tackling these problems. In short a somewhat more radical, and unpopular, policy is required.

If we are to alleviate the roads in Britain them we must encourage rail travel in Britain and we should be opening new lines not closing old ones. Perhaps the privatisation of British Rail will produce a more competitive service but I fear that it will will result in the closure of smaller less profitable lines and only a better service on the main routes. Why is British rail so unreliable? Most of the world besides Britain seems to run a reliable service even developing countries. Few efforts have been made to make the fares cheaper and a more desirable form of family travel, with the Family railcard really being a non-starter.
Until the rail service improves people will continue to use the ever increasingly clogged up roads. Simply widening and building new roads is not a solution as the number of cars on the roads simply increases to "fill in the gaps". With the Newbury bypass work now being stopped for 3 days running I can sympathise with the protestors. We are simply running out of room to build new roads.
One of the main side effects of road travel in particular is pollution. Acid rain, asthma and many other problems are rife and soon the fuels for these cars will be running out. Gas buses and gars is really only a short term solution and a renewable source must be found. Solutions for these problems in Britain have been fairly unimaginative and unsuccessful.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The United Kingdom is a small island with a population of around 55 million, making it quite overpopulated. Its inadequate and expensive public transport system is contributing to the issue, as it forces more and more cars onto the road. As a result, Britain now has the highest number of cars per mile of road in the world, and modern traffic policies have not effectively addressed these problems. In short, a somewhat more radical and unpopular policy is required.

British rail is notoriously slow, late, and expensive, and the hype of rail travel and steam trains is long since gone with many old tracks being dismantled. To alleviate the congestion on British roads, we must encourage rail travel and consider opening new lines rather than closing old ones. While the privatisation of British Rail may produce a more competitive service, it could also result in the closure of smaller, less profitable lines, leaving only a better service on the main routes. The unreliability of British rail is a significant issue, as many other parts of the world, including developing countries, boast more reliable services. Efforts to make fares cheaper and rail travel more family-friendly have been minimal, with the Family railcard being largely ineffective.

Until the rail service improves, people will continue to use the increasingly clogged roads. Simply widening and building new roads is not a solution, as the number of cars on the roads will continue to grow to fill in the gaps. This is evident from the ongoing protests against the suspended work on the Newbury bypass, highlighting our limited options for expanding road infrastructure. One of the main side effects of road travel is pollution, with issues such as acid rain and asthma being widespread. As our fuel sources run out, the reliance on gas buses and gas stations becomes increasingly untenable. A renewable source must be found.

Solutions for these problems in Britain have been fairly unimaginative and unsuccessful, necessitating a reconsideration of current approaches and policies to address the country's transportation challenges.

"Main Problems" in road and rail transport are significant issues that concern operators to the extent that they hinder operations. The essay will be organized into four sections. There are many problems facing both road and rail transport in the UK. The most talked about issues concerning road are probably congestion and safety. Congestion is most apparant around the major conurbations such as London, Greater Manchester and Birmingham. The simple way to solve this problem would be to either build more roads or make the present ones larger. However this, as seen in recent events for example Newbury, has been met with strong opposition from environmental groups and local residents. another way to reduce congestion, especially in the large cities, could be to persuede people not to use their vehicles at all. Introducing schemes such as the 'park-and-ride' scheme and encouraging people to use bicycles would certainly reduce the number of cars on the road.
Safety is often talked about as a priority factor concerning roads. Too many accidents occur because of dangerous driving on busy roads. There are several ways to combat this problem. Although the legal limit for drinking while driving has just been increased lowering the limit by several units would detere many people from using their own vehicles and instead encourage them to use public transport.
Increasing the amount of law enforcement could also be effective, giving the police more right to make arrests and increasing the number of speed cameras as well as possibly give larger fines. Cutting down on national speed limit may also encourage drivers to take more care. The condition of roads is often a local issue rather then of national concern. It is therefore up to the local council to maintain their roads better, especially in winter. This may require the local council obtaining more money from the government.
Safety is much less of a factor for rail transport. Here the major talking point is efficiency. It is often noted that trains are delayed and are rarely running on time. Because of this inefficiency many of rails customers are turning to other forms of transport, cars mostly but for long distance journeys flying is an increasingly attractive option.
A large amount of blame for this inefficiency goes to the actual trains which are in most cases out of date and slower then modern ones such as the French TGV or the Japanese 'bullet' train.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
There are many problems facing both road and rail transport in the UK, with congestion and safety being some of the most talked-about issues for roads. Congestion is most apparent around major conurbations such as London, Greater Manchester, and Birmingham. A simple solution to this problem would be to either build more roads or make the present ones larger. However, as seen in recent events such as Newbury, this approach has been met with strong opposition from environmental groups and local residents. Another way to reduce congestion, especially in large cities, could be to persuade people not to use their vehicles at all. Introducing schemes such as the 'park-and-ride' scheme and encouraging people to use bicycles would certainly reduce the number of cars on the road.

Safety, on the other hand, is often discussed as a top priority concerning road transport. Too many accidents occur due to dangerous driving on busy roads. There are several ways to combat this problem, including lowering the legal limit for drinking while driving. Although the legal limit has recently been increased, lowering it by several units would deter many people from using their own vehicles, thereby encouraging them to use public transport. Increasing the amount of law enforcement could also be effective. Giving the police more rights to make arrests, increasing the number of speed cameras, and possibly imposing larger fines can contribute to enhancing road safety. Additionally, reducing the national speed limit might encourage drivers to take more care. The condition of roads is often a local issue rather than a national concern. Therefore, it is up to the local council to maintain their roads better, especially in winter, which may require the council to obtain more funding from the government.

Safety is much less of a factor for rail transport, where the major talking point is efficiency. It is often noted that trains are delayed and rarely running on time. This inefficiency has led many rail customers to turn to other forms of transport, such as cars for short trips or flying for long-distance journeys. A significant amount of blame for this inefficiency goes to the outdated trains, which are slower than modern ones, such as the French TGV or the Japanese 'bullet' train. Improving the efficiency of rail transport could help regain customer trust and shift more travel back to this environmentally friendlier mode. 

Overall, addressing the issues of congestion and safety in road transport, alongside improving efficiency in rail transport, presents a comprehensive approach to enhancing the United Kingdom's overall transportation system.

Travelling by motorway today is not as easy as it was meant to be by any standards, yet every morning and evening, motorways across the United Kingdom are blocked solid with traffic to and from work. Not only is this ecologically unsound, due to the harmful byproducts of the combustion engine, but it is also stressful, time-wasting, and expensive. Earth has a finite supply of fossil fuels from which petroleum and diesel, the fuels we rely on for cars and trains, are derived. However, we still have a need to get to work, which could be anything up to 200 miles away. Not only are there problems traveling from point A to point B, but there is also the added difficulty of finding parking in major cities, which can add to the wasted time and stress.

During pre-war Britain, rail was the only means of long-distance travel within the UK, making it more efficient with more frequent trains and many more stations. However, as the motor car became more popular, fewer people used the rail system, leading to its decline. The smaller demand resulted in less frequent services and higher prices. In my opinion, the way forward is the increased use of public transport systems because of the sheer waste caused by the average two-car family.

The majority of the cars you'll see travelling at a snail's pace along the M6 outside Birmingham will be driven by one person with no passengers. If these drivers had offered colleagues from work a lift home, the number of cars on the road would effectively be halved.

Cities like Manchester have tried to control the increasing number of cars by introducing bypasses and providing multi-storey car parking. Some cities have even banned cars from entering the city during work hours, making pedestrian life more enjoyable. Trams have been re-established in some cities, allowing people to leave their cars for shopping. This, in my opinion, is the attitude that should be adopted not only by town and city councils but also by the government to reduce the number of cars on the road.

Although Britain is said to have the oldest democrasy in the world,  however in many way this democrasy can be seen to be antiquated, old fashioned and unfair. There has not be whole sale reform of the electral system within Britain since women were granted the vote in the 1920's. This only alowed a growth in the electorate with the system of voting not having changed since the last century. This above all else can be seen to make Britain an undemocratic country.
The system used within Britain is known as the "First past the post" system. This is the system of direct constituencies. within these constiuencies the candidate with the largest number of votes is elected. This means that in many areas candidates are elected with under 50% of the total vote within that constituency. These successful candidate move on to the House of Commons to become MPs. This creates a house of representatives voted in by a minority vote in many cases (the only exceptions being for instance Huntington or Islington two very safe seats). This led the times when at a general election when parties have come to power with less votes than the main opposition party. This was the case in 1970 with the Conservative victory under Edward Heath. Many would argue that the weaknesses and unfairness of this system are apparent and that it should be changed. However there are strengths to this system. The first past the post system always leads to strong government usually leaving the governing party with a workable majority. Much of the work, to bring Britain into the modern economic world, done by the conservatives in the early 1960's was done through the first past the post system; The other option is proportional representation which is seen to give more say to the electorate on who get elected. But unfortunatly this system can lead to weak government allowing the growth of political extremist parties, through the ability to have a member of Parliament even with the overall vote. result:
Although Britain is often cited as having the oldest democracy in the world, this democrasy can be viewed as antiquated, old-fashioned, and unfair in many ways. There has not been a wholesale reform of the electoral system within Britain since women were granted the vote in the 1920s. This limited growth in the electorate, as the voting system remained unchanged for much of the last century. This, in part, renders Britain an undemocratic country.

The electoral system used in Britain is known as the "First past the post" system, which is a system of direct constituencies. In these constituencies, the candidate with the most votes is elected. This often results in candidates being elected with less than 50% of the total vote. These successful candidates move on to the House of Commons, where they become MPs. This leads to a House of Representatives that is sometimes elected by a minority of votes, with Huntington and Islington being the only exceptions. This has led to instances, such as the 1970 general election, where the Conservative party, led by Edward Heath, won with fewer votes than the main opposition party. While many criticize the weaknesses and unfairness of this system, it also has its strengths.

The First Past the Post system typically results in strong governments, usually providing the governing party with a workable majority. This system facilitated the work of the conservatives in the early 1960s, propelling Britain into the modern economic world. However, there is an alternative to this system: proportional representation.

Proportional representation is argued to give the electorate more say in who gets elected. However, this system also has drawbacks. It can lead to weak governments, potentially fostering the growth of political extremist parties, as even minimal votes can secure a seat in Parliament. The weak government could also upset the balance of power within Britain's three-party system, where the Liberal Democrats and the National Parties would always hold sway. Despite these concerns, the First Past the Post system remains a significant part of Britain's electoral landscape.

The British parliamentary electoral system is often criticized as unfair and undemocratic. However, I believe it remains the most effective basis for government. Consider a general election in a country with 5000 voters, where three parties—X, Y, and Z—compete for power. Suppose party X receives 2000 votes while parties Y and Z combine to get 1500 votes. Under this system, party X would come into power as it has the most votes. However, this result does not represent the majority's preference, with 3000 voters opposing party X. This raises questions about the system's democratic nature.

Moreover, the concept of each constituency having a Member of Parliament (MP) who represents its beliefs in parliament comes with significant flaws. For instance, MPs may switch parties, complicating voters' ability to choose representatives based on consistent beliefs. This situation highlights a disconnect between voter intentions and MPs' actions, particularly during elections. Once a party comes into power, it often shifts policies, making promises during campaigns that may not be fulfilled in practice. This cycle can lead to a lack of accountability and trustworthy governance.

Although I acknowledge these issues, it is important to consider that no electoral system is flawless. Dictatorships, for example, clearly fail by concentrating power in the hands of a single individual or group, which can result in economic disasters affecting not only the country in power but also its neighbors.

Ultimately, it is challenging to devise a perfectly fair system of government, as no system can please everyone at all times. In smaller groups of about ten people, the potential for discontent remains, but even then, achieving a universally satisfying system is difficult. Despite its imperfections, the British parliamentary electoral system offers a balance that is more favorable compared to extreme alternatives like dictatorships.

There have been many demonstrations by activists when fox hunting is taking place, and although I do not agree with some of the animal activists' methods, I strongly believe that fox hunting should be banned in the United Kingdom. My reasons for this stance are as follows.

Fox hunting, in my eyes, is a brutal sport carried out predominantly by the upper classes in society. It is often regarded as a traditional practice, having been conducted for many years. While it is true that foxes are regarded by many farmers as pests and can occasionally cause issues by killing chickens or other farm birds, this is merely an instinct for survival. Farmers usually permit fox hunting on their land because foxes, despite their predatory nature, need to feed themselves and their young. The opportunity for foxes to steal chickens is rare. Therefore, the occasional harm caused by foxes to farm animals should be seen in the context of their instinctual behaviors.

Moreover, the furs of foxes were once sought after for coats, but modern public opinion has rendered this practice obsolete. I find fox hunting pointless for several reasons: it involves excessive pomp and tradition, and it is too brutal on the now endangered wild fox population. Once a fox is spotted by the hunting party, a pack of hounds is unleashed, and the fox has little chance. Hunted in desperation, it cannot escape the overwhelming odds of approximately twenty blood-thirsty hounds. Although some foxes manage to escape or hide, in most cases, the outcome is tragic, with foxes being torn to pieces.

Since the beginning of man on this earth, we have always detected, stalked, captured, and killed our prey. This was essential for our survival. In the modern world, there is no need to hunt to obtain our food. This raises the moral issue: "Is it right and just to kill animals if we aren't going to eat them?" Are blood sports acceptable in today's society? Then again, should foxhunting be considered a sport?

Therefore, perhaps like recreational fishermen, the prey could be caught and then released. Unfortunately, the hounds won't see it this way.

The pursuit of fox hunting comes under a lot of attack from pressure groups. Protests are all very well, but recently, the protesters have taken it too far. In the first week of the New Year, a man and his wife were severely beaten up by a gang of protestors in front of their two young children. By doing so, the protestors are taking the law into their own hands and violating the very laws of humanity, which they ardently support.

By banning fox hunting, the law would probably drive the sport underground as it were, and participants would find some way around it. The sport has always been under attack, and strong public opinion against blood sports does not give protestors the right to fight back literally. There is a strong argument that fox hunting is a national institution and a tradition that should be continued. However, I don't think it will be banned. The best that can be done is to have police on site to ensure that, during a hunt, the fox is the only animal that gets killed.

Two men, one ring, only one can leave. This dramatic premise underscores the fundamental principle of boxing: the competition to emerge as the sole survivor. While rules have evolved over the years to lessen the sport's sadistic aspects, the question remains—should boxing be banned? Every time a boxer takes a punch to the head, their brain vigorously moves within the skull. This motion causes the loss of brain cells, which, when repeated frequently, can lead to long-term brain damage and potentially end a boxer's career prematurely. In my eyes—and likely many others—this is sufficient reason to ban boxing.

Despite its violent nature, boxing is often described as a blood sport, primarily because the goal is to incapacitate an opponent. Chris Eubank, a prominent boxer, argues that boxing is an art form, stating he aims not merely to knock out his opponent but to win by points. He believes in giving respect to opponents and that his fights are won based on skill rather than sheer violence. Yet, there is one stark exception that highlights the sport's inherent danger: the tragic incident where Michael Watson was put into a coma by Chris Eubank, the very boxer who doesn't claim to fight to knock opponents out. This incident serves as a chilling reminder of boxing's potential for harm.

Efforts by the boxing federation to make the sport safer have included the presence of ring-side doctors and the banning of bare-knuckle fights. However, the bottom line remains clear: any blow to the head can cause significant damage. The undeniable risk posed by boxing challenges the notion of its place in modern sports.

The National Lottery was criticized before its introduction as "a tax on the stupid." This criticism has two main facets. Firstly, it targets the government for attempting to raise additional revenue through the lottery without introducing a new tax. The government, aware of the widespread unpopularity of taxation, faced objections for marketing the lottery as a game while essentially raising funds. Critics were concerned not only about the government's share of lottery proceeds but also about the amount being allocated to "good causes." The slogan "it could be you" was heavily scrutinized.

Secondly, the criticism aimed at the lottery's marketing practices. Critics argued that marketing companies emphasized the likelihood of winning despite the statistical improbabilities. Despite this initial criticism, recent studies have demonstrated that most people have a reasonable view of the lottery, spending within their means. Contrary to fears, it was shown that lottery spending increases with income, with the poor spending the least and the rich the most. This suggests that the original critics may have overstated the number of people influenced by the lottery's appeal.

The criticism directed at the government was based on transparency about the allocation of lottery funds. All forms of gambling, including the National Lottery, are taxed, and most consumer spending is subject to Value Added Tax. Consequently, it would be unreasonable to expect the government to exempt the lottery from taxation.

Additionally, the National Lottery faced criticism for how it represented the breakdown of funds to various causes, notably charities. Critics argued that the contributions to charity were exaggerated, suggesting that the actual support for these causes would be significantly less impacted by the lottery's introduction than initially portrayed.

result:
The National Lottery was introduced to Britain in November 1994, and since its first draw, it has become increasingly popular, involving millions of people across the country each week. The proposal of a lottery brought about many objections and complaints. One of the principle concerns, which Anti-National Lottery Campaigners still have, is the impact on working-class citizens. People living in high society, who can afford to spend £10-20 a week, do not feel the financial strain. In contrast, working men and women, as well as unemployed individuals, work hard throughout the year and cannot afford to spend copious amounts of money on the lottery. This spending is beyond their means, despite their best efforts.

Another significant problem with the National Lottery is the encouragement of gambling. The National Lottery is essentially another gambling game, albeit a large-scale one. The probability of winning the jackpot is approximately 1 in 14 million, while the probability of winning ten pounds is 1 in 58. It is gambling, and more importantly, it introduces gambling to young people, including 16-year-olds. Many gambling problems are associated with the scratch cards linked to the lottery, which are easily purchased and offer the allure of immediate wealth. This instant gratification entices gamblers of all ages.

Despite these issues, the National Lottery also has its positive aspects. One of the main advantages is that it has helped charities and societies achieve things they otherwise could not. For instance, the lottery has funded a young child with brain problems, who received an expensive piece of stimulative equipment, and it has built a new village hall for a small community in the Shetland Islands. The lottery has created jobs, encouraged spending, and has made many people dream about the possibility of becoming rich.

In conclusion, the National Lottery has its good points and its bad points. Whether it should have been introduced is a personal decision that depends on how one rates these points. However, I believe the lottery is a benefit to the country.

When the National Lottery was introduced, 14 months ago, many arguments were put forward as to whether it should survive or whether it was harmful. The main objections to the Lottery were as follows: Firstly, by publicising a gambling event on such a wide scale, it brings gambling to a wider audience than it would otherwise have. Consequently, many people who may have otherwise not gambled, become addicted to gambling. Secondly, gambling is indulged in by a large number of people on lower incomes, who attempt to win prizes to improve their low standard of living. National Lottery draws have become a rigor part of Saturday nights for most British families. Some people have become millionaires overnight because their numbers have been picked. However, before the first draw was made, heated debate centered around whether the National Lottery should even exist.

During the debate, many interested parties stated their objections to the National Lottery. One of Britain's most famous businesses and families had a particular objection to the start of the National Lottery. The 'pool' companies and Littlewoods, in particular, were worried that people would stake a £1 on the National Lottery instead of pooling their money. This was a major part of their argument, as they feared the National Lottery would take their business away and lead to reduced employment, exacerbating the already high unemployment rate in Merseyside.

Charities were also worried about the impact of the National Lottery. They had been promised a share of the profits, specifically around 40p in the pound. However, calculations showed that charities would probably lose out due to reduced collections, which were vital for their funding. Clubs and charities that sold scratch cards as a source of income were concerned because they thought people would be less inclined to buy scratch cards for smaller prizes compared to the large money prizes offered by the Lottery. This concern was heightened when the Lottery's own scratch cards were introduced, potentially resulting in even less money for charities.

The large debate then centered around which organizations stood to benefit from the profits made by the Lottery. While charities expected a reasonable share, various organizations expressed interests in receiving funds, including applications to the National Heritage Office. Some money was allocated to build a series of monuments marking the start of the next millennium. Although many agreed with this initiative, people did not wish to see 'White Elephants' constructed.

Sports teams, clubs, social groups, and communities applied for cash for new facilities, and John Major announced that some profits would be used for the construction of a British Academy of Sport. However, there was concern that the money would not be evenly distributed, potentially contributing to the North-South divide.

When the national lottery was first introduced in November of 1994, many objections were raised about various different aspects of the lottery. Firstly, before the lottery actually started, there was conflict between two parties over who should actually run the lottery. These two parties were Michael Bronson's 'Virgin' group and another independent group, 'Camelot.' When it was decided that 'Camelot' would run the lottery, Richard Bronson objected, arguing that 'Camelot' intended to take a share of the profits from the National Lottery to donate a percentage to good causes, such as local support groups like homeless shelters, the Millennium Fund, and other more prominent charities. Another objection raised was that the National Lottery would create a 'gambler's society,' where people might become addicted to the thrill of trying their luck every week and might end up throwing away their money. This concern was particularly significant among low socio-economic groups, who viewed the lottery as a means to 'get rich quick,' despite their inability to afford it. Furthermore, there was concern that young people, under the age of sixteen, would also become hooked on the lottery, a potential addiction problem comparable to alcohol or drugs.

Lastly, the possibility of one single individual winning a sum of as much as £40 million was another major objection. Groups such as church teachers felt this was too much money for one person to have, especially given the numerous problems like famine and homelessness in the world. I think that it is possible to argue that the computer has made us both use and not use our brains for a number of reasons. Firstly, the introduction of computers has made us think more due to the numerous programs we use. Learning to navigate these programs can take quite a while, and as soon as one program or computer is released, it quickly becomes outdated because people are constantly thinking about improving it. After all, it was humans who invented the computer in the first place; computers can't replace the human brain (at least, not yet).

It is possible to say that using computers does not stop us from using our brains as much; instead, they serve as quick, efficient time-savers. For example, consider the difference between using a word processing program and writing with an old-fashioned typewriter. If you were to make a mistake writing an important letter, you would have to start over, whereas a single key press on a computer can eliminate such errors.

People often claim that computer games do not require brainpower to be played. However, some games are so challenging that people from around the world consult with each other to solve them. This collaboration, facilitated by computers, is a quick, efficient way to communicate and solve complex problems. Yet, there are also computer games that require no brainpower at all, simply keeping your finger on a button, which showcases another way computers have stopped us using our brains.

Despite the time-saving capabilities of computers, they can perform almost every task with a single touch. They can solve difficult mathematical sums, check for spelling errors in essays, letters, and other documents, and much more. This efficiency could lead to the argument that we are not using our brains as much. From simple tasks like doing homework to complex operations such as running a nuclear power station, computers handle everything. For instance, at the Hesselam's Nuclear Power Station control room, one man can manage millions of pounds' worth of computers, while the rest of us sit back and let them do the work.

Computers have even taken on more advanced roles, such as communicating with each other, flying planes, and building cars. In the future, computers may even be running the country, highlighting the dual nature of their impact on our use of the brain.

The development of more sophisticated and technologically advanced computers, such as the Amiga and PC, has served to deepen this "problem." The growing realism of the games appeals strongly to children, but parents feel that children should be broadening their minds by reading books instead. Additionally, some parents believe that the computer games industry encourages children not to learn academic skills. Computers have also been blamed for a perceived fall in education standards among primary school children; a belief accentuated by survey results showing that the majority of primary school children struggle with simple arithmetic and rely heavily on calculators.

Another moral dilemma that computers have created is their role in the workplace. Many people fear that computers will eventually replace humans in the workplace. The role of computers is already significant in employment areas such as accountancy, which require specialist abilities for calculating and manipulating numbers. These computers have replaced humans, prompting fears that unemployment levels could increase as a result. As computers are more efficient than humans, do not require payment for their work, are less temperamental than humans, and will never have a day off, it seems mankind is faced with a serious problem.

Furthermore, another claim is that computers could potentially render the human brain obsolete by promoting anti-social behavior. The creation of the World Wide Web and the Internet has sparked concerns that people may become unsociable. While the Internet allows for global communication and offers numerous conveniences, many worry that its fundamental problem lies in its ability to foster a lack of real-world interaction.

The computer has been one of the most influential inventions of all time, significantly impacting government business, science, and communication, as well as many other aspects of human life. In many ways, it has taken the place of the human brain in performing calculations and thought processes. The most obvious example of this is the calculator, an instrument used by mathematicians and scientists for making numerical calculations. This has made it no longer necessary for humans to perform calculations and run through equations; instead, people need only to know which buttons to press. While this view may seem extreme, it is worth noting that there is still much in the world of maths and science that a computer cannot calculate. However, this may not be the case centuries into the future.

Computers have also been used as a means of keeping records, effectively superseding handwritten text. In a few decades, people may well be faced with a computer screen and keyboard in their General Studies exams. Beyond academics, computers are used to transfer money across the globe, create artwork, and entertain. Computer-generated pictures, including fractal images drawn from equations, seem to be more popular than hand-painted images from an artist's imagination. Furthermore, computer games seem to provide more entertainment than any game or activity that takes place in the real, physical world. Virtual reality also allows people to have immersive entertainment created for them by a computer.

Whether or not the computer is taking over from the human brain, it has certainly made the human body all but redundant. People, businesses, or corporations can be contacted at any point around the globe by fax machines, e-mail, and the internet. Some people prefer these forms of communication to actually meeting face-to-face. Additionally, money can be transferred instantly without even needing to move the actual money; it is the computer records that state how much each bank owns.

However, the idea that the human brain is no longer useful is not entirely true. Computers cannot deal with human beings, have no capacity for coping with anything outside their expected situations, and cannot adapt to new situations using judgment. Despite these limitations, the computer's impact on human life and society continues to be profound and far-reaching.

It is now the age of the computer. Almost everyone owns a computer or has access to one. Computers nowadays are a far cry from the ones in the past, which filled whole rooms. They are able to generate amazingly accurate graphical representations and perform extremely difficult mathematical equations in just seconds. This technological advancement has made computers a crucial part of our lives both in work and education; however, we must ask whether they are entirely beneficial.

When calculators became commonplace, a noticeable decline in students' ability to perform mental arithmetic was evident. Now, computers handle the simplest calculations, leading some to argue that they encourage laziness. While computers are undeniably time-saving and efficient, they also cause people to forget basic skills, such as spelling. This reliance on technology is concerning, as spell-check may offer convenience, but it undermines the importance of the skill itself.

For the youth today, computers provide links to the world and vast resources of facts and figures. Some may argue this is educational, but it could also stifle imagination. Children might spend hours at a keyboard, confined to the digital realm, rather than engaging in real-life experiences. Instead of sitting in darkness at night, they should be enjoying daylight activities and adventures.

The idea that computers enable us to meet people and form relationships through digital interactions seems preposterous to many. This shift threatens our ability to communicate and build genuine connections in person. Further, while computers offer an escape from the humdrum routine of daily life through games, they often fail to stimulate creativity and invention, becoming mind-numbing and uninteresting.

However, there is also a more dangerous threat from computers: the potential for them to replace human labor. This could lead to high unemployment, especially for those who work with computers for long periods. The repetitive nature of key tapping and screen staring can be harmful, both physically and mentally. Boredom and lack of engagement can take a toll.

As we contemplate the future, we must consider the role that computers will play in shaping it. It is essential to find a balance that allows us to leverage technological advancements while maintaining our essential human skills and connections. Only by doing so can we ensure that computers serve as a valuable tool without diminishing our humanity.

Assuming that computers will always operate mechanically and think mechanistically, they will only ever perform tasks like those calculators used in schools. If children lose the ability to do these calculations themselves, it is arguably morally wrong. After all, it represents a progression; they will never need to use these skills in the future.

However, with the exponential growth of computer capabilities, it may be possible for computers to eventually replace part of the brain, making it completely redundant. This raises profound questions about our future and the ethical implications of such a profound technological advancement.

Scientists believe that it may not be safe to eat beef products. Several years ago the disease BSE or 'Mad Cow Disease' became quite commonplace amongst cattle. The disease incurs a mental deficiency, where the cow cannot think for itself, and slowly dies. This BSE has been known to cross the animal barriers; several sheep have had a similar disease after eating feed made from the reminants of dead, meatstripped cows. Now, scientists fear that it has crossed the boundary between cows and humans, as there are more and more cases of Creutzfeld-Jacob Disease (CJD) appearing more frequently. There is, as of yet, no cure for this disease, and the only way humans could contract it would be by eating beef products. This clearly has put a lot of people off beef, as the press also had coverage of the inefficient quality control by the government, and the fact that this has been going on for years is worrying. The disease can take upto 15-20 years to become evident in humans, so even if people gave up beef today, they will have a chance of getting CJB. However, to give up the products now would reduce the chances of being crippled by this disease in the future. 
If a lot of people did give up beef products, this will have had effects on the agricultural industry. Cattle farmers will be hit particularly badly if no-one wants to buy their meat. It will affect other animals being sold for meat also; more people will want to buy the meat from sheep and pigs and so-on so they can still eat the same amount of meat. The whole episode may send the price of beef down so people will buy it and take the risk (which must be tiny) rather than forking out for more expensive meat products. If no-one wants to eat beef then cows will only be bred for their milk, which means there will be less cows in the future possibly. If cows are no longer required by the public for food, some abbattoir workers may lose jobs, and several butchers, to whom the money from beef products is a considerable percentage of their income, may be hit hard by this.
The politicians still say it is safe, and that they will continue to eat beef.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
Scientists believe that it may not be safe to eat beef products. Several years ago, the disease BSE, also known as 'Mad Cow Disease', became quite commonplace amongst cattle. The disease causes mental deficiencies, where cows cannot think for themselves, and eventually die. This BSE has been known to cross animal barriers, with several sheep having similar diseases after consuming feed made from the remnants of dead, meat-stripped cows. Now, scientists fear that it has also crossed the boundary between cows and humans, as there has been an increase in cases of Creutzfeld-Jakob Disease (CJD). There is currently no cure for this disease, and humans can only contract it by eating beef products. This concern has made many people hesitant to eat beef, especially since the media has highlighted the poor quality control and the long duration of the issue.

The fear is heightened by the fact that the disease can take up to 15-20 years to become evident in humans, meaning even if people stopped eating beef today, they would still risk contracting CJD in the future. However, ceasing beef consumption now could reduce the chances of being afflicted by this disease in the long run. If a significant number of people gave up beef, it would have a ripple effect on the agricultural industry, particularly cattle farmers who would suffer from reduced meat sales. This could also impact the sale of other meats, like sheep and pigs, as people might opt for these alternatives to maintain their meat consumption.

The episode might lead to a decrease in beef prices, tempting some to take the risk and buy beef instead of opting for more expensive alternatives. If no one wants to eat beef, cows could be bred solely for their milk, potentially reducing their numbers in the future. This shift might also result in some abattoir workers and butchers losing their jobs, as the income from beef products constitutes a significant portion of their earnings.

Despite these concerns, politicians continue to assert that beef is safe and maintain their consumption habits. However, the growing instances of BSE and CJD have created a growing fear among the public, questioning the safety of beef. The debate over beef consumption and its potential risks continues to impact both consumers and the agricultural industry.

The discovery of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (B.S.E), often termed 'mad cows disease,' and, although not yet fully proven, its human equivalent, Creutzfeld-Jakob Disease (C.J.D), presents significant risks to both public health and the farming industry. Recent statistics indicate a troubling increase in B.S.E cases, which has been sensationalized by the British press, fueling public fear that consuming British beef might lead to severe health issues such as C.J.D. In its most severe instances, C.J.D can be fatal; however, the majority of cases result in severe brain damage, leaving sufferers dependent on others. Despite these alarming developments, the direct correlation between consuming British beef and contracting C.J.D remains unproven; studies on mice have cast doubt on this link. While the rise in reported C.J.D cases in the U.K. might be attributed in part to improved medical technology and more accurate diagnoses, it is also important to note that the Netherlands has a higher death rate from C.J.D. Although lower, the U.S.A also experiences cases of C.J.D. 

Therefore, the recent beef scare, amplified by the media, could have detrimental effects on the British farming community. The introduction of the Common Agricultural Policy post-World War II aimed to make Europe self-sufficient, addressing the severe food shortages experienced during the war. As a result, the U.K. achieved near full self-sufficiency, supported by the European Union's financial backing for farmers. The guaranteed purchase of unsold stock at market price has helped keep farmers in business.

In essence, a significant decline in public demand for beef would lead the EU to face a surplus of Q1-Q2, possibly resulting in further production restrictions, known as quotas. These measures would have a profound impact on the farming industry, potentially causing economic hardship and affecting the livelihoods of those within this essential and profitable sector.

The main problem in the United Kingdom is BSE or as it is so-called "Mad Cow Disease". It has been discovered that the disease can be transmitted to humans due to consumption of the infected beef.
Beef production is a fairly large business in the U.K and it was necessary to discover more about this relatively new disease.
It was discovered that British farmers were to blame, due to their various industrial techniques. The disease originally, was carried by chickens. When the farmers killed the chickens for their meat, the remains (bone and organs) were processed to provide a cheep feeding product. Unfortunately the disease carrying organs were not just fed back to chickens but to cows as well. The cows contracted the disease (in a slightly different form) and this was when "BSE" first came about.
The correct thing to do, would have been to destroy the infected cows bringing an end to a potentially life-threatening situation. However, the farmers had money involved and did not. When the infected cows were slaughtered for beef, their remains were processed and fed back to other cattle spreading the disease further.
Unfortunately, unlike the chickens, the cattle were able to pass this disease on to humans in their beef.
The same industrial techniques are still used today, and with the people in the UK becoming aware of the facts and more health concious, the sales in beef have decreased.
It is impossible to learn that you have contracted the disease for up to seven years. And so, some attitudes of the public are: "Why should I stop eating beef if I could already have BSE?". Another public attitude is to ignore warnings as there have not been any victims. But it seems that the most popular option is to be safe and quit beef entirely.
It seems that more and more families have opted for chicken, pork or lamb as an alternative.

result:
The main problem in the United Kingdom is BSE, also known as "Mad Cow Disease." The disease, which can be transmitted to humans through the consumption of infected beef, has raised significant concerns. Beef production, a substantial industry in the U.K., became a focal point as more information about this relatively new disease emerged. It was discovered that British farmers were partly to blame due to their industrial techniques. The disease was originally carried by chickens. When farmers killed the chickens for their meat, the remains (bone and organs) were processed into a cheap feed. Unfortunately, the disease-carrying organs were fed not only back to chickens but also to cows. This led to cows contracting the disease in a slightly different form, giving rise to BSE.

Rather than destroying the infected cows, which would have ended the potentially life-threatening situation, farmers continued to process them for beef sale, further spreading the disease. Unlike chickens, cattle were able to pass the disease on to humans through their beef.

Despite the industrial techniques still being in use, awareness among the people in the UK has increased, leading to a decrease in beef sales. Learning that one has contracted the disease can take up to seven years, which has contributed to public attitudes such as, "Why should I stop eating beef if I could already have BSE?" and, "There have been no victims, so I should ignore the warnings." The most popular option, though, seems to be to be safe and quit beef entirely. Consequently, more families are opting for alternative meats such as chicken, pork, or lamb.

The situation could have devastating effects on the agricultural industry. If demand decreases significantly, farmers might reduce beef production, potentially leading them to switch to alternative products, fundamentally altering the industry's landscape.

Recently, the consumption of beef in the UK has fallen dramatically. This has caused many problems not only for beef farmers, but for the economy as a whole, since the exportation of beef brings welcome finances into Britain.
The reason for beef consumption in the UK falling is because of "Mad cow disease" or BSE. This is a disease which affects the cerebral cortex of the cows brain. It is therefore feared, due to poor knowledge in the scientific world, that there is a contractable human equivalent called Creutzfeld Jacobs disease or CJD. This lack of knowledge has immediately made the public afraid, and are now turning to substitutes. If these falls in sales keep going, then it is possible to see many of these farmers going out of business and into unemployment. For farmers this would be disasterous. These farmer have been farming beef all their lives, and know nothing else. If farmers live in marginal land areas, then the resulting population will become unskilled, and ageing.
I personally believe that the agricultural industry will never collapse, due to the common agricultural policy (CAP), and price support by the government. The government wants to be self-sufficient, and also keep unemployment as low as possible, so the government will start to buy up surpluses. <figure> In this situation, at price P, more is supplied, than demanded, but this intervention price means that the farmers can produce what they like, as they get to sell their surplus anyway.
All this will do for the agricultural industry is ensure farmers can predict their income for the next year. This is because once these "price-support schemes" are started, they are very difficult to take down again.

Recently, the consumption of beef in the UK has fallen dramatically, leading to many problems not only for beef farmers but also for the broader economy, as the exportation of beef brings welcome finances into Britain. The reason for the decline in beef consumption is primarily due to "Mad cow disease" or BSE, a disease that affects the cerebral cortex of cows. Because of the lack of comprehensive scientific knowledge, there is a fear that BSE has a human equivalent called Creutzfeld-Jacobs disease (CJD). This lack of knowledge has immediately made the public afraid and has driven them towards substitutes, further decreasing demand. Consequently, this reduction in demand has led to lower prices, placing farmers in deep financial trouble. In figure 1, we can see that the original price and quantity demanded were significantly higher than in figure 2, where a fall in demand resulted in a price reduction.

If these sales declines continue, it is possible to see many farmers going out of business and into unemployment. For these farmers, who have dedicated their lives to beef farming and have no other skills, this would be disastrous. Particularly for those living in marginal land areas, the resulting population may become unskilled and aging.

However, I believe the agricultural industry will not collapse, thanks to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) and the government's price support mechanisms. The government aims to be self-sufficient and maintain low unemployment rates, so it will buy up surpluses to stabilize the market. This intervention price allows farmers to produce what they want, knowing they can sell their surplus anyway. This ensures that farmers can predict their income for the next year, as these "price-support schemes" are difficult to dismantle once implemented.

In conclusion, although BSE is a dangerous disease, it is unlikely to cause the agricultural industry to collapse to the extent that was anticipated, thanks to government intervention and support mechanisms.

There are various reasons why people in the UK may decide to stop eating beef. Firstly, it may be in response to the protests at ports trying to prevent calves being exported, where they may be used as veal calves and put into veal crates, which are uncomfortable for the animal and have been banned for many years in the UK. Scenes of calves in these crates or of protests, which have sometimes turned deadly, both on television or in newspapers, may have persuaded people to either become vegetarian or at least stop eating beef. The emergence of BSE (mad cow disease) among cattle and the linked (or possibly linked) Creutzfeldt-Jacobs disease (CJD) have alarmed consumers so much so that many schools have banned beef from the menu. Despite the risk of contracting CJD, which is minutely small and the number of cases per year has stayed roughly the same, the media hype has blown the disease out of proportion. Consequently, people are now very wary of eating beef, resorting to other products such as lamb instead.

The effect on the agricultural industry, including beef producers, is catastrophic. Prices have already decreased by as much as 20p per kilogram at auction, which is a substantial loss when an average beef animal weighs around 500 kg. Many farmers may go out of business due to this loss in profits or may diversify into other products such as arable crops. This may then bring the price of beef back up in the future, although this will also bring problems of arable overproduction and increase storage costs for excess produce. This situation may cause prices in the arable market to rise as more farmers shift their production to arable crops. Thus, the effects of people not eating beef will have a knock-out effect throughout large areas of the agricultural industry. Beef producers would find it increasingly hard to make profits as they would have to increase sales to maintain revenue while also incurring the excess costs of food and other expenses such as bills. This scenario may necessitate reducing the labor force, thus increasing unemployment and government benefit payments simultaneously.

In summary, the reasons people in the UK stop eating beef, such as concerns over calf welfare, BSE, and CJD, not only affect consumer choices but also have far-reaching consequences for the agricultural industry, impacting beef prices, producers’ livelihoods, and the broader economic landscape.

This incident, along with the media's portrayal of "mad cow disease," has contributed to a belief among some UK residents that eating beef may have adverse effects.

"Mad cow disease," which causes a cow's brain to turn into a spongy semi-liquid, has been widely reported by tabloids, documentaries, ITN, BBC news, and gossip, leading to widespread fear. This fear, primarily driven by media narratives, has caused a sharp decline in beef consumption. Although other factors, such as increasing numbers of vegetarians and people on low-fat diets, may also contribute to the decline, they are not expected to be nearly as significant.

The agricultural industry relies on cattle for meat production. Any farmer with a substantial number of cattle relies on the sale of beef for their financial stability. A sudden shift in public taste away from beef can leave dairy farmers with cattle they cannot sell. When there is little demand for a product, there is little point in producing it. Therefore, if demand for beef decreases, fewer farmers will have cattle to slaughter, which will have a ripple effect on suppliers of cattle materials like feed and services such as slaughterhouses.

The problem facing the Monarchy is how to adapt to modern life whilst still retaining a traditional role. The pressures<?> can be seen with the growing question of whether the Prince of Wales may rule as king when being a divorcee. This brings up the issue of him being the Head of the Church of England and so the main problems lie in discussions about the future rather than the present. Also their role in society is a matter of debate: are they there in order to just open hospitals and wave to people? This is the image often seen by the normal subject, discounting of course the scandals within the newspapers.
	The pressures of growing media coverage and ever more efficient ways of hearing and seeing what is intended to be private questions the Monarchy's fitness to govern. The use of telephoto lenses has produced pictures casting shadows over their morality, such as the infamous activities of the Duchess of York. The Monarchy's right to govern is also questionable since it is a non-elected body presiding over an apparent democracy, however limited this, in fact, is.
	An argument for retaining the Monarchy is the enormously useful role the Monarch plays. The present Queen is an adviser on constitutional matters to the govenment and such advice is often useful. Also the experience obtained over many years of govening and advising govenment, since she sees the cabinet papers, is of benefit for the country. The role is necessary in deciding who is to make a govenment, this is especially true if there is a hung parliament and the Queen will assess who can produce an effective government. Since all laws need the royal assent then the Queen acts as a safeguard against any truely damaging acts, such as if there was an attempt to form a dictatorship. Also the activity in calling general elections is a right of the Monarchy and so provides a useful role in the administration of the country. This may also prevent a prime minister from attempting to 'cash in' on short term popularity, such as if a war has just been won, as the Monarch can refuse to call such an election.
	If the Monarchy was abolished it leaves the question what is to replace it. There is a need for a Head of State for diplomatic purposes, therefore a President is needed.<|end|><|assistant|>
result:
The problem facing the Monarchy is how to adapt to modern life whilst still retaining a traditional role. The pressures of growing media coverage and ever more efficient ways of hearing and seeing what is intended to be private question the Monarchy's fitness to govern. The use of telephoto lenses has produced pictures casting shadows over their morality, such as the infamous activities of the Duchess of York. Additionally, the Monarchy's right to govern is increasingly questioned, as it is a non-elected body presiding over an apparent democracy, however limited this may be.

An argument for retaining the Monarchy is the enormously useful role it plays. The present Queen, for example, is an adviser on constitutional matters to the government, and such advice is often useful. Her experience obtained over many years of governing and advising the government, since she sees the cabinet papers, is of benefit for the country. This role is necessary in deciding who is to make a government, especially in the case of a hung parliament, where she will assess who can produce an effective government. Since all laws need the royal assent, the Queen acts as a safeguard against any truly damaging acts, such as attempts to form a dictatorship. Moreover, the Monarchy's right to call general elections acts as a useful role in the country's administration, potentially preventing a prime minister from attempting to 'cash in' on short-term popularity, such as if a war has just been won.

If the Monarchy were abolished, it leaves the question of what is to replace it. There is a need for a Head of State for diplomatic purposes, and thus a President would be necessary.

Every year, the Monarchy costs the British public millions of pounds. This money contributes towards keeping the Monarchy in the style to which it has become accustomed to living in, maintaining numerous palaces around the country, several retreats abroad, and a fleet of cars (each with its own chauffeur, no doubt) of ridiculous proportions; not to mention several boats and private carriages on trains. Plus, the indirect expenditure of round-the-clock bodyguards and constant policing. Admittedly, when divided by the number of people paying taxes in the country, this figure amounts to less than one pound each year per person. However, surely this money could be put to better uses—reducing the national debt or towards scientific research—rather than merely increasing the already vast Royal fortune.

"In Vitro fertilisation" (IVF) is the process of fertilising an egg in the laboratory, such as in a test tube. The egg is taken from the mother and placed in an environment optimized for fertilisation by sperm from the father. Once fertilisation occurs, the fertilised egg is implanted back into the mother's womb, and from there on, the pregnancy follows a normal course. Typically, more than one egg is retrieved from the mother to increase the chances of a successful pregnancy, leading to multiple births like twins or triplets.

However, some people oppose IVF, arguing that it is not natural and that life should start from the moment of conception. They raise ethical concerns, such as who should be given the treatment, the appropriate age for undergoing it, and whether it is justifiable to spend significant amounts of money on IVF when those funds could instead save numerous lives through measles vaccinations. Proponents of IVF argue that it is a person's right to have their own children. For women who would normally be unable to conceive due to conditions like blocked fallopian tubes, IVF offers a fair chance to have children, regardless of their age or health conditions.

As technology has advanced rapidly, ethical and practical guidelines have not always kept pace, leading to debates about regulations. One example of this is the case of a post-menopausal woman who was given IVF treatment by lying about her age. 

Given these complexities, it is crucial to ensure that fertility treatments are administered responsibly. Regulations should be in place to ensure that fertility treatments are only given when medically appropriate and ethically justified, considering both the potential benefits and the broader implications for society.

Concerns include the potential damage to the baby and whether society could become too dependent on artificial fertilisation methods.

Recent developments in the field of genetic engineering have largely stemmed from discoveries made and techniques developed during this century, starting with the discovery of DNA and the mapping and understanding of its structure. The manipulation of genes, an incredibly important and dangerously powerful ability, can no longer be left solely to the scientists to look after; we are all now affected by the results of genetic engineering, whether for medical or commercial reasons. Tomatoes are designed and engineered to last longer, apples to grow bigger, crops to ripen later to allow for transport time, and pigs are used to grow insulin for human use. If we are going to accept the advantages that come with genetic engineering, we must also take responsibility for the disadvantages, as the stakes are too high to leave this job solely to the scientists. The world of genetic engineering is a fiercely competitive and rapidly expanding area of science. The research in the last decade or so has made unbelievable progress at every turn, not all of it 'morally viable', so to speak. The theory that scientists should take responsibility for their work and its consequences is an interesting idea, but there is one basic function of human psychology that makes this hypothesis invalid. When an individual scientist is working on research, they are almost always working under sponsorship or directly working for a company. This means that any responsibility they feel for their actions is shifted to their employers or sponsors. This effect has been studied for many years and several well-documented experiments show the effect clearly. It has been shown to have been present in WWII when German troops killed Jews; they did not hold themselves responsible because they had been told to do it—they had been set on their course by someone else. Similarly, people in command positions in many scientific situations easily commit themselves to decisions simply because there is no immediacy for them—i.e., they rarely see their decisions face-to-face.

Using the analogy of the persecution of Jews in WWII again, it was said that Goebbels was physically sick when he actually visited the concentration camps and saw what happened, yet he could still order the camps to carry out their work because he had no sense of immediacy in the situation when he was sat in his office in Berlin.

This is all very interesting, you may say, but these geneticists must feel some moral obligation. The actual work of genetic engineering is constantly coming up for discussion in today's media world. The work of many leading laboratories has been recognized as useful and moralistic. For example, the production of insulin by genetic engineering is undoubtedly a laudable use of scientific knowledge, as is the development of high-yield crops for third-world countries—another useful facet of genetic control.

However, looking at these examples, are they really as good as they sound? High-yield crops, for instance, do indeed give many times the harvest of a normal variety yet leach the soil, require very careful use of oil-based fertilizers, and necessitate countless other minor adjustments. Are these plants morally reprehensible because they require greater care and nurturing than their hardier cousins?

A scientist's job is often a subject of debate: Is it the blind pursuit of knowledge and the discovery of the unknown, or the implementation and use of ideas, whether his own or others'? I believe the answer leans towards the former—a scientist uncovers what is unknown. The latter falls more within the realm of business.

Consider how difficult it would be for a scientist to shoulder the responsibility for his work if others implemented his discoveries. Could Einstein, one of the greatest scientists of the 20th century, be held responsible for the development of the atom bomb, or more recently, the catastrophes at Three Mile Island or Chernobyl? Einstein's work laid the theoretical foundation for nuclear weapons, and the subsequent development of the nuclear weapons program provided the catalyst for nuclear electricity generation. Can we blame Einstein for this?

He cannot prevent others from continuing his work, nor can he ensure that his discoveries won't be made by others. In the real, money-driven world, these pressures push him to continue his work, with money being the most significant factor: if he sees a potential monetary bonus, he is likely to continue his work. Additionally, taking moral responsibility for a discovery made by pure luck is challenging. Consider an extreme example: a chemical researcher deliberately mixes chemicals, unaware of its effects, creating an unknown but deadly substance that kills his entire research team. These considerations reveal the complexities of a scientist's responsibilities, where the pursuit of knowledge often intersects with ethical and practical dilemmas.

Genetic manipulation has been going on for many centuries in the form of selective breeding, both of crops and animals. This technique has been of great benefit to the human race, enabling the production of more food, better food, and new and interesting varieties of food. Additionally, it has aided the development of different natural fibers such as wool and cotton. However, it is only in very recent times that genetic manipulation has been seen to have both positive and negative sides.

This shift is because we are now at the stage where scientists can alter an organism by changing its genes in some way. I do not believe that the scientists who originally began research into the nature of genetics had any idea that it would one day be put to both good and bad uses—they simply wanted to find out what it was all about, and thus cannot be blamed for any later events.

Today, much research is being carried out on human genes to find out how they work and whether they can be altered to prevent diseases. The scientists who work on this cannot be blamed if someone else uses their techniques for less philanthropic ends—for example, in biological warfare or to eliminate a 'gay' or 'criminal' gene which may be present in human embryos.

Where scientists can be blamed is in the case of genetically engineered tomatoes, which are now available in a supermarket near you, with their genes altered to increase their redness, juiciness, or resistance to disease. These tomatoes are likely safe, but if they, or some other genetically engineered food, were to prove to cause a terrible disease, that would be the fault of the scientist who developed them because they did not adequately test them to ensure they were safe. Similarly, if genetically engineered vaccines or medicines prove to have harmful side effects, that would be because they were not adequately tested before being released into the market, and the scientists would be to blame.

This bacteria was then left to reproduce, producing insulin throughout its life time. This insulin is then extracted and given to diabetics. This process is preferable to grinding down cow's livers. Cows have been bred for milk and for their meat by simply breeding cows who produce lots of milk due to a genetic defect together eventually after many generations cows will be produced yielding much more milk than their offspring would need.

result:
Genetic manipulation holds the promise of a future where inherited diseases like hemophilia and cystic fibrosis can be eliminated. This future hinges on the ability to map the entire human genome, which would allow scientists to understand the function of each gene. With this detailed knowledge, genes that cause diseases can be identified in the fetus. Should these genes be detected, they can be replaced with healthy ones, potentially curing the condition before it manifests.

Genetic Engineering, as a method of producing substances lacking in the human body, has already proven invaluable. For instance, the human gene for insulin production was inserted into plasmids within bacteria. These genetically modified bacteria, which also contained an antibiotic resistance gene, were then allowed to reproduce, producing insulin that could be extracted and administered to diabetics. This method is preferable to extracting insulin from cow's liver, and it demonstrates how genetic engineering can be critical to treating certain diseases, allowing those affected to live relatively healthy lives.

In the realm of agriculture, genetic manipulation has also been applied through selective breeding. For example, cows have been bred over generations to produce more milk by combining cows with genetic traits that favor higher milk production. Similarly, crops have been engineered to yield more and withstand various challenges, such as drought, pests, and diseases, thus improving food security.

Looking ahead, there is potential to alter the physical and mental capabilities of humans. However, this prospect is fraught with ethical concerns. The creation of 'superhumans' for specific roles, such as enhanced fighters, raises serious moral issues. To prevent such misuse, stringent controls must be established over genetic manipulation, ensuring it serves to help disadvantaged individuals rather than creating superhumans. Mental ability alterations should not be pursued, as this too would be morally indefensible.

The responsibility for regulating these powerful technologies lies with scientists. As the experts with the necessary knowledge and skills to create 'superhumans,' they must bear the burden of ensuring that genetic manipulation is used responsibly, to improve lives rather than creating inequality or unethical outcomes. Genetic manipulation should aim to normalize disadvantaged people, not transform them into superhumans.
